Thank you so much again for checking out our page! If you have any questions or feedback, please reach out to us by using this contact form.

story:
Introduction

 

        Have you ever wondered what happens to your "recycled" plastic items? 

Do you really know where it goes? 

Statistics show over 91% of plastic isn't recycled and goes directly to landfills. And nothing is being done about it.  Between 1950 and 2015, humans produced 8.3 billion metric tons of plastics, 6.3 billion tons of which ended up in landfills. (source: GREENMATTERS)  The 1's and 3's that are deemed acceptable for recycling are not so easily sorted out, and unfortunately, waste management companies do not see it as worth their time or money. 

Pacific Resource Recycling Systems (PACRRS ) aims to use a closed-loop gasification system to turn plastic into reusable and renewable energy and resources with zero emissions.

At PACRRS, our facility will take any plastics, clean or dirty, and use it as a fuel to create a renewable energy.  So if you are worried about where your plastics go and what happens to it, we are here to tell you that we ARE doing something about it!

PACRRS was started to not only remove, but also reuse plastics to create a clean and reusable energy that we can all use today, and for future generations.  Our passion is to do something about this epidemic, and the oceans of plastic that are clogging the arteries of our planet.  Through new technology, and with the help of proven processes that have been around for years, we are able to provide a place where we can do just that.

The PACRRS team is committed to bringing good paying jobs to the local Lebanon community and the larger Willamette Valley as a whole while protecting the environment for all to live, work, and play.  However, our goal to work towards solving this problem of plastics and nonrenewable energy sources cannot be possible without your help and support.

 

Our Impact

Each day, the PACRRS facility will be able to process 50 metric tons of plastics and generate countless quantities of renewable assets by starting off with one gasification unit using cutting edge technology.  In the future, we hope to be able to expand and scale up to 4-6 units in Lebanon as well as look into opening up more facilities in other counties and states.  The amount of processed tons of plastic will grow in size as new units evolve, growing from 50 metric tons to upwards of 100 tons or more as engineering efforts increase to create larger capacity gasification units.

All types of plastic would be able to be collected and used for the process, including: 

  • Straws
  • Styrofoam
  • Film Plastics
  • Carpets
  • Car Parts (plastic)

With your support, PACRRS will be the first commercial operation that starts using plastic as a fuel, to spearhead the effort to clean the planet of plastic while providing much-needed resources and energy.

In turn, the facility's gasification process will provide specific renewable resources through our engineering efforts, such as:

  • Syngas
  • Fuel
  • Electricity
  • Hydrogen
  • Renewable Natural Gas (RNG)
  • Ethanol

 

Our Technology 

PACRRS will use gasification technology, which converts organic- or fossil fuel-based carbonaceous materials into carbon monoxide, hydrogen and carbon dioxide.  This is achieved by reacting the material at high temperatures.

Compared to an average waste burning system, PACRRS will be using the latest technology to reach temperatures of around 4000+°​F which ensures that all waste breaks down at the molecular level.  Organic material is vaporized and collected as a clean syngas.  Inorganic material melts and is collected as metal and non-leaching vitrified stone. There are no major byproducts from the process that require additional disposal.  Our ultimate goal is to create completely clean, reusable energy and outputs that are all contained in a closed-looped system to emit zero waste.  We believe this is what sets PACRRS apart from others who use traditional gasification processes.

Gasification Overview:  This is a very basic model of the gasification process.  The full ability and additional technologies that are needed to produce the energies we have outlined are not shown here, due to classifications and restrictions.

Site Model:  The following is a set of different sections that will be uniform once we can share the completed model.  Due to ongoing configuration and engineering, we can only show small sections at a time.  The general idea is Receive, Ingest, Clean, and lastly Store clean energy.

 

Future Partnerships & Education Goals

Our community is at the heart of our operation and drives everything that we do.  With the 46 acres of land that has already been acquired for our facility, the PACRRS team would like to set aside, study, and protect a large portion of the land and wetlands.  To do so, the team is highly interested in strategic partnerships with local companies, nonprofits, and educational institutions.

Strategic Partnerships:   We are looking to partner with companies or nonprofits that specifically have a concern or issue with increased consumption rates, the continuing generation of plastics, and how they are disposed of or recycled.  This partnership will work closely with our executive team to build a strategy and on-going relationships that will be beneficial to both parties.

Educational Partnerships:  We are also looking to partner with local and regional businesses, universities, community organizations, nonprofits, and K-12 schools with the overall goal to promote educational access and opportunities.  We hope to create partnerships that allow students to build on their education around Environmental Studies and Engineering Studies, in addition to creating fellowships, internships, and research opportunities either associated with the facility or the surrounding ecosystem.  To accommodate this, our plans will include establishing an R&D facility that can accommodate interns, scholarship students, and local graduates working in a relevant environmental or engineering degree.

 

Our Budget

While this technology has not been used commercially before, it has been used privately.  The PACRRS team has completed a site visit and the due diligence in order to estimate that an excess of 5 million dollars will be needed.  To get started, however, we will need $500,000.

Money raised with this campaign will help us start the process of acquiring property and start the process of building warehouses to store collected plastic materials before they are processed through industrial shredders to become fuel, addition to recruiting help.

Budget Needs: 

  • Site Preparation (Cleanup, Structural & Environmental Assessments) -  200k
  • Structure to House Collected Plastics - 100k
  • Industrial Shredders - 60-100k
  • Conveyor Implementation - 60-100k

 

Risks & Challenges

The Risks:

There are a lot of areas we need to keep an eye on and be very aware of.  Being part of a new energy offering, there are many hurdles one can face when building in a new area that needs a lot of attention prior to the build.  We want to be diligent in our procedures, and keep a detailed account and checklist of all things that can affect the day-to-day operations.   We will be working closely with environmental and engineering companies to make sure we can offset as many potential risks as possible.

The Challenges:

When building something as big as this in terms of sheer production of renewable resources, we have be aware of the hidden dangers that can rise.  Our focus is to be as transparent as possible, and to do everything accordingly.  Our potential challenges include possible rejection from the community of what we are planning, zoning problems within the city, and environmental hurdles as we start building.  However, the great thing about our campaign is that the Lebanon community and Mayor Paul Aziz have been behind our mission and vision from the beginning.  The ease of doing business and working with the City of Lebanon has been more than welcoming on many levels.  This helps us in our efforts to know we have help when we need it, and that it eases the challenges we may face.

 

How You Can Help

To reach our goal of building a new facility in Lebanon, we need your help. 

The following are tiers of donation amounts and what the PACRRS team hopes to give back to show our appreciation:

You Choose:  We obviously would appreciate any amount of donation that you feel comfortable giving.  Simply choose "Back It" on the main Indiegogo page, and enter your exact amount. We thank you for generosity!

Plastic B Gone!:  This donation is just the start of eliminating plastics, and turning them into energy.  We appreciate your help in supporting our cause, and we will make sure you are known for your generosity!  Your name will be listed on our Facebook Page.

Bronze:  This donation is to sponsor the amount of ¼ of a ton of plastic to be processed and turned into energy.  The person(s) or organization will be mentioned on our website for this donation level.

Silver:  This donation is to sponsor the amount of ½  of a ton of plastic to be processed and turned into energy.  The person(s) or organization will be mentioned on our website, and social media sites for this donation level.

Gold:  This donation is to sponsor the amount of ¾  of a ton of plastic to be processed and turned into energy.  The person(s) or organization will be mentioned on our website and social media sites for this donation level.  Additionally, you will receive recognition in our marketing and sales materials, along with accolades, and a Special Invitation to the facility's Grand Opening.

Platinum:  This donation is to sponsor the amount of 1 ton of plastic to be processed and turned into energy.  The person(s) or organization will be mentioned on our website and social media sites as well as recognition in our marketing and sales materials, along with accolades.  The person(s) or organization will have be named on an “Esteemed Sponsor” plaque, which will be prominently placed within the completed facility's lobby area.  A Special Invitation to a Premiere Opening of the facilities in addition to the Grand Opening will also be given for this donation level.

Partner:  This level is for a company or business who is looking to donate in a BIG way.  The terms of the donation will be discussed with our Executive Team, and will be held confidential until an agreement to disclose or not disclose their name is confirmed.  Upon such agreement of partnership terms, both parties will work to promote and enhance social awareness and brand recognition.  Upon agreement, Platinum perks will be given for this donation level.

Click on images below to see better examples:

Wall of Recognition:  Platinum Sponsors and Partners will have their plaques prominently placed within the completed facility, and they will be displayed with a tasteful design. 

The Team

Larry Shuttlesworth, CEO

Larry attended Oregon State University for Industrial Engineering, West Texas State for Criminal Justice, and Chemeketa Community College for Human Resource Management.  He was the National Director for the Institute of Environmental Science & Technology (IEST) and has over 15 years of experience with Hewlett Packard where he was promoted to Manufacturing Engineer with the Factory Design Team to control contamination, noise, vibration, and electrostatic discharge (ESD).  Additionally, Larry has 15 years of law enforcement and military experience.

Steve Henderson, CMO

Steve attended Oregon State University and is a Linn-Benton Community College (LBCC) alumni.  He worked with Hewlett Packard for more than 12 years, first as a Logistics Manager for many of those years, before turning his career to I.T. and sales.  Steve oversees all marketing and sales at PACRRS, and is responsible for providing the direction needed for PACRRS to become a leader in the waste recovery and renewable energy industry moving forward.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are not currently in a position to help financially with our campaign, there are plenty of other ways you can help:

  • Share this campaign with friends, neighbors, family, and coworkers
  • Share this campaign on your social media networks
  • Visit our website for more information: www.pacrrs.com
  • Like, connect, and subscribe to us on Facebook, LinkedIn, and Youtube
    •  https://www.facebook.com/PACRRS/
    •  https://www.linkedin.com/company/pacrrs
    •  https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC8MiIZigbtWjgL...
  • Do your research about plastics: There is so much content out there that shows how plastics are contaminating and affecting our world.  We have picked a few videos to show you just how devastating the amount of plastics are reeking havoc in all parts of our planet. 
    • Why your recyclables might have no place to go: www.youtube.com/watch?v=UAwCK--pmZ0
    • China's Waste Ban Is Causing A Trash Crisis In The U.S. (HBO): www.youtube.com/watch?v=NK20t11He14
    • How This U.S. City Ended Up in a Dire Recycling Crisis | Reports | NowThis www.youtube.com/watch?v=SnB6iRDoJ90
    • Dirty Business - What really happens to your recycling: www.youtube.com/watch?v=oRQLilXLAIU

story:
Jungle Move and Moving the Planet = we are the two entities behind this project of crowdfunding. Both located in the Canary Islands, we share a common dream and a clear philosophy: we want to change the world through a #mover attitude or, at least, leave our #mover footprint for the generations who are to come through our three main values: sustainability, solidarity and sports - the three pillars of the #mover spirit.

Do you want to know more about us? Check our website and follow us on social networks.

 

 

https://movingtheplanet.com/

http://www.junglemove.com/

 

 

As an Association, we have a beautiful project in our hands and we need your help! We are organizing our first volunteering trip to Thailand to go and see, with our own eyes, how one of the most active Sanctuaries of elephants in Thailand helps them live in a more decent way and takes care of them. By working as volunteers in the Kindred Spirits Sanctuary, the one chosen for this campaign, we want to put our #mover spirit into practise! But we don’t want to simply go there and that’s it… We want to show the world what is happening and our experience, recording a documentary so everyone can see the great task of the team and the volunteers working in places like this Sanctuary and how they are able to organize everything with such a low budget.

The estimated cost of this crowdfunding campaign includes budgets for recording and the cost of five volunteers who will be able to win a place in our mission. Three of the five places will be randomly offered, through a raffle, to all the people who donate more than 5€ to the campaign. The other two places will be offered on social networks, so be sure to follow us on Facebook and Instagram!  

You can help us make our dream possible and be a #mover as well! Starting at just 1€, the price of a simple coffee, you can make the difference and join this growing community. 

 

Moving the Planet - Creating #movers all around the world

 

 

Our campaign is focused on helping elephants, but we cannot forget the philosophy that is behind everything we do. Our main goal is to help start a change in the world and turn it into a cleaner, healthier and more solidary Earth, thanks to our positive actions. As #movers, we fight for equal rights, solidarity, sustainability and respect for nature and all the resources found on this Earth, alive or not, always inspired by a deep and active connection with our body through physical activity and positivity. And that is the impact we want to generate: raise awareness of the importance of taking care of nature and the environment, of treating people fairly and not misusing the resources we can find in this world. 

 

 

Can't donate? You can simply help by sharing the campaign!

We know not everyone is able to donate... But we're sure you can share the campaign and participate in our contests online! So, be sure to share our campaign and spread the word!

 

 

 

 

Resumen 

Tres de cada cuatro elefantes que son destinados al turismo en Asia sufren maltratos,

muchos otros son cazados por sus colmillos o confinados en jaulas para el disfrute de las

personas … Somos muchos los que protestamos, pero ya con eso no es suficiente.

Moving the Planet y Jungle Move quieren dar un paso al frente para dar a conocer este

problema y encontrar una solución, para eso nace este proyecto.

 

Un proyecto con la vocación de reflejar un problema y crear una conciencia que permita

terminar con una situación que se ha prolongado demasiado en el tiempo. Y como todos

los grandes cambios, no podemos hacerlo solos, necesitamos tu ayuda para poder

hacerlo posible.

 

Esperamos ser el primer paso de una largo camino que nos permita evolucionar a un

mundo más justo y de respeto por los animales y la naturaleza, pero queremos y

necesitamos que recorras ese camino con nosotros.

 

¿Quieres saber más sobre nosotros? ¡Mira nuestra página web y síguenos en redes

sociales!

https://movingtheplanet.com/

http://www.junglemove.com/

 

Lo que necesitamos & Lo que los participantes reciben

 

Queremos mostrar una realidad que tiene que cambiar y también mostrar una de las

soluciones que se están llevando a cabo mientras realizamos una acción de

voluntariado que muestre alguna de las formas en las que se puede colaborar con una

causa tan bonita como necesaria.

 

En Tailandia se encuentra el Kindred Spirits Sanctuary, uno de los santuarios de

elefantes más activos en Tailandia, que hacen posible que estos animales vivan

de una forma digna y libre.

 

Queremos mostrar al mundo nuestra experiencia y que puedan ver lo que está

pasando, grabando un documental para puedan ver como el equipo de Kindred

Spirits Sanctuary ha podido organizar toda esta labor con muy pocos recursos.

Viendo a que problemas se enfrentan y como ha surgido una iniciativa como esta

en uno de los lugares focos del problema.

 

El coste de esta campaña incluye presupuestos para grabación el

desplazamiento de cinco voluntarios que tendrán la oportunidad de ganar una

plaza en nuestro viaje. Tres de las cinco plazas serán atribuidas aleatoriamente

a través de un sorteo entre todas las personas que donen más de 5€ para la

campaña. Las otras dos plazas serán atribuidas en las redes sociales, así que

asegúrate de seguirnos en redes y estar al corriente de todas las novedades.

 

La idea es poder llevar con nosotros a gente involucrada que quiera participar

activamente en el cambio de las cosas y pueda ver la situación en primera

persona, teniendo más testimonios que ayuden a esa creación de conciencia

colectiva sobre el problema

 

Impacto de la campaña

 

Nuestro objetivo principal es hacer del mundo un lugar mejor, pero entendemos que un

objetivo tan ambicioso como este solo se puede conseguir a través de pequeños, pero

significativos, pasos. Y queremos que este sea uno de los primeros, por que entendemos

que la relación del ser humano con su entorno y en este caso con los animales es del

todo injusta.

 

Como organización luchamos por la igualdad de derechos, la solidaridad y la

sostenibilidad y esta es la actitud que queremos expandir. La de vivir en armonía con

nuestro entorno y respetar los recursos y especies que nos rodean.

 

Si lo resumimos de la manera más sencilla diríamos que lo que buscamos es que las

generaciones futuras puedan encontrarse un mundo mucho mejor del que heredamos

nosotros y del que estamos camino de dejar cuando ya no estemos.

 

Para finalizar queremos darte las gracias ya solo por llegar hasta aquí y dedicar tu tiempo

en informarte sobre nuestros propósitos. Porque el hecho de llegar hasta aquí implica

una preocupación que muchos no tienen.

 

Gracias a los que puedan colaborar, gracias por la ilusión de que las cosas pueden ser

diferentes, gracias por formar parte de una iniciativa simple ero ambiciosa. Gracias por

ser una prueba de que queda gente que quiere cambiar las cosas y gracias por dar este

primer paso con nosotros, disfrutemos del camino.

 

¿No puedes donar? ¡Nos ayudas con simplemente darle a compartir!

Do you want to know more about us? Check our website and follow us on social networks.
 

 
https://movingtheplanet.com/
http://www.junglemove.com/
 

 
As an Association, we have a beautiful project in our hands and we need your help! We are organizing our first volunteering trip to Thailand to go and see, with our own eyes, how one of the most active Sanctuaries of elephants in Thailand helps them live in a more decent way and takes care of them. By working as volunteers in the Kindred Spirits Sanctuary, the one chosen for this campaign, we want to put our #mover spirit into practise! But we don’t want to simply go there and that’s it… We want to show the world what is happening and our experience, recording a documentary so everyone can see the great task of the team and the volunteers working in places like this Sanctuary and how they are able to organize everything with such a low budget.

The estimated cost of this crowdfunding campaign includes budgets for recording and the cost of five volunteers who will be able to win a place in our mission. Three of the five places will be randomly offered, through a raffle, to all the people who donate more than 5€ to the campaign. The other two places will be offered on social networks, so be sure to follow us on Facebook and Instagram!  
You can help us make our dream possible and be a #mover as well! Starting at just 1€, the price of a simple coffee, you can make the difference and join this growing community.  Moving the Planet - Creating #movers all around the world
 


 
Our campaign is focused on helping elephants, but we cannot forget the philosophy that is behind everything we do. Our main goal is to help start a change in the world and turn it into a cleaner, healthier and more solidary Earth, thanks to our positive actions. As #movers, we fight for equal rights, solidarity, sustainability and respect for nature and all the resources found on this Earth, alive or not, always inspired by a deep and active connection with our body through physical activity and positivity. And that is the impact we want to generate: raise awareness of the importance of taking care of nature and the environment, of treating people fairly and not misusing the resources we can find in this world. 
 






 

Can't donate? You can simply help by sharing the campaign!
We know not everyone is able to donate... But we're sure you can share the campaign and participate in our contests online! So, be sure to share our campaign and spread the word!
 

 


 
 
Resumen 
Tres de cada cuatro elefantes que son destinados al turismo en Asia sufren maltratos,
muchos otros son cazados por sus colmillos o confinados en jaulas para el disfrute de las
personas … Somos muchos los que protestamos, pero ya con eso no es suficiente.
Moving the Planet y Jungle Move quieren dar un paso al frente para dar a conocer este
problema y encontrar una solución, para eso nace este proyecto.
 
Un proyecto con la vocación de reflejar un problema y crear una conciencia que permita
terminar con una situación que se ha prolongado demasiado en el tiempo. Y como todos
los grandes cambios, no podemos hacerlo solos, necesitamos tu ayuda para poder
hacerlo posible.
 
Esperamos ser el primer paso de una largo camino que nos permita evolucionar a un
mundo más justo y de respeto por los animales y la naturaleza, pero queremos y
necesitamos que recorras ese camino con nosotros.
 
¿Quieres saber más sobre nosotros? ¡Mira nuestra página web y síguenos en redes
sociales!
https://movingtheplanet.com/
http://www.junglemove.com/
 


Lo que necesitamos & Lo que los participantes reciben
 
Queremos mostrar una realidad que tiene que cambiar y también mostrar una de las
soluciones que se están llevando a cabo mientras realizamos una acción de
voluntariado que muestre alguna de las formas en las que se puede colaborar con una
causa tan bonita como necesaria.
 
En Tailandia se encuentra el Kindred Spirits Sanctuary, uno de los santuarios de
elefantes más activos en Tailandia, que hacen posible que estos animales vivan
de una forma digna y libre.
 
Queremos mostrar al mundo nuestra experiencia y que puedan ver lo que está
pasando, grabando un documental para puedan ver como el equipo de Kindred
Spirits Sanctuary ha podido organizar toda esta labor con muy pocos recursos.
Viendo a que problemas se enfrentan y como ha surgido una iniciativa como esta
en uno de los lugares focos del problema.
 
El coste de esta campaña incluye presupuestos para grabación el
desplazamiento de cinco voluntarios que tendrán la oportunidad de ganar una
plaza en nuestro viaje. Tres de las cinco plazas serán atribuidas aleatoriamente
a través de un sorteo entre todas las personas que donen más de 5€ para la
campaña. Las otras dos plazas serán atribuidas en las redes sociales, así que
asegúrate de seguirnos en redes y estar al corriente de todas las novedades.
 
La idea es poder llevar con nosotros a gente involucrada que quiera participar
activamente en el cambio de las cosas y pueda ver la situación en primera
persona, teniendo más testimonios que ayuden a esa creación de conciencia
colectiva sobre el problema
 


Impacto de la campaña
 
Nuestro objetivo principal es hacer del mundo un lugar mejor, pero entendemos que un
objetivo tan ambicioso como este solo se puede conseguir a través de pequeños, pero
significativos, pasos. Y queremos que este sea uno de los primeros, por que entendemos
que la relación del ser humano con su entorno y en este caso con los animales es del
todo injusta.
 
Como organización luchamos por la igualdad de derechos, la solidaridad y la
sostenibilidad y esta es la actitud que queremos expandir. La de vivir en armonía con
nuestro entorno y respetar los recursos y especies que nos rodean.
 
Si lo resumimos de la manera más sencilla diríamos que lo que buscamos es que las
generaciones futuras puedan encontrarse un mundo mucho mejor del que heredamos
nosotros y del que estamos camino de dejar cuando ya no estemos.
 
Para finalizar queremos darte las gracias ya solo por llegar hasta aquí y dedicar tu tiempo
en informarte sobre nuestros propósitos. Porque el hecho de llegar hasta aquí implica
una preocupación que muchos no tienen.
 
Gracias a los que puedan colaborar, gracias por la ilusión de que las cosas pueden ser
diferentes, gracias por formar parte de una iniciativa simple ero ambiciosa. Gracias por
ser una prueba de que queda gente que quiere cambiar las cosas y gracias por dar este
primer paso con nosotros, disfrutemos del camino.
 

¿No puedes donar? ¡Nos ayudas con simplemente darle a compartir!

story:
The Jewish Shepherd's Tent

Avraham Herzlich came to Israel many years ago, as a young man in search of his Jewish identity. After a long boat ride from America, he took off his shoes and walked the width and length of the Holy Land, barefoot. On his trek, he discovered Torah Judaism in the Yemenite community's traditions. He found his calling in herding small cattle, like the fathers of the nation of Israel - Avraham, Itzhak and Yaakov. He realized that a shepherd in the field, whose livelihood is truly reliant on the rains and seasons, can develop a sense of direct connection between himself - a simple Jew - and G-d and His blessings.

Avraham has been shepherding his flock of goats and sheep in the hills of Israel for over 40 years now - first in the Galil, and later in Shomron. He and his wife Aviva brought up their eleven children to value being close to the land and nature, and learning the ways of HaShem. Thirteen years ago, major tragedy struck Avraham's family when his daughter Talya and her husband Binyamin were killed in a roadside ambush by terrorists. Their six children were left orphans, to be raised by their extended family. And as if that were not enough, four years ago, his entire herd of 400 goats was stolen and transported into the Palestinian Authority, and lost forever.

With the small herd he has succeeded in gathering since, Avraham spends many hours every day out in the grazing lands near the town of Kfar Tapuach in Shomron. He walks many kilometers each day, moving his flock to fresh pastures, assisted by his faithful shepherd dogs and his grandchildren, who learn Torah and read Psalms with him, while enjoying the wonders of nature and the beautiful scenery of the hills of Samaria.

In short, Avraham has a unique life, and a story to tell.

The idea:

Avraham is not as young as he once was; his work is not getting any easier, and he has been through a lot. His daughter and son-in-law, Mollie and David Ha'ivri, came up with an idea that would help Avraham transform his life’s work into something that could be shared with people who wish to learn more about his ideals.

They have built a visitor's tent in the middle of his grazing land at Kfar Tapuach, and launched a Facebook page for the Jewish Shepherd. They have begun coordinating tour group visits with Avraham the Shepherd. The first season of this program was a big success. Tour groups included farmers from America, motorcycle clubs from Israel, new immigrants from the former Soviet Union, Chabad Hasidim from New York, and journalists from both BBC and Arabic-language Alhura TV.

In some very unusual weather this past winter, Israel experienced two heavy blizzards. The first one was preceded by very strong winds, which caused major damage to the Shepherd's visitors’ tent. Now that the winter is behind us, we need to rebuild and expand the site to facilitate the expected flow of visitors this coming spring, summer and fall.

We need your help to make this happen. We plan to rebuild and expand the visitors’ tent, build restrooms for guests, build a cooking area and a pita bread oven, clear an area for car and bus parking, set up a shooting range for bow and arrow archery activities, build a holding pen for the goats, near the tent, and fence in grazing lands nearby.

The overall budget to do all of these things is about $75,000. But as we are known for doing the best we can with what we can get, we are looking to raise at least $5000, to start. Feel free to contact us directly, if you are interested in sponsoring major parts of this project. Donations can be recognized for your taxes. (Just ask, if you need documentation for that.)

Please take advantage of our perks program for this crowdfunding campaign. We ask for your help now, not only through your own donation, but that you also share with your friends and urge them to support this project as well.

Thank you for your help, and thank you for your friendship.

Please do come to visit.

The Jewish Shepherd's Tent Team

story:
A Chance to Make History! 





  • Donate to the campaign - every person who donates in any way will get their name on the giant poster we will display at the festival.
  • Share this campaign!
  • Like Texas Wild Rice Festival on Facebook & Subscribe to the TWRF mailing list.
  • Sign up to be a festival volunteer
  • Bring Your Family, Business, or Group to our Festival
    - Non-Profit or Educational Booth Form
    - Vendor Form
  • Do you have experience?  Contact us about the possibility of joining the festival team at: texaswildricefestival@gmail.com 



The Festival was born out of a River’s  dream. After working in Environmental Education at the San Marcos Springs with the Meadows Center for several years, organizer Ashley Wright became inspired to share the majesty of the Springs and the unique ecosystem with a greater audience. Once she pitched the idea to her dearest friend and co-worker, Samantha Beasley, the duo became determined to reach out to the entire community about the importance of the River. Unsure of exactly how to begin such a grand endeavor, the two Texas State Alumni partnered up with their long time friend, an experienced and enthusiastic festival organizer, Thomas Waymouth, who brought all of his creative knowledge to their dynamic. With all of their powers combined, they reached out to the City of San Marcos and were invited to create River Awareness Day, the pilot event for the Texas Wild Rice Festival.

In 2013 we put together River Awareness Day; which was named "Best New Flow Festival" by the Austin Chronicle.  It was held on August 3rd 2013 and it was made possible by the sponsorship of the San Marcos River Foundation, the Habitat Conservation Plan, and Community Impact Newspaper as well as the donation of the use of City Park by the city of San Marcos.  The three organizers put in over 2000 hours to make it happen with no remuneration other than satisfaction that comes from bringing community together over water. We received an education grant from the HCP for $5000 and with the help of local businesses, nonprofits and community volunteers we were able to create a festival that was educational, interactive, and loads of fun!

This year the educational grant is no longer available so it is up to us as a community to co-create this event.  Normally this kind of opportunity to support the creation of a festival is only offered to businesses, but we wanted to offer it to all the individuals of our community as well.  This way each person has a voice.  We can show Indiegogo, our city, and the world how much the people of our community care about how we develop, what our priorities are, and how we can choose to craft and guide our identity together. 


Thank you Friends,

Keep San Marcos Flowing! 


Special thanks to the Yakona team for their underwater footage and photography!

story:
Growing the commons, growing community:

Help Yourself!, Inc. is a non-profit in Northampton, Mass. that works to fund-raise, design, plant and maintain fruit trees and forest gardens in public places in the Pioneer Valley, free for all to harvest from. Educational and inviting signs, murals, and plant walks engage the community and nurture a growing, inter-generational culture of land connection and stewardship.

  • If fully funded, this campaign will allow us to plant more than 2,000 additional fruit and nut trees, shrubs and vines in public places in Franklin, Hampshire and Hampden counties at more than 30 planting projects including:
  • Fruit trees & more at 20 public K-12 schools in Holyoke, Northampton, Hampshire and Franklin counties, in addition to expanded plantings at the 13 schools already partnering with Help Yourself.
  • The Hampshire Council of Governments Courthouse Lawn, and the Forbes Library, downtown Northampton, high-profile opportunities for public edible landscaping.
  • Expanded plantings along the Norwottuck and Manhan Rail Trails in Northampton, Florence, Hadley and Easthampton: +100 grape vines and many more fruit trees and shrubs along the bike path, along the path, in nearby clearings, and in 'edible exits' along its length, opening to the back yards of adjacent homes, business and institutions offering planting space.
  • A number of community gardens and nearby sidewalks in Holyoke, maintained by Nuestras Raices in Holyoke and housing projects with Northampton Housing Authority, and farms like Next Barn Over in Hadley, offering PYO public forest garden space.
  • Native medicinals and shrubs to the Brookie Sculpture Park on Deerfield St. and fruit trees at the Franklin County Jail in Greenfield.
  • and more! Check out our projects page for more info.

We are entirely donation funded. Every little bit helps us make this world a little greener. Can you help share this fundraiser with friends, family, social media, etc?

Where the Funding Goes:

  • Funding will go entirely to the following: 6000$ to plants, 300$ for materials and signage, 300$ for a youth maintenance corps stipend, & 400$ for grants offered to communities in the area beginning their own planting projects. If we don't reach our goal, we'll break down what we raise proportionally.
  • Each grafted or nut tree costs 20-25$. Native shrub and tree seedlings cost 1-5$ each. Herbs and perennials cost 5-10$. Grape vines cost ~10$. Laminated signs cost ~1$/ea. Plants will be sourced from nurseries in the northeast, as locally as possible.

Impact so Far:

Last year's kickstarter, plant sale and grants brought in more than 2,000 perennial plants - apples, pears, walnuts, hazlenuts, plums, and more. Since fall 2012, all of these have been planted in a variety of public locations in the Valley and Hilltowns from Barre south to Springfield, and Cummington east to Amherst. The bulk of our plantings are in Northampton and Greenfield. See our planting projects page for more info.

  • Public K-12 Schools: Beginnings of forest gardens at 13 schools in the valley.
  • Community Gardens: Florence Organic CG, Northampton CG, Gardening the Community in Springfield, Brooks Bend Farm
  • Institutions, Orgs. and Businesses: Community Action!, Just Roots, Chabad Northampton, Hampshire Council of Governments, Northampton Housing Authority, Tran's World Food Market, Congregation B'nei Israel
  • Parks & Conservation Land: Brookie Sculpture Park, Amethyst Brook conservation land, GF Energy Park
  • Bike Paths: Norwottuck Rail Trail

Get Involved:

Want to help out in other ways? Come out for a planting or site prep day, or get connected to a tree to do seasonal maintenance. We also could use help designing new gardens, doing outreach, and working at local nursery Tripple Brook Farm.

  • Visit www.helpyourselfedibles.org to join the mailing list & stay in the loop.

story:
Help us attend the single largest mobilization about climate change in history!

                               This is an invitation to change everything…

On September 21st, world leaders are coming to NYC for a UN summit on the climate crisis. UN Secretary­ General Ban Ki-­moon is urging governments to support an ambitious global agreement to dramatically reduce global warming pollution. With our future on the line and the whole world watching, we’ll take a stand to bend the course of history.

In order to make all the Gulf Coast climate fighters present in NYC, we're going to be sending vans to New York from New Orleans. Our transportation will cost about $9,000 USD, and we're trying to raise as much money as possible so that everyone from the NOLA community who wants to come with us can, no matter how much money they are able to pay. We from Divest Tulane can't wait to take part in an event that will make history as we bring environmental action to the forefront of the nation's mind. Donate to help us get there!

Check out our ticketing website if you'd like to join us! 

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/new-orleans-to-new...

FAQs

  • Are there any low-income or FREE seats? Yes! We'll be pursuing funding from Tulane University and 350.org this september. See the ticket purchase board for low-income seats. Need a free ticket? Email cfitch@tulane.edu
  • Is there a waiting list? We’re working on hiring as many vans as we can to accommodate everyone. If the tickets are sold out, email me and I’ll put you on the waiting list.
  • Do you have a non-profit # I can use to claim my donation? Yes, email me at cfitch@tulane.edu
  • Can I invite my friends? Invite everyone you know!
  • Do I need a hotel? Van rides are overnight, no hotels are needed.
  • Where will we be staying in NYC? Although nothing is set in stone yet- we are working to find places to stay for free. If you know of any people with a floor to sleep on in new york please let us know! If you don't know anybody, no worries! We're working to find places for everyone to sleep, no one willl be left behind.
  • Where can I contact the organizer with any questions? cfitch@tulane.edu

We're working to find places for everyone to sleep, no one willl be left behind.

Where can I contact the organizer with any questions? cfitch@tulane.edu

story:
Funds raised will pay 4 months’ rent and internet.

Tasmania’s forests desperately need our most active campaigners to be able to continue working together in the Forest Hub. Despite the recent hard won victory in maintaining World Heritage listing for Tasmanian forests we still face open slather logging in promised reserves and in existing formal reserves. We need rent for our campaign hub urgently!

Help us keep these precious high conservation value forests safe.

The new Tasmanian government is legislating to abandon 400,000 ha of future promised reserves and instead allocate those forests to future logging zones. In addition, existing reserves of many years’ standing, comprising another 840,000 ha are also being opened for logging, particularly affecting temperate rainforest. 

Astonishingly, they plan to win Forest Stewardship Council (FSC) certification for Forestry Tasmania to cement ‘green’ credentials in the markets, despite this anti-conservation agenda. If we can’t get a strong response organised, this scary scenario could become a reality.

Our group of high profile forest defenders have been working together in a forest hub in Tasmania’s capital city, Hobart. From this hub we’ve organised a big rally in the wilderness World Heritage forests, support from high profile global voices around the world, an online action for people to send a message to the forest industry supply chain from Tasmanian forests to market, 48 hours of international action to defend World Heritage, and activity in Doha at the World Heritage meeting to name a few from just the last couple of months. Staunch campaigners Paul Kimbell, Peg Putt of Markets for Change, Jenny Weber of Bob Brown Foundation, Miranda Gibson of Observer Tree, and Ed Hill, appeal for donations to continue this hive of activity.

Funds raised will pay 4 months’ rent and internet.

We have the passion and commitment to confront the ongoing threats and tragic destruction of Tasmania’s magnificent wild forests. We volunteer our time and energy. We need financial assistance to maintain the hub as we take on governments and well-resourced logging corporations.

Alongside the rising threat to open up World Heritage and high conservation value forests to the chainsaws sit new plans to burn our loved native forests for electricity or trash them to create biofuels. Sarawak logging cartel Ta Ann is also entrenched here, receiving government largesse.

Between us we work all aspects of this vital campaign, from deep in the threatened forests to dialogue with overseas markets and investors in their high rise offices.

CAMPAIGN TEAM

Peg is one of the elders of the environment movement in Australia, previous Parliamentary leader of the Tasmanian Greens and now an international advocate on forests and climate who works the markets. She is listed on the Tasmanian Honour Roll of Women for services to the environment.

Jenny is a full time forest activist who earned the inaugural Bob Brown Foundation award for Environmentalist of the Year in 2012 for her strong stand and unwavering dedication in the face of extreme local hostility. Currently working with the Bob Brown Foundation as their Campaign Manager. She advocates from the grass roots with a regional environment centre in Tasmania through to markets and solidarity with Sarawak.

Paul is a design and film making wizard who takes messages from the forests to the globe. His design work, for The Last Stand’s markets action - a Harvey Norman QR Code Action - was a finalist in the Memefest International Awards for Socially Responsive Communication and Art.

Miranda entranced the world from the Observer Tree with her record-breaking 457 day tree sit that stalled logging of world heritage value forests and also earned her a Bob Brown Foundation award as Environmental Courage Award in 2012. 

Ed is a volunteer forest campaigner based in Hobart, Tasmania. He has worked extensively on grassroots campaigns to protect native forests from far East Gippsland in Victoria to Tasmania's southern forests for the last 12 years. Having contributed to several successful campaign outcomes, he will continue to advocate and agitate until native forests are given the protection they deserve.

Above: Peg Putt

Above: Jenny Weber

Above: Paul Kimbell

Above: Miranda Gibson


Above; Ed Hill

More Ways You Can Help

If you don’t have any money to support the hub, there are other ways you can help our forest campaigns.

Sign our cyber campaigns

Take action online for Tasmania's forest protection:

Send a message about saving Tasmania’s forests to the chain of forest destruction from Tasmania’s forests to the market. Click here

Visit our websites to see our campaign

www.bobbrown.org.au

www.marketsforchange.org

www.observertree.org

story:
Summary

I am a Christian Social Entrepreneur who has been developing biblical based solutions for permanent rural poverty alleviation. I aim to authentically live out the Biblical admonition: "If a brother or sister is poorly clothed and lacking in daily food, and one of you says to them, ‘Go in peace, be warmed and filled’, without giving them the things needed for the body, what good is that?"

My social enterprise - African Honey Bee - supports 62 families in rural South Africa. We train, mentor, incubate, provide logistical and technical support and most importantly provide access to premium markets.

Our main aim is to enable these families to lift themselves out of poverty by establishing micro-beekeeping businesses. 

By contributing towards this project you will be helping us improve the lives of 62 rural families by providing them the skills and support to increase their incomes 5 fold.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $30,000 to get us through the next 6 months while we build our honey production up Already we produced 5 tons of pure, raw honey this year. Our goal is to produce 20 tons by this time next year. If we can do that, we wont need any further funding.

For every $1,000 that you contribute, we will give you a box of 24 x 375g raw honey packed in square glass jars (valued at $130) to say thank you. You will just need to arrange transport.

Even if we don't reach our goal of $30,000, your contribution will help us reach self sustainability faster.

The Impact

Globally and more specifically in Europe, Japan and the United States of America, consumers and governments are demanding high quality and healthy food. Honey is one such food product. With the spread of pollution it is becoming more and more difficult to provide these markets with adequate quantities of honey that is raw, pure and free of pollutants.

Retailers in South Africa are demanding locally produced (pure and ethically traded honey) for their private labels, but are struggling to find reliable suppliers. A recent history of government rebated cheap imported honey, created barriers of entry to honey producers, because the costs of honey production in South Africa were higher than the cost of importing it. A growing consumer awareness about the plight of the honeybee and the quality (or lack thereof) of honey in general, offers beekeepers an opportunity to compete with the imported honeys. South African consumers are also becoming more and more aware of the fact that all imported honey into SA is radurised by law, making it far less healthy than locally produced pure honey.

African rural communities often live in areas adjacent to unpolluted prime honey producing vegetation, (capable of producing organic honey) that they do not benefit from, nor realise the potential. In identifying this opportunity, African Honey Bee (AHB) has been established as a social enterprise to roll out a biblical model that provides:

  • partner beekeepers with access to fair markets, affordable technology and training; and
  • the consumer with access to fairly priced, premium quality raw honey.


Summary of the African Honey Bee Method

African Honey Bee has been exploring ways to empower potential and existing honey producers and then link them to the honey consumers, enabling all to benefit from the relationship. First a stable platform based on a “hub-and-spoke” principle is established. Profitable incubation farms are set up to produce viable volumes of honey, enabling critical mass and thereby providing partner beekeepers access to appropriate technology, infrastructure, training, quality control, logistical support and access to markets.

The incubation farms not only provide a stable platform for market off-takers that require relationships with “big farmer” type operations, but also an environment for partnering with, and incubating beekeepers.

Beekeepers that partner with AHB are provided with:

  • Training, mentoring and support;
  • Low cost infrastructure, equipment, consumables and logistics; and
  • Off-take agreements/partnerships with large retailers.

They are incentivised to be loyal to AHB because besides receiving these services and competitive prices for their products, partner beekeepers become dividend sharing beneficiaries in the AHB Stakeholder Trust.

AHB is able to guarantee its product quality to the consumer, because as a prerequisite for the partnership it has with its beekeepers, it requires the beekeepers to:

1) manage their bees according to the Afri-hiveTM system - a specific method of organic beekeeping that it has developed,

2) use AHB’s NektarTM management and traceability technology,

3) be compliant with AHB quality standards and

4) be managed and mentored by an AHB senior beekeeper.

Prospective beekeepers from rural areas with beekeeping potential, who are generally between the ages of 18 – 26, are recruited to participate in the AHB incubation programme. They spend between 4 - 18 months (depending on their prior knowledge and experience) in an incubation programme during which time they are officially employed by the incubator as salaried working interns. During their incubation, the interns complete an AHB developed, SAQA accredited NQF level 1 Learnership in beekeeping. They gain practical experience by working under guidance of senior beekeepers on an AHB commercial bee farm. During the incubation programme the interns are also assisted to either start their own beekeeping business on a small scale or expand their existing business, with the view of commercialising it once they complete the incubation process. At the end of their incubation, the beekeepers automatically become beneficiaries in the AHB Stakeholder Trust. In other words, they become shareholders in AHB Kruger Park (Pty) Ltd, the main operating entity of the group. Highly competent beekeepers also stand to be qualified as AHB senior beekeepers to supervise beekeeping activities according to AHB quality standards.


A beekeeper development Trust (that owns 10% of the equity in AHB Kruger Park (Pty) Ltd) raises grant funding to provide support to partner beekeepers in the form of mentorship, training, logistics, access to low cost equipment and consumables.

AHB’s African Honey Bee Kruger Park incubator has been operating since April 2013, and is expected to function at full capacity (2 500 hives) by July 2015. AHB plans to expand its commercial operations into the 30,000 ha of Sappi owned Eucalyptus grandis plantations that it has a tender to use.

During 2013 twelve beekeepers from Vhembe municipality in Limpopo Province joined AHB as beekeeper partners and have been supplying AHB with excellent quality honey ever since. Recently 27 Vhembe beekeepers under their representative – John Mudau - sent AHB a letter requesting formal engagement and membership as beneficiaries in the AHB Stakeholder Trust.

Early in 2014, Lima Rural Development Foundation asked AHB to consult on developing a plan to revive a number of beekeeping projects on Sappi land in KwaZulu Natal.

Although AHB believes that there is potential for replicating the model elsewhere in southern Africa and the developing world, I feel that AHB needs more time to prove concept and therefore do not wish to expand before June 2015.

Honey harvested from the incubation farms and procured from partner beekeepers, is transported to a central processing plant where it is strained, bottled, labelled, packaged and dispatched for distribution. AHB is implementing a complete traceability system under its NektarTM management and traceability technology. This will eventually allow consumers to trace their batch of honey back to the beekeeper that produced it and see on Google Earth where it comes from.

HB’s short term marketing emphasis focuses on local markets such as delis, boutique stores and independent retailers. In November 2013, the Tiger’s Eye Group signed an off-take agreement with AHB to supply their nine Kruger Park and other Lowveld stores. Ultimately, AHB intends to develop partnerships with local and international retailers, with which it can promote its honey products through telling its “good news story.” Already relationships with retailer, Coop and ingredient wholesaler Varistor, have been established in Switzerland. Locally much interest has been shown by Food Lovers Market, Dischem, Pick n Pay and Woolworths.


Risks & Challenges

One of our biggest challenges at this stage is the lack of operating capital. It is relatively simple to raise capital for assets and training, but for some reason funders are loath to provide operating capital. Lack of sufficient operating capital can create cash flow problems which can cripple a project or even cause it to fail. That is why any amount that you contribute will go a long way towards reducing this risk.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please remember that even if you cant help us with a financial contribution, you can support us by buying our honey and marketing our honey in your area. To order honey, please visit our website www.africanhoneybee.co.za

Please also remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Short Summary

Hello! I am Cynthia Melendy, an environmental advocate who has been working with environmental groups most of my life making them stronger by counting birds, increasing their membership, and helping to make their voices heard. Now it is time to get out in the front lines and become an advocate.
I'm pleased to inform you that I have been selected for the Climate Reality Leadership Corps three-day training with Chairman and Founder, former U.S. Vice President Al Gore on November 4-6 in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. (http://climatereality project.org/leadership-corps). This training will provide a huge boost to my advocacy for the environment in the immediate White Mountain Community, New England, and beyond. 

What We Need & What You Get

I need help to fund my travel expenses (airfare, accommodation, visa, insurance, etc) for this exciting venture and also for collaboration on the related 'Acts of Climate Leadership' (presentations, rallies, exhibitions, etc.) for at least a year after the training.

Here is a breakdown of how the funds will be used:

  • Round trip from North Conway, New Hampshire to Rio de Janeiro, Brazil: $2000. (includes round trip bus to Logan airport, ground transportation)
  • Accommodation, meals and transport: $200 x 5 = 1000
  • Visa, processing and travel Insurance: $500

The Impact

We in New England are already feeling the effects of climate change. These include:

  • More frequent heat waves in the Northeast expected to increasingly threaten human health through heat stress and by affecting air pollution.
  • As temperatures rise, farms and fisheries will likely face increasing problems with productivity, potentially damaging livelihoods and the regional economy.
  • More frequent heavy rains and sea level rise are likely to increase flooding in the Northeast
  • Precipitation and Sea Level rise, already visible by the necessity to build sea walls, and the effects of strong storms, with accompanying expensive cleanup.
  • Effects on human health, such as the introduction of new mosquito borne diseases such as West Nile Virus and Equine Encephalitis.
  • For more specific information on the effects of climate change, see this website http://www.epa.gov/climatechange/impacts-adaptation/northeast.html

The Challenge

What can we do?  Cut emissions, manage resources and live sustainably. Although you may be just one household, each one adds up. We can all learn together to change our ways. The other key action is to raise our collective voices to address the matter before we are even more severely impacted. 
Unfortunately, despite its far reaching effect, some people, local companies and large, distant heads of corporations don't find this a very attractive topic. Personally, I have worked over the years to create land trusts, preserve open land, educate children, and raise funds for environmental organizations. I drive an efficient automobile. But there is much more to be done.
It is not easy to get action off the ground to activate effective change. That is why I have joined the Climate Reality Leadership Corps to learn new ways to involve everyone in making changes. 
I need your help to participate in this dramatic action. Help me get to this training as well as involved in a global platform for action so that I can be part of the change that the New England Region needs.
As an experienced public speaker, knowledgeable expert on natural history, social and cultural history, and the community, I am eager to reach the public with the new skills and tools I will gain by becoming a Climate Reality Leader.
Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Help me get the word out: share this campaign on your social media!
  • Share with me your ideas you have for climate awareness and action. 
  • Do your own part for climate smart action: every little thing counts! 
  • Thank You!

Thank You!

story:
On The Side of the Living

Our planet is being murdered. Mountains are falling. The oceans are dying. The climate itself is bleeding out and it may be beyond repair. Industrial civilization has entered its thrashing endgame. Technology can’t fix it and shopping—no matter how green—won’t stop it. And we are out of time.

The environmental movement has severely truncated its strategic thinking by insisting on education, consumer choices, and legislative initiatives as the only options for action. None of these can address the scale of the emergency facing our planet.

To save this planet, we need a serious resistance movement that can bring down the industrial economy. Authors Derrick Jensen and Lierre Keith with filmmaker Carson Wright are producing a film that will make the case for that movement.

You can help us tell this story.

On the Side of the Living starts where the environmental movement leaves off: civilization can never be sustainable and is ultimately incompatible with life. People of courage and conscience are now stranded between moral agony and moral agency: the only certainty is that our one and only home will soon be a bare rock if we do nothing. Within that terrible urgency, the film confronts the possibility—and possible necessity­—of principled, militant resistance.

What We Need & What You Get

You can find the money to pay rent, utilities, and bills. You pay for food and other expenses every day. Maybe you even spend money on luxuries like vacations. Can you afford not to spend money to help save the planet?

$10,000 will see On the Side of the Living to completion. If you love this planet, please give what you can. Your contributions will help us with film equipment, design, and production costs, as well as transportation expenses so we can deliver aesthetically striking footage with interviews from the movement’s most charismatic leaders.

Supporters giving:

  • $5,000 or more will be credited as executive producers.
  • $3,000 or more will receive a gift box from our talented resistance artists.
  • $1,000 or more will have the opportunity to Skype with authors Lierre Keith, Derrick Jensen, and our veteran organizing team.
  • $500 or more will receive a box of home-made chocolate truffles and a postcard from the production team.
  • $200 or more will gain access to footage of full uncut interviews and bonus content.
  • $100 or more will receive limited edition, numbered, and hand-signed posters. 
  • $50 or more will get access to an exclusive behind-the-scenes photo gallery of the production process.
  • $25 or more will receive access to a special pre-release version of the film.
  • $10 or more will get a shoutout on our social media platforms.
  • $5 or more will receive our sincere thanks for supporting us.

The Impact

Time is short. One hundred species disappeared yesterday, 100 species are disappearing today, and another 100 will disappear tomorrow. Meanwhile, those in power are using their control over the culture industry to churn out story after story, book after book, film after film seducing us to forget and encouraging the masses to snuggle back into the warm illusion of civilization. On the Side of the Living combats the lies of those in power. Your support will help us spread our message to a greater audience.

Lierre Keith (www.lierrekeith.com) is a writer, small farmer, and radical feminist activist. She is the author of six books including, The Vegetarian Myth: Food, Justice, and Sustainability, which has been called “the most important ecological book of this generation.” She is also coauthor, with Derrick Jensen and Aric McBay, of Deep Green Resistance: Strategy to Save the Planet. She’s been arrested six times for acts of political resistance.

Hailed as the philosopher poet of the environmental movement, Derrick Jensen is author of twenty books, including Endgame and A Language Older Than Words. He holds a degree in creative writing from Eastern Washington University, a degree in mineral engineering physics from the Colorado School of Mines, and has taught at Eastern Washington University and Pelican Bay State Prison. He has packed university auditoriums, conferences, and bookstores across the nation, stirring them with revolutionary spirit.

Carson Wright is a graphic designer, activist, photographer and filmmaker based in the Columbia River Gorge. Since joining Deep Green Resistance in 2012, he has advocated for radical solutions to the converging environmental, social, and ecological crisis we face including his role as a panelist at the 2014 Public Interest Environmental Law Conference in Eugene, Oregon. For Carson, On The Side of The Living is an opportunity to apply more than a decade of art and visual communication expertise to a subject of profound urgency and significance.

Risks & Challenges

A film supporting a principled, militant resistant movement will probably not be overwhelmingly popular with the mainstream population. On the Side of the Living’s message will most likely prevent it from receiving material support from traditional sources of funding like corporations or government grants. But, as so many resistance movements have proven – from the efforts of the women suffragists, to the IRA, and to the Movement for the Emancipation of Niger Delta – a committed group of militant resistors can win.

Funding for On the Side of the Living will be provided by grassroots supporters like you. Support for a serious resistance movement is growing and your support for this film will speed the momentum.

How Your Money Will Be Spent

  • Additional Film and Video Equipment: $3400.00
  • Post Production Costs: $3000.00
  • Travel Expenses: $1500.00
  • Stock Footage: $1100.00
  • Professional Score: $1000.00

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute financially, we need help spreading the word. Please share links to this campaign especially with those who may have the material resources to contribute. We will also produce promotional posters and other media. Please contact us if you’d like to be involved distributing promotional materials.

The future of our loved ones, our homes, of everything depends on our ability to organize and coordinate an effective resistance movement that will dismantle civilization. Stand On the Side of the Living. Support us today.

On The Side of the LivingOur
planet is being murdered. Mountains are falling. The oceans are dying. The
climate itself is bleeding out and it may be beyond repair. Industrial
civilization has entered its thrashing endgame. Technology can’t fix it and
shopping—no matter how green—won’t stop it. And we are out of time.
The
environmental movement has severely truncated its strategic thinking by
insisting on education, consumer choices, and legislative initiatives as the
only options for action. None of these can address the scale of the emergency
facing our planet.
To

industrial economy. Authors Derrick Jensen and Lierre Keith with filmmaker
Carson Wright are producing a film that will make the case for that movement.You can help us tell this story.On the Side of the Living starts where

story:
Lake Baikal is located in East Siberia,  it is the deepest (1637 meters) and the oldest lake in the world - Its age is more than 25 million years, length of Baikal is 636 km, width is 80 km. Square of Baikal's water surface is equal to size of Belgium! Lake Baikal contains 20% of fresh surface water on the Earth. Biodiversity of its flora and fauna is unique, most of the plants and animals found there are endemic (unique species that can be found only there). Baikal natural territory (BPT) is 386.1 thousand. Sq km and is located on the territories of the three subjects of the Russian Federation: the Republic of Buryatia, the Irkutsk Region and the Zabaikal Region.

Although Baikal is located in Russia, water catchment area of ​​the lake (Lake Baikal Basin) is more than 500,000 km2 and is located on the territory of the two countries - Russia and Mongolia - including more than 300 rivers and streams. Baikal is world heritage protected by UNESCO.

Baikal Lake attracts thousands of people annually who come to see this unique place from all over the world. Tourist inflow has a positive impact on the economic development of the region, but at the same time the ecological situation is increasingly worsening. 

The reasons for the problem can be summarised as follows:

• Absence of an efficient and controllable infrastructure for garbage collection and disposal, imperfect legislation in the field of waste treatment and nature protection, impossibility to reveal those guilty in arranging the unsanctioned dumps and to impose respective sanctions on them;

• Negligent treatment of nature, low level of eco-awareness;

• No control over the behaviour of the tourists and the representatives of the hospitability industry;

• Insufficient amount of informational, educational and explanatory materials for the tourists in the designated area;

• People’s negligence of law and overriding of the rules for garbage disposal;

• Harmful activities of private business;

• Insufficient budget;

• Absence of public control;

• Lack of effective administrative supervision, lack of administration stuff.

As a result we can see this:

«Save Baikal»  was started five years ago by two people who cared. Our idea was (and still is): If you don't like what is happening around you - don't sit and cry, stand up and do something good to improve the situation with your own hands! And do it smart!

For past years we had long and hard way from volunteers that are far from ecology to high qualification professionals in sphere of nature protection. Our work is 100% civil lead, which sertantly brings as to many opportunities and threats in circumstances of Russian reality.

Today Save Baikal is one of the biggest volunteer civil project in Baikal region. 

Since 2011 year more than 40 different events have been held, around 3 000 volunteers taken part and more than 800 tons of garbage collected and removed from Baikal shores! Today our active work territory is more than 150 square km.

«Save Baikal»  is aimed at research, development and implementation of effective methods of maintaining the beauty of the shoreline of Lake Baikal, including in the field of waste management in specially protected areas. In the project "SB" included a wide range of organizational, educational and research activities.

Each work season includes block of one-day events and 30-days volunteer camp. Volunteer camp is our special pride! It is called Baikal Shore Service (BBS). During period of BSS we work at Baikal shores as public inspectors, doing clean up, territory ennoblement, education and enlightening, patrol work. We not only inhibit environmental damage but also hold efficient preventing activity. 

We work at most hard, popular territories as civil support to administration. We also work at barely reachable areas. 

Here at «Save Baikal»  we try to clean Baikal lake and reform people's minds in order to save beautiful nature. 

Unfourtantly, our project is not supported financially by government. We hope it will change some day, but for now we have to search for commercial sponsors every season as well as taking part at different local and international contests and grant programms. Each season is a challenge. We are doing great work but we do not show our maximum and do not actualize all the ideas we have.

We hope to gain additional money so we can change that! We would like to establish on-line stream right from our camps during  «Baikal shore service» on Baikal in July of 2015. We also would love to improve our web site, translate it to different languages, create nice and interesting interactive web map that would help to establish efficient monitoring of environmental conditions, publish our methodological material so other people could use our experience, create agitation and enlightment materials for hotels, administration and other interested groups, start forest protection and fish reproduction programms! And lots more!

We are also in need of money due to increasing ammount of volunteers and lack of essential supplies. We want to use funded money to give more people chance to join us and to show the world what happends inside our camps and hope to get public attention on ecological issues. 

We invite everyone to attened our camp and events. Our movement includes lots of interesting people from various countries and cultures and we always are happy to welcome new members of our growing society. It is a truely unique experience that not only lets you meet new people but also allows you to add your drop to our goal. And when it comes to environment, every drop matters.

On Baikal we are admired by locals and are supported by a variety of Russian and international companies. Sometimes they help us with automobiles or other essential resources. Here is a video made by one of our major partners "UNDP" and "GEF". Check it to understand why we love Baikal so much:

Any question about joining us can be e-mailed to the following adress: volunteer.baikal@gmail.com. Visit our web-site to explore our other projects.

Let's SAVE BAIKAL together!

story:
www.macawmovie.com

Short Summary

We would like to make a 26-minute documentary of macaw conservation research in the rainforest of Peru. The documentary will be used to direct public attention towards the problems these birds are facing in their habitat and the importance of scientific conservation research on the future of macaws in this region.

This documentary differs from other documentaries because it is filmed from the perspective of researchers that is rarely seen. We will explain the newest techniques of this field of research and show up-to-date findings in a comprehensible way in a spectacular movie.

By using our exclusive footage from the fieldwork we will include the following aspects in the documentary:

●  The storyline begins with the arrival of a researcher to the pristine Peruvian rainforest, the habitat of enigmatic large macaws.

●  During his research trip to the field he first visits a local community who today mostly earn their living from ecotourism.

●  He visits their tourist lodges to gain an understanding of the importance of ecotourism for conservation in this region.

●  Later he arrives at a research center to see the everyday life of other researchers and find out about their topics.

●  He then continues to the wildest part of the Amazon, which is only accessible to researchers today, and he carries out fieldwork in Candamo, a largely inaccessible location with high biodiversity.

●  On the way back to the town of Puerto Maldonado the storyline ends with the human impacts threatening this part of the Earth and endangering the macaws: namely gold mining using mercury, tree logging, oil extraction and road construction.

The project in detail

A scientific research project is being implemented in the Tambopata-Candamo region of the southeastern Peruvian Amazon. Thanks to the voluntary work of researchers, we already have a repository of suitable full-HD footage that would require professional editing to produce the desired documentary. Such editing, or post-production, of the footage would include all activities carried out after filming such as editing, sound mixing, recording voiceovers and creating subtitle.

To make this project we have 2 main collaborators:

●  Rainforest Expeditions is a Peruvian eco-tourism company that operates 3 award-winning lodges in our research area.

●  Filmjungle.eu Society is an NGO founded in 1996 by independent filmmakers. By now the Budapest-based Filmjungle.eu had become the most productive production unit for wildlife films and conservation documentaries in Hungary. Its award winning list of films include titles as Wolfwatching, Invisible Wildlife Photographer, Sharks in my Viewfinder and Budapest Wild.

Nowadays most scientific research are only available for a very narrow academic audience by publishing in scientific journals. Often the reality of the field-based research, which underpins these journal articles, is most interesting part and is worth to be communicated to a much broader audience by this kind of documentary. Public awareness is an important goal of any conservation research, and documentary films are great tools to accomplish this – not only by conveying our conservation message to many people around the world, but more crucially revealing truths based on scientific evidence.

You can find more detailed information about the research project at this site: http://people.anu.edu.au/george.olah

In the event that we won’t reach our desired goal, we will still make some shorter videos from the extensive full-HD footage about the macaw research in Tambopata-Candamo. It depends on the final budget what we will be able to achieve. If we over-reach our goal we could extend the duration of the documentary or create several episodes instead.

The Impact

●  Public Awareness: Aim to reach a broad international audience with our documentary with a strong scientific basis and first-hand experience from a field researcher, interviews with other researchers, locals, visitors, and indigenous people to document a wide spectrum of the study site

●  Saving Macaws: Show how we use new (even genetic) techniques for the conservation of macaws, outlining the project’s main aims and initial findings.

●  Saving Habitat: Demonstrate how macaws “function” as umbrella species as we can also be conserving other species which use the same elements of the ecosystem as the macaws do.

●  Evaluate Threats: Discuss the effect of the newly built Interoceanic highway, gold mining, logging and show what alternative and promising solutions exist like ecotourism that helps local tribes to conserve their ecosystem.

●  Land Conservation: Present the story of Candamo Valley that was saved by the public media (thanks to a documentary) from oil extraction and declared to a national park. We will add new information to the story about an isolated macaw population in Candamo prioritizing the importance of biodiversity hotspots.

●  English broadcast: The documentary will be in English and we will aim to distribute and broadcast it in the US, Canada and several European countries.

●  Spanish broadcast: We will also aim for a Spanish version of the documentary to broadcast in Central and South America.

●  Education: We intend that the documentary will be used as educational material in local schools and local communities in Peru. With this documentary we hope to demonstrate to local people and their children the importance of conserving their own natural heritage.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us to make some noise about our campaign by sending the link to your friends or posting to your social media sites (you could also use the Indiegogo share tools as well).

The incoming funds from this campaign will only be used for making the documentary about this research. If you want to contribute to the research project itself, please visit the following link.

story:
The online campaign is over. If you’d still like to donate (cash or cheques), please contact us by e-mail at founders@thermasolaris.com or directly on our website through the online contact form at http://www.thermasolaris.com/contact-us/

***

The campagne de financement collectif en ligne est maintenant terminée. Si vous désirer faire un don (en argent comptant ou par chèque), veuillez nous contacter par courriel à founders@thermasolaris.com ou simplement en utilisant le formulaire de contact en ligne disponible sur notre site web à http://www.thermasolaris.com/contact-us/
