story:
Some Background Information About Us

We are a small Ecuadorian-German company based in the region of the Amazon rain forest in Peru. Since childhood both the environment and global justice issues have been important topics to both of us which can be seen not only in our vegan diets but also in our work (both of us work in the e-mobility sector in Peru) and our engagement in NGOs (e.g. anonymous for the voiceless, save movement, B.U.N.D., Kifafa e.V.). Always wanting to help more and pursuing ideas with greater outreach we finally have the chance to contribute our part to the protection of the environment and to fight climate change while increasing social justice in a developing country and offering a healthy lifestyle that all social classes can afford. To be able to do so we need your help!

Reforestation in Combination with Permaculture

We are fortunate to own approximately 30 hectares of degraded farm land in the Amazon region of Peru. We want to use this land to create The Edible Forest through permaculture. The forest will provide all the food needed for those involved in the project and much more. From the surplus we intend to produce foods and sell these locally to begin with. The revenues will be used to keep expanding The Edible Forest and promoting this form of symbiotic agriculture.

The method we want to apply for our whole food production and distribution chain is based on the cradle to cradle concept by William McDonough and Michael Braungart which emphasizes on having a circular economy and working with materials that can either be 100% reusable or are 100% biodegradable. This includes: sustainable agriculture, food production and a self-sufficient energy system and water supply based on renewable energies.

Production of Cheap & Healthy Foods

The Edible Forest concept contains the whole cycle of food production: we grow all ingredients that can be grown in the climate of the Amazon region, create products out of them (i.e; plant-based cheese, milk and yogurt)  and sell these in Peru to establish a market of healthy foods as well as an awareness of health and dietary issues that so far unfortunately have not permeated to mainstream.

There is a big opportunity for Peru to enter the emerging and rapidly growing market of plant-based products which pulled in five billion US$ in sales in 2016. According to several food industry analysts there is an exponential growth of the plant-based sector expected in the coming years. Furthermore, a report compiled by market intelligence agency Mintel showed that products with a vegan claim increased by 257% since 2011. Peru has three different climate regions (coast, mountain region and tropical rain forest) and a large percentage of the raw materials used in plant-based meat, dairy and cheese substitutes are produced here, so their market potential is enormous.

It is very important to us that the prices of our products are as low as possible so that everybody can afford them, but of course without sacrificing the welfare of workers throughout the whole production chain. Some healthy plant-based products are already available in Peru (at least in Lima) but these are usually only accessible for middle to high class citizens due to their price. To make sure our prices will stay accessible is why we chose the method of vegan permaculture for our project and will enlist the help of volunteers who in return will be enriched by our know-how and experience a safe-space to escape the rush of the modern world. They will be able to stay at our farm for free and will be provided by with the food from our forest. In return we ask them to help us working in the fields or the production of our vegan food. Networks like wwoof.net or workandtravelperu.com will help us find these energetic volunteers.

Environment and Social Justice Issues

For us, as we both have lived in developed as well as undeveloped parts of the world, it is hard to see that people living in poorer countries have to suffer just because they were born in the "wrong" country. We want to make a change! By giving an example of how sustainable agriculture can work and that it is even possible to earn good money with it, we want to help local farmers to become independent from global markets or exploitative business agreements which too often leave the supplier or producer with just a fraction of the revenue. But to make it right, to be able to be an example, we need the infrastructure to do so. This is why we need your help. We want to build an ecological farm where the local workers and the volunteers can live and work under great conditions. As it is our aim to protect nature and the environment, we want everything to be sustainable and self-sufficient.

Further Information

The farm will be a combination of a garden and forest through permaculture with a living area in its center (see picture below). Here both workers and volunteers have a place to live and be comfortable. There is no need for high class housing, but at least everybody should have a roof above one's head and an own bed to sleep in, in a clean and safe place. The permanent workers (and their families) should of course have some kind of privacy, too. There also needs to be some common area where the people can cook and spend their free time.

This image shows a general guideline by which we want to set up a permaculture farm/garden. It has six zones of which four are used to grow food, one for housing and production of plant-based foods and the outermost zone is reserved for us to learn from nature and provide an undisturbed habitat for wildlife to return to.  

We want to build up tree houses since they offer a great chance to live in tune with nature. Furthermore we already made up a concept of ecological dry toilets which we want to install next to the tree houses. These neither pollute the soil nor the groundwater and even produce organic manure that can be used to fertilize the plants. Do not worry: dry toilets are absolutely sanitary and do not even smell.

As Pucallpa is located in the tropics it is useful to use the energy from the sun. Because of that we want to place solar panels on the roofs of the tree houses and have a backup generator (which would be used less and less as the solar panel system is enlarged) running on pure plant oil, which is carbon neutral. Water supply is not a problem either. The drinking water comes from a well and is cleaned with an activated carbon filter. For showering and laundry water there will also be tanks that collect and clean the rainwater. We do not want the people to use any shampoos or soaps or anything that may contain chemicals since we will use this water to irrigate the small gardens surrounding the tree houses and will therefore offer organic, biodegradable options for everyone to use.

Perks

In our decision-making we try to consider all three aspects of sustainability (social, ecological & economical issues). Therefore our Perks cover these three topics. Depending on how much money you donate, you will receive different small to big objects made either by local people from Pucallpa, the communities around Pucallpa or an eco-friendly company in Europe. This means that by donating money to The Edible Forest you do not only help us to create an eco-effective form of agriculture and food production but also you contribute to some small companies and local artisans reaching an international audience. Our perks vary from ecological pencils to handmade bags with imprints typical of Pucallpa.

What You Give & What You Get

Of course, what we are basically doing here is asking people for donations and their blind trust in us. We believe that crowdfunding is the best way to kick-start our project as soon as possible which is very important. Still, if we cannot manage to convince people to support us, we will give our best to create The Edible Forest on our own. This will of course take longer, but hopefully someday in the future we will get there either way. The reasons why we want to get it started as soon as possible are obvious: humans have created enormous problems for future generations through their exploitation of natural resources and of animals. We are on a path in which sticking to the business-as-usual scenario will not have a positive outcome. Climate is changing, the chasm between rich and poor is getting bigger and bigger all the time, currently about 815 million people suffer from hunger (not to mention all the animals that suffer in this world), people take refuge from their homes because of wars, climate, poverty and hunger or other conditions that cause them to abandon their families. The list goes on and on. Many of us (humans) do not realize that change is required and it needs to be right now or it might be too late. That is why it is so important for us to start with The Edible Forest immediately. If we manage to make a change, people could learn from us and a snowball effect could occur which will hopefully contribute to the world being a better place for future generations and non-human animals.

To sum it all up: To get the whole farm set-up as described above (see Further Information), we need at least 120,000$. The expenses would be as follows:

- 35,000 US$ to build four tree houses (with sanitation rooms) to host the permanent workers, volunteers and have a common area (cooking, recreation etc.).

- 50,000 US$ for salaries for our team of five workers for a period of one year. The team consists of experts in reforestation and permaculture and professionals in the area of plant-based food production. Additional experts required can help us on a consultation basis or by volunteering.

- 10,000 US$ for small machinery with low energy demands to increase the efficiency of our plant-based food production.

- 10,000 US$ for a small oil press and a backup generator that runs on pure plant oil.

- 7,000 US$ for the solar energy and solar thermal collector systems.

- 8,000 US$ for plants and materials (for example: biodegradable banana fiber bags to plant the trees and shrubs in before transferring them to the land).

The funding is mainly to get us started. After the first year our concept will be established and we will have empirical data to show its economic viability and encourage private investors to see a great opportunity in The Edible Forest.

Therefore, as you can see, every cent we manage to bring in is just going to help us achieve a greater impact. If we do not manage to get the full amount we would start step by step and gradually create The Edible Forest with our savings. All the money we get will contribute to the reforestation of the Amazon region and the creation of a regenerative method of food production.

The Outcome

The first step will be to plant the carefully selected plants and trees (for example cashew, coconut, brazil nut, cacao, etc.) that provide each other with the most effective benefit and us with the fruits we need to produce our food. As soon as the plants yield fruits, these are harvested and the foods are produced. This is a lot of work and cannot be done by us alone. We therefore want to ask as mentioned before volunteers from all over the world for their help.

So far many raw materials growing in Peru are exported and the processed or finished products imported. Depending on what developed countries prefer, the small farmers grow their crops in hopes of being able to export their goods and get as much profit as possible. This means, for example, that if one year the international demand for cacao is high, many of the small farmers will be encouraged to grow cacao. The problem with this is that they don't have large extensions of farm land or any kind of machinery to cultivate, harvest and process the cacao so they end up selling the raw beans to a big company that pays the lowest possible price to increase their own profits. Also the cacao plants take three years to start producing and during this time the market could shift and the farmers are left with a mono-culture crop that has little to no demand.

With our concept of food production the farmers could grow not only one product but a variety of different products without the use of heavy machinery or intensive labor. This makes sure that they still can sell some of these even if the market of one particular product is low. Also, since the market for plant-based products is growing we will not be able to supply all the demand of vegan products with The Edible Forest. Therefore we want to create associations with the small farmers in order to help them create these products themselves or provide us with their raw materials for a fair price depending on what they prefer.

An additional benefit of The Edible Forest is that the farmers applying this method can be self-sufficient . This gives them at least the security that they and their families still have enough food even if a worst-case scenario occurs and nobody wants to buy any of the products.

We know that it is a lot of work, but we hope that there are some people out there who think like we do and do not only care about themselves, but also about people who have not been so lucky to be born in a wealthy society and that these people out there support us by donating money. We will give our best to return everything we have to the local communities in the Amazon region of Peru.

Risks & Challenges

The plants and trees need time to grow and produce and also the infrastructure of the ecological farm is not built within a few days. Meanwhile there are many unforeseeable factors. For example due to climate change: heavy rainfalls or longer dry seasons could cause poor yields. These problems would be tremendous if we would use common agricultural practices, but luckily we do not intend to. In a permaculture garden these climate fluctuations cause less harm because we always have hundreds of different plants with different water and nutrient needs as well as higher or lower resistance to insects or fungus. This means, that there are always some species that will survive extreme weather conditions.

Furthermore, we have been working for over four years with native species in the Amazon region of Peru and for The Edible Forest we will also be working with two local experts with a combined experience of over 40 years in the areas of permaculture and reforestation.

Another problem could be that it is just not possible to create a market of vegan products in Pucallpa. This might be a heavy one, but since we are very flexible and also very confident that there is a growing market for plant-based food in Peru, we can adapt and expand our project to other cities. Of course, the production will always take place in the farm located near Pucallpa, but the finished products can be sent to Lima or other cities where people are already more aware about the benefits of a more plant-based diet.

Further Ways to Support The Edible Forest

We know that it is not always possible to donate money - even if it is just a small amount. No worries, you do also help us a lot if you tell others about our project. Maybe some of your friends or family members have some few dollars left to give to our revolutionary project. Visit our website (www.v4vegan.de), like and share our facebook page (https://www.facebook.com/Revoluci%C3%B3n-Alimen), use the Indiegogo platform to spread our ideas, but most importantly talk about our project! If you feel that together we can make a change and create a better world, share your enthusiasm with everyone you know and somehow we will achieve our crowdfunding goal and will be able to create The Edible Forest!!!
story_txt:
Some Background Information About UsWe are a small Ecuadorian-German company based in the region of the Amazon rain forest in Peru. Since childhood both the environment and global justice issues have been important topics to both of us which can be seen not only in our vegan diets but also in our work (both of us work in the e-mobility sector in Peru) and our engagement in NGOs (e.g. anonymous for the voiceless, save movement, B.U.N.D., Kifafa e.V.). Always wanting to help more and pursuing ideas with greater outreach we finally have the chance to contribute our part to the protection of the environment and to fight climate change while increasing social justice in a developing country and offering a healthy lifestyle that all social classes can afford. To be able to do so we need your help!Reforestation in Combination with PermacultureWe are fortunate to own approximately 30 hectares of degraded farm land in the Amazon region of Peru. We want to use this land to create The Edible Forest through permaculture. The forest will provide all the food needed for those involved in the project and much more. From the surplus we intend to produce foods and sell these locally to begin with. The revenues will be used to keep expanding The Edible Forest and promoting this form of symbiotic agriculture.The method we want to apply for our whole food production and distribution chain is based on the cradle to cradle concept by William McDonough and Michael Braungart which emphasizes on having a circular economy and working with materials that can either be 100% reusable or are 100% biodegradable. This includes: sustainable agriculture, food production and a self-sufficient energy system and water supply based on renewable energies.Production of Cheap & Healthy FoodsThe Edible Forest concept contains the whole cycle of food production: we grow all ingredients that can be grown in the climate of the Amazon region, create products out of them (i.e; plant-based cheese, milk and yogurt)  and sell these in Peru to establish a market of healthy foods as well as an awareness of health and dietary issues that so far unfortunately have not permeated to mainstream.There is a big opportunity for Peru to enter the emerging and rapidly growing market of plant-based products which pulled in five billion US$ in sales in 2016. According to several food industry analysts there is an exponential growth of the plant-based sector expected in the coming years. Furthermore, a report compiled by market intelligence agency Mintel showed that products with a vegan claim increased by 257% since 2011. Peru has three different climate regions (coast, mountain region and tropical rain forest) and a large percentage of the raw materials used in plant-based meat, dairy and cheese substitutes are produced here, so their market potential is enormous.It is very important to us that the prices of our products are as low as possible so that everybody can afford them, but of course without sacrificing the welfare of workers throughout the whole production chain. Some healthy plant-based products are already available in Peru (at least in Lima) but these are usually only accessible for middle to high class citizens due to their price. To make sure our prices will stay accessible is why we chose the method of vegan permaculture for our project and will enlist the help of volunteers who in return will be enriched by our know-how and experience a safe-space to escape the rush of the modern world. They will be able to stay at our farm for free and will be provided by with the food from our forest. In return we ask them to help us working in the fields or the production of our vegan food. Networks like wwoof.net or workandtravelperu.com will help us find these energetic volunteers.Environment and Social Justice IssuesFor us, as we both have lived in developed as well as undeveloped parts of the world, it is hard to see that people living in poorer countries have to suffer just because they were born in the "wrong" country. We want to make a change! By giving an example of how sustainable agriculture can work and that it is even possible to earn good money with it, we want to help local farmers to become independent from global markets or exploitative business agreements which too often leave the supplier or producer with just a fraction of the revenue. But to make it right, to be able to be an example, we need the infrastructure to do so. This is why we need your help. We want to build an ecological farm where the local workers and the volunteers can live and work under great conditions. As it is our aim to protect nature and the environment, we want everything to be sustainable and self-sufficient.Further InformationThe farm will be a combination of a garden and forest through permaculture with a living area in its center (see picture below). Here both workers and volunteers have a place to live and be comfortable. There is no need for high class housing, but at least everybody should have a roof above one's head and an own bed to sleep in, in a clean and safe place. The permanent workers (and their families) should of course have some kind of privacy, too. There also needs to be some common area where the people can cook and spend their free time.This image shows a general guideline by which we want to set up a permaculture farm/garden. It has six zones of which four are used to grow food, one for housing and production of plant-based foods and the outermost zone is reserved for us to learn from nature and provide an undisturbed habitat for wildlife to return to.  We want to build up tree houses since they offer a great chance to live in tune with nature. Furthermore we already made up a concept of ecological dry toilets which we want to install next to the tree houses. These neither pollute the soil nor the groundwater and even produce organic manure that can be used to fertilize the plants. Do not worry: dry toilets are absolutely sanitary and do not even smell.As Pucallpa is located in the tropics it is useful to use the energy from the sun. Because of that we want to place solar panels on the roofs of the tree houses and have a backup generator (which would be used less and less as the solar panel system is enlarged) running on pure plant oil, which is carbon neutral. Water supply is not a problem either. The drinking water comes from a well and is cleaned with an activated carbon filter. For showering and laundry water there will also be tanks that collect and clean the rainwater. We do not want the people to use any shampoos or soaps or anything that may contain chemicals since we will use this water to irrigate the small gardens surrounding the tree houses and will therefore offer organic, biodegradable options for everyone to use.PerksIn our decision-making we try to consider all three aspects of sustainability (social, ecological & economical issues). Therefore our Perks cover these three topics. Depending on how much money you donate, you will receive different small to big objects made either by local people from Pucallpa, the communities around Pucallpa or an eco-friendly company in Europe. This means that by donating money to The Edible Forest you do not only help us to create an eco-effective form of agriculture and food production but also you contribute to some small companies and local artisans reaching an international audience. Our perks vary from ecological pencils to handmade bags with imprints typical of Pucallpa.
What You Give & What You Get
Of course, what we are basically doing here is asking people for donations and their blind trust in us. We believe that crowdfunding is the best way to kick-start our project as soon as possible which is very important. Still, if we cannot manage to convince people to support us, we will give our best to create The Edible Forest on our own. This will of course take longer, but hopefully someday in the future we will get there either way. The reasons why we want to get it started as soon as possible are obvious: humans have created enormous problems for future generations through their exploitation of natural resources and of animals. We are on a path in which sticking to the business-as-usual scenario will not have a positive outcome. Climate is changing, the chasm between rich and poor is getting bigger and bigger all the time, currently about 815 million people suffer from hunger (not to mention all the animals that suffer in this world), people take refuge from their homes because of wars, climate, poverty and hunger or other conditions that cause them to abandon their families. The list goes on and on. Many of us (humans) do not realize that change is required and it needs to be right now or it might be too late. That is why it is so important for us to start with The Edible Forest immediately. If we manage to make a change, people could learn from us and a snowball effect could occur which will hopefully contribute to the world being a better place for future generations and non-human animals.

To sum it all up: To get the whole farm set-up as described above (see Further Information), we need at least 120,000$. The expenses would be as follows:
- 35,000 US$ to build four tree houses (with sanitation rooms) to host the permanent workers, volunteers and have a common area (cooking, recreation etc.).
- 50,000 US$ for salaries for our team of five workers for a period of one year. The team consists of experts in reforestation and permaculture and professionals in the area of plant-based food production. Additional experts required can help us on a consultation basis or by volunteering.
- 10,000 US$ for small machinery with low energy demands to increase the efficiency of our plant-based food production.
- 10,000 US$ for a small oil press and a backup generator that runs on pure plant oil.
- 7,000 US$ for the solar energy and solar thermal collector systems.
- 8,000 US$ for plants and materials (for example: biodegradable banana fiber bags to plant the trees and shrubs in before transferring them to the land).
The funding is mainly to get us started. After the first year our concept will be established and we will have empirical data to show its economic viability and encourage private investors to see a great opportunity in The Edible Forest.
Therefore, as you can see, every cent we manage to bring in is just going to help us achieve a greater impact. If we do not manage to get the full amount we would start step by step and gradually create The Edible Forest with our savings. All the money we get will contribute to the reforestation of the Amazon region and the creation of a regenerative method of food production.

The Outcome

The first step will be to plant the carefully selected plants and trees (for example cashew, coconut, brazil nut, cacao, etc.) that provide each other with the most effective benefit and us with the fruits we need to produce our food. As soon as the plants yield fruits, these are harvested and the foods are produced. This is a lot of work and cannot be done by us alone. We therefore want to ask as mentioned before volunteers from all over the world for their help.
So far many raw materials growing in Peru are exported and the processed or finished products imported. Depending on what developed countries prefer, the small farmers grow their crops in hopes of being able to export their goods and get as much profit as possible. This means, for example, that if one year the international demand for cacao is high, many of the small farmers will be encouraged to grow cacao. The problem with this is that they don't have large extensions of farm land or any kind of machinery to cultivate, harvest and process the cacao so they end up selling the raw beans to a big company that pays the lowest possible price to increase their own profits. Also the cacao plants take three years to start producing and during this time the market could shift and the farmers are left with a mono-culture crop that has little to no demand.
With our concept of food production the farmers could grow not only one product but a variety of different products without the use of heavy machinery or intensive labor. This makes sure that they still can sell some of these even if the market of one particular product is low. Also, since the market for plant-based products is growing we will not be able to supply all the demand of vegan products with The Edible Forest. Therefore we want to create associations with the small farmers in order to help them create these products themselves or provide us with their raw materials for a fair price depending on what they prefer.
An additional benefit of The Edible Forest is that the farmers applying this method can be self-sufficient . This gives them at least the security that they and their families still have enough food even if a worst-case scenario occurs and nobody wants to buy any of the products.
We know that it is a lot of work, but we hope that there are some people out there who think like we do and do not only care about themselves, but also about people who have not been so lucky to be born in a wealthy society and that these people out there support us by donating money. We will give our best to return everything we have to the local communities in the Amazon region of Peru.

Risks & Challenges
The plants and trees need time to grow and produce and also the infrastructure of the ecological farm is not built within a few days. Meanwhile there are many unforeseeable factors. For example due to climate change: heavy rainfalls or longer dry seasons could cause poor yields. These problems would be tremendous if we would use common agricultural practices, but luckily we do not intend to. In a permaculture garden these climate fluctuations cause less harm because we always have hundreds of different plants with different water and nutrient needs as well as higher or lower resistance to insects or fungus. This means, that there are always some species that will survive extreme weather conditions.
Furthermore, we have been working for over four years with native species in the Amazon region of Peru and for The Edible Forest we will also be working with two local experts with a combined experience of over 40 years in the areas of permaculture and reforestation.
Another problem could be that it is just not possible to create a market of vegan products in Pucallpa. This might be a heavy one, but since we are very flexible and also very confident that there is a growing market for plant-based food in Peru, we can adapt and expand our project to other cities. Of course, the production will always take place in the farm located near Pucallpa, but the finished products can be sent to Lima or other cities where people are already more aware about the benefits of a more plant-based diet.

Further Ways to Support The Edible Forest
We know that it is not always possible to donate money - even if it is just a small amount. No worries, you do also help us a lot if you tell others about our project. Maybe some of your friends or family members have some few dollars left to give to our revolutionary project. Visit our website (www.v4vegan.de), like and share our facebook page (https://www.facebook.com/Revoluci%C3%B3n-Alimen), use the Indiegogo platform to spread our ideas, but most importantly talk about our project! If you feel that together we can make a change and create a better world, share your enthusiasm with everyone you know and somehow we will achieve our crowdfunding goal and will be able to create The Edible Forest!!!

story:
Who

In order for utopia to become a reality we have founded Verdecuratoda...voi. A cultural association whose main aims and objectives are to spread art culture through the activation of practices related to the environment and to sustainability. But not only! Verdecuratoda also hopes to activate transdisciplinary practices and get closer to the people hence the choice of relational actions.

 

What

The title expresses the entire sense of the operation: green because it's an environmental work, curated (but also taken care of) because we assume the responsability of accomplishing something useful, by you because it is a collective work that could not be realized without you. In this project I wanted to ask the public to give me the possibility to achieve my utopia: creating the biggest plant sculpture in the world. Verdecuratoda is a social art project in which the community involved becomes an integral part of the artistic process. The final result won't be tangible, but it will be a change of habits that will positively affect the surroundings. The public will enter the process and will assume a part of the responsability, in a way that allows the work to benefit the community.

Supporting Verdecuratoda

we could grow together, create the sculpture and donate the distributors to museums, schools, hospitals and to all those public and private authorities where we find it useful to stimulate a sense of civic engagement linked to collective actions that support the environment through contemporary art. Lets support Verdecuratoda.

How

Verdecuratoda ... voi is simply a distributor of gadgets, candy, marbles, those usually found outside a bar, but in this case, the transparent spheres, instead of containing useless objects contain seeds of various species of trees. Easy, look for a Verdecuratoda...voi distributor. Once found, insert a €1 coin, collect the ball, throw the capsule in the container, open the bag and read the instructions. Choose an area that you like, plant the seeds following the instructions on the slip of paper. Go back and check your seeds every now and then. Let Verdecuratoda...voi know where you have planted your seeds and, together with the others, you will be contributing to the making of the biggest plant sculpture in the world.

Thanks to them this simple business object has been transformed into a small space, where the theme of the limit is exceeded by simply changing this limit. To the distributor were added two panes of glass mounted on an iron structure that allow the user to enter into contact with the work.
At the exact moment in which the action occurs, the transparent wall with its thickness becomes a neutral screen that tells the action. The edge of the glass becomes a screen showing an ethical action.

ITALIANO

"Verdecuratoda", un'associazione culturale i cui suoi scopi e obiettivi principali, sono diffondere la cultura dell'arte attraverso l'attivazione di pratiche legate all'ambiente e alla sostenibilità. Ma non solo, Verdecuratoda vuole attivare pratiche transdisciplinari ed avvicinarsi maggiormente alle persone, ecco perché la scelta di azioni relazionali.

Il titolo esplicita tutto il senso dell'operazione: verde perché é un'opera ambientale, curato nel senso di prendersi la responsabilità di compiere un' azione utile, da voi perché é un'opera corale che senza di voi non si potrebbe realizzare. In questo progetto ho voluto demandare al pubblico la possibilità di realizzare una mia utopia: costruire la scultura vegetale più grande del mondo. Verdecuratoda...voi è un progetto d'arte sociale in cui la comunità coinvolta diventa parte integrante del fare artistico. Il risultato finale non sarà tangibile, ma sarà un cambio delle abitudini che influisce positivamente sull'ambiente circostante. Il pubblico entra nel processo e si assume parte della responsabilità in modo che il lavoro diventi a favore della collettività.

Semplice, cerca il distributore di Verdecuratoda...voi, una volta trovato inserisci una moneta da 1€, ritiri la pallina, apri la capsula e leggi le istruzioni. Scegli una zona che ti piace, pianti i semi seguendo le istruzioni del foglietto...e poi ogni tanto vai a dare una controllata ai tuoi semini, segnala a verdecuratoda.com dove hai piantato, insieme agli altri contribuirai a realizzare la più grande scultura vegetale del mondo.

Sostenere Verdecuratoda significa contribuire a costruire la scultura vegetale più grande del mondo e aiutarci a donare i distributori a musei, scuole, ospedali e a tutti quegli enti pubblici e privati che riterranno utile stimolare il senso civico legato ad un’azione collettiva, a supporto dell’ambiente attraverso l'arte contemporanea. Sosteniamo Verdecuratoda Verdecuratoda ha bisogno anche del tuo aiuto per vivere.

story:
Short Summary

Hello! My name is Alex Aguirre and I am a Boy Scout with Troop 841, Whittier.  I've been involved in scouting for  5 years.  After 5 years, I am now close to reaching Eagle Scout rank. One of my final requirements is to complete a project that gives back to the community.  The project I selected will benefit the Whittier Public Library. I plan on updating old merit badge pamphlets, create a unique display for them, and also install cork tiles to a wall. The cork tiles on the wall will be used to decorate and promote children book programs throughout the year. 

This project is important to me as it will benefit any future scouts needing to work on merit badges and beautify the children's section of the library.

I will need to fund raise to pay for materials and supplies. I created this campaign so anyone who would like to donate towards the cause may do so at any time. Any amount would be greatly appreciated will help me complete the project and reach my goal of becoming an Eagle Scout. Thanks in advance!


What We Need 

My goal is to raise $600 for my project.  The project cost will be over $600, however I'm expecting the library to make a donation for the Merit Badge pamphlets. If the goal is not reached, I will still receive the donations made.

  • Purchase Merit Badge pamphlets
  • Purchase cork tiles for wall.
  • Purchase wood, paint and other material to make display case
  • Purchase miscellaneous supplies
  • Purchase food & drink for my volunteer helpers (other hungry scouts)

What You Get

Boy Scouts of America is a 501(c)3 organization. A donation made to Boy Scouts of America, Troop 841 may be a tax deductible donation.  Please consult with your tax adviser.

The Impact

The Whittier Library director is really excited about this project.  Enhancements to the library collection and engaging reading program decorations will benefit scouts and children using the libraries resources.


Other Ways You Can Help

I understand if you are unable to make a financial donation.  You could also help by words of encouragement or sharing my fundraising campaign with others.

Sincerely,
Alexander D. Aguirre
BSA Troop 841

story:
Haga click aquí para la versión en Español!


With Conuco Solar, we plan to build and operate a solar farm aimed at reducing CO2 emissions and the national energy deficit of the Dominican Republic. Many people don’t have the space at their home or place of business to have their own solar panels installed. Our service will ensure that anyone can still have access to clean, renewable energy by essentially renting space at our solar farm, rather than having to set up their panels at home or their place of business where space may be limited. Our service is also a cost-effective alternative to the traditional and expensive electricity generated on the island and creates even more increased saving as using solar installations generates a credit on the electrical bill of our clients. Users pay a simple monthly fee for the maintenance of their panels and the rental of the land. The strategic location of our farm will help to reduce energy loses on the national grid, improving the electric service around the island.

The Impact

The impact on the environment is clear, as the introduction of more ways to access renewable energy source will help reduce the country’s CO2 emissions, which is among the highest in the world. To put it into perspective, each Mega Watt of solar panels installed equals the benefit of planting almost 20,000 trees. Our clients, primarily small businesses, but also homeowners, stand to save over 70% on the cost of electricity. This will reduce their operational costs and ultimately give small businesses a better chance to survive, thrive and protect the jobs they’ve created in the local community. 

By installing the farm in a strategic location we will help reduce the energy losses of the Dominican Republic’s national grid. This will reduce the subsidy the government has to pay for electricity, so they can use these funds for health, education and other areas that have historically received lower financing than electricity.

If we can be successful developing this first project, we can make additional solar plants in our country and in other countries that have similar conditions so  we can multiply the benefits. It doesn't really mater where in the world the installation is, global warming has no borders, we will all equally benefit.

We need your help!

We now require funding to ensure we can acquire the necessary permits and land to install the panels and run a pilot project so that we can verify our business model.
Total funds needed to cover all of this are $260,000, but with these $15,000 we can really get things moving along with a pilot installation that we will donate to the De Corazon A Corazon (From Heart to Heart) foundation. The rest of the funds we are aiming to get from The Venture competition, but the more you can contribute the closer we will be to making this a reality.

You can help us by going to The Venture's website and giving us your vote.

The Venture is a project from Chivas where they will fund social entrepreneurs from all over the world, and we will be able to access some of these funds simply by getting votes from people like you.

We really appreciate your donations, votes and spreading the word with your friends so they can also vote and help the environment and slow down global warming!

The Team

Our team is a small and dedicated one. Our representative at The Venture Final will be Raul Aguayo, an Electrical Engineer and sailing Olympian. Our project management specialist, Francisco Garcia is a Civil Engineer, and an authority in the field of economy applied to business, while Julio Pou is a Business Graduate and our trust manager.

The Perks

bumper sticker

 Conuco Solar Shirt

Melon Seed Bracelet

 Coconut Shell Crafts 



 Solar Charger

 Sailing Lessons

Español


Con Conuco Solar, planeamos construir y operar una granja solar dirigida a reducir emisiones de CO2 y el déficit nacional energético de la Republica Dominicana.

Muchas personas no tienen el espacio en sus hogares o negocios para tener sus propios paneles solares instalados. Nuestro servicio va asegurar que cualquiera pueda tener acceso a energía renovable y limpia, esencialmente rentando un espacio en nuestra granja solar, en vez de tener que instalar sus paneles en sus hogares o negocios donde el espacio puede ser limitado. Nuestro servicio también es una alternativa costo-efectiva a la tradicional y costosa electricidad generada en la isla y crea un mayor incremento que el ahorro en la factura eléctrica ya que invertir instalaciones solares genera un crédito fiscal a nuestros clientes.

Los usuarios pagan una simple tarifa mensual por el mantenimiento de sus paneles y el arrendamiento del terreno.

La ubicación estratégica de nuestra granja ayudará a reducir las perdidas de energía en la red nacional, mejorando el sistema eléctrico alrededor de la isla.

El Impacto

El impacto en el medio ambiente es claro, ya que la introducción de nuevas maneras de accesar a fuentes de energía renovables ayudará a reducir al país sus emisiones de CO2, el cual se encuentra entre los mas altos del mundo. Para ponerlo en perspectiva, cada Mega Watt de paneles solares instalados equivale al beneficio de plantar aproximadamente 20,000 árboles.

Nuestros clientes, principalmente negocios pequeños, podrán beneficiarse de créditos fiscales ofrecidos por un plan de gobierno que incentiva la inversión en energía renovable y ello representa un ahorro del mas del 70% en el costo de la electricidad. Esto reducirá sus costos operativos y últimamente dará a los negocios pequeños mayores posibilidades para sobrevivir, prosperar y proteger los empleos que han creado en la comunidad local.

Reduciendo la pérdida de energía en la red nacional de la República Dominicana, ayudaremos a producir un mejorado y continuo servicio eléctrico. Esto reducirá los subsidios que el gobierno tiene para pagar la electricidad, de manera que puedan usar estos fondos para salud, educación y otras áreas que históricamente han recibido menos financiamiento que la electricidad.

Si podemos desarrollar este primer proyecto, podemos hacer granjas solares adicionales en nuestro país y en otros países que tienen condiciones semejantes y podremos multiplicar los beneficios. No importa donde en el mundo esté la instalación, el calentamiento global no tiene fronteras, todos nos beneficiaremos.

Necesitamos que nos ayudes!

Necesitamos recursos para adquirir el terreno y los permisos necesarios para instalar los paneles y ejecutar un proyecto piloto para comprobar este modelo de negocio para nuestro país.

El total de los fondos requeridos es de USD $260,000, pero con estos $15,000 podemos darle inicio a la instalación piloto que donaremos a la fundación  De Corazon A Corazon. El resto de los fondos esperamos conseguirlos de la competencia The Venture, pero mientras mas puedas contribuír mas cerca estaremos de hacer esto una realidad.

Puedes ayudarnos entrando a la página web de The Venture y regalándonos tu voto.

The Venture es un proyecto de Chivas donde darán recursos a emprendedores de todo el mundo, y podremos tener acceso a estos fondos simplemente recibiendo votos de personas como tu.

Agradecemos sus donaciones, sus votos y que nos ayuden a regar la voz entre sus amigos para que ellos también puedan votar y ayudar a frenar el calentamiento global!

El Equipo

Tenemos pequeño y dedicado equipo. Nuestro representante en la final de The Venture será Raul Aguayo, un ingeniero eléctrico y atleta Olímpico de vela. Nuestro especialista en gerencia de proyecto, Francisco Garcia es Ingeniero Civil, y una autoridad en el campo de economía aplicada a negocios, mientras Julio Pou es Graduado de Negocios y nuestro gerente Fiduciario.

Los Perks

bumper sticker

 Camisa del Conuco Solar

 Bracelete de Semillas Melon

 Artesania de Coco

 Cargador Solar

  

Clases de Vela
story_txt:
Haga click aquí para la versión en Español! 





With Conuco Solar, we plan to build and operate a solar farm aimed at reducing CO2 emissions and the national energy deficit of the Dominican Republic. Many people don’t have the space at their home or place of business to have their own solar panels installed. Our service will ensure that anyone can still have access to clean, renewable energy by essentially renting space at our solar farm, rather than having to set up their panels at home or their place of business where space may be limited. Our service is also a cost-effective alternative to the traditional and expensive electricity generated on the island and creates even more increased saving as using solar installations generates a credit on the electrical bill of our clients. Users pay a simple monthly fee for the maintenance of their panels and the rental of the land. The strategic location of our farm will help to reduce energy loses on the national grid, improving the electric service around the island.
   The Impact


The impact on the environment is clear, as the introduction of more ways to access renewable energy source will help reduce the country’s CO2 emissions, which is among the highest in the world. To put it into perspective, each Mega Watt of solar panels installed equals the benefit of planting almost 20,000 trees. Our clients, primarily small businesses, but also homeowners, stand to save over 70% on the cost of electricity. This will reduce their operational costs and ultimately give small businesses a better chance to survive, thrive and protect the jobs they’ve created in the local community. 

By installing the farm in a strategic location we will help reduce the energy losses of the Dominican Republic’s national grid. This will reduce the subsidy the government has to pay for electricity, so they can use these funds for health, education and other areas that have historically received lower financing than electricity.

If we can be successful developing this first project, we can make additional solar plants in our country and in other countries that have similar conditions so  we can multiply the benefits. It doesn't really mater where in the world the installation is, global warming has no borders, we will all equally benefit.


We need your help!

We now require funding to ensure we can acquire the necessary permits and land to install the panels and run a pilot project so that we can verify our business model. Total funds needed to cover all of this are $260,000, but with these $15,000 we can really get things moving along with a pilot installation that we will donate to the De Corazon A Corazon (From Heart to Heart) foundation. The rest of the funds we are aiming to get from The Venture competition, but the more you can contribute the closer we will be to making this a reality.

 You can help us by going to The Venture's website and giving us your vote.


The Venture is a project from Chivas where they will fund social entrepreneurs from all over the world, and we will be able to access some of these funds simply by getting votes from people like you.
We really appreciate your donations, votes and spreading the word with your friends so they can also vote and help the environment and slow down global warming!

Our project management specialist, Francisco Garcia is a Civil Engineer, and an authority in the field of economy applied to business, while Julio Pou is a Business Graduate and our trust manager.

story:
Short Summary

I am a father of two growing boys, 12 and 8, with passion for the outdoors and love the idea of tiny house/simple living. It is my hope to be able to purchase a small plot of land for unplugged weekend retreats to spend quality time with my family. I work hard during the week and need some time away on the weekends to recharge and connect with God's nature and my family.

This is important to me as my boys will only be young for a short time. 

By donating, you will help ensure that we can take advantage of this inexpensive plot of land. This 1/2 acre of land is less than 1,000 dollars and is close to lots of places for hiking and white water rafting. I have a popup camper ready to be set up and would love to build a small cabin on the land as well. 

What We Need & What You Get


The 1/2 acre is listed for $599. Anything raised over this will go to help getting it set up for camping and weekend retreats. 

I will open the property for others to use to enjoy the great outdoors as well. 

Risks & Challenges

Need to act quickly since this is such a low asking price, it may sell quickly. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share and spread the news. The more people that see this the better.

story:
Hello, everyone!

My name is Dan Minghella, and I'm currently a student at the University of Edinburgh. I love travel and exploration, and this year I thought I'd put my hobby to good use, by partnering with Water Aid. Inspired by the Rickshaw Run, an excellent charity project run by The Adventurists, I will be spending the summer of 2014 in the Indian and Nepali Himalayas, driving an autorickshaw (3-wheeled taxi) from Srinagar in Kashmir to Arunachal Pradesh in the very eastern extremity of the subcontinent. 
I will brave bad mountain roads, freezing temperatures and low oxygen in the upper reaches, as well as searing heat and monsoon downpours in the lowlands, in an unwieldy 3-wheeled vehicle designed for the inner city. I will cover more than 2000 miles over four months, and I will do it all without using private accommodation. 
I am doing this in an effort to raise money and awareness for the situation in India and Nepal surrounding the drastic shortage of clean water. A lack of proper drinking water and sanitation is one of the primary causes of disease, particularly in the rural areas of the region through which I will be travelling. The subcontinent is heavily dependent on monsoon, and this year's is likely to underperform, putting serious pressure on existing water supplies and crop yields. Your donations here will help me achieve this task, while a donation here sends money straight to Water Aid. Any surplus left over at the end goes directly to charity. 

What We Need

The current budget is £2000, which is broken down into several sections: 
  • An autorickshaw. 

     One of these ugly buggers. A three-wheeled, repurposed motor-tricycle currently the most common form of transport in India's cities. Currently going used for around or under £1000. Will be resold on the other end and the proceeds given to Water Aid.

  • Living costs. India and Nepal have extremely low minimum costs of living - usually less than 500INR (£5) per day. The duration of the trip is exactly 110 days, so this comes to £550. 

  • Air fares. £400 return via Air India.

  • Visa. £50 for a 6 month tourist visa.

What You Get

I'm told I need to offer some perks for those of you kind enough to donate. Be warned, it's mostly gratitude. I don't have many shiny things to put in the post.
  • £25 gets you a handwritten letter or postcard from one of my destinations. My handwriting is pretty terrible, but you will get your very own letter of appreciation and thanks for your support. 
  • £100 gets you a handwritten letter, plus a bag of genuine Kashmiri saffron, no longer exported outside of India. 
  • £200 gets you a letter, a bag of saffron, and a scarf of genuine kashmir wool. Again, most 'kashmir' wool now comes from China - you can only get it inside of India. 
  • £500 gets you the one and only map I will be using to get from A to B, plus everything above. The map will trace my entire journey as I travel from one end of the mountain range to the other, including detailed annotations for each notable destination, including the seat of the exiled Tibetan government, the birthplace of Gautama Buddha, and some of the world's highest mountains: Everest, Khangchendzonga and Annapurna. 

The Impact

The money raised, regardless of amount, will go some way to helping the hundreds of millions of Indians and Nepalis without access to clean water, as well as raise awareness for the issues that face the region. While one person can only do so much, the support of many can go a great way to ameliorating some of the difficulties which many Indians and Nepalis face in their daily lives, especially in a year when the life-giving rain of the monsoon may fall short of expectations.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please, share this page, my Water Aid page and my Twitter, @RickshawRunner, and encourage others to donate, it really helps. Thank you.

story:
Any amount will help us with our project.  No need to stick to the Perk amounts unless you want a Perk!  Thanks!

 

 Our Story

James was diagnosed with Asperger's syndrome, a form of autism,  when he was 4 years old.  There have been many challenges in his life, but  21-year-old James has grown into an amazing young man with a strong desire to help the earth.  Together with his mom and his longtime aide, he started a small door-to-door recycling pick up service that has grown quickly and is now serving over 200 households.  James collects items that are not allowed in our city's curbside recycling program, such as plastic cups, take out containers, lids, straws, plastic bags, Styrofoam, etc., and takes them to companies that can recycle them.

With the state of the recycling market being so poor, a staggering amount of our country's plastic waste is ending up in the landfill.  However, we have an edge!   After hearing James' story, a local post-industrial plastic recycling company agreed to help us out.  They don't normally take post-consumer plastic, but they taught us how to properly clean, sort and shred plastic so that it is a valuable commodity for them.  They are committed to the success and growth of James' business and are enthusiastically behind our expansion plans.

We have a high demand for our service and know that it's time to grow.  Our plan is to open a recycling drop-off site and eventually expand our pick up service to more neighborhoods around our city AND to employ adults on the autistic spectrum (and other developmental disabilities).

We have even started a "pilot" program at a local school for kids on the autistic spectrum.  Several of their high school students collect recycling from families and staff and bring it to James to learn all about recycling.  When they graduate, they will be offered jobs at James' Recycling.

                                           

 

Who we are

James Harris is the heart of the business and his love for the environment and recycling is the reason this business exists.  James is excited and enthusiastic about his job and is proud that his efforts are making a difference.

Kathi Goldman is James' mom.  Frustrated by the limited job opportunities for James, she took his favorite "hobby" and helped turn it into a business.  

Mardi Gotesman is helping this business grow and thrive.  She has been James' aide since he was 10 years old and has helped James learn to navigate life with autism and reach his potential. 

Mardi, Kathi and James

What We Need

We are currently working out of our family garage and need a bigger facility so we can grow.  We need funding to help with the cost of leasing a warehouse so that we can take our business to the next level. 

The warehouse rental rates in our area average around $2000/month.  Your contribution will help us pay for a space to launch the next chapter of our business!

 

The Impact

With the success of our business and the number of people wanting our service, we have proven that our model works.  If we can establish a drop-off center and eventually take the pick up service to other neighborhoods, the impact could be huge.  First is the environmental impact.  Post-consumer plastic waste is a big problem and we have found a solution that's working.  We have a committed group of customers who follow our recycling guidelines and want to learn about what can and can't be recycled.  In addition to collecting recycling, if we can continue to educate people about recycling, we can help create cleaner recycling streams.  The human impact is also huge.  The unemployment rate for people on the autistic spectrum is around 80% and the rate of autism in our country is 1 in 58.  There is a huge group of people who are absolutely able to contribute to the workforce but don't have the opportunities.  We want to help change that.

James hard at work

Risks & Challenges

Our business is unique and something that no one else in our area is doing, but there are some risks associated with growing our business - one being that we don't know how many customers will use our service.  However, with limited options for recycling in our community and with a population of 2.45 million in the Portland metropolitan area, odds are good that we will get more than enough business to keep us going.  Another challenge might be getting the word out about our expansion.  Along with our own marking efforts,  a local reporter has offered to do a news segment once our drop-off site is up and running, plus two local recycling companies and the Portland Metro recycling information center are eager to refer callers to us, making us feel confident that people will hear about us.  Our project has been approved by the City of Portland and we are complying with all regulations associated with our venture.

 

Other Ways to Support our Cause

You can help us by getting the word out and letting your friends, neighbors, local businesses and other contacts know about our campaign.  Visit our website for more information about what we do  https://jshrecycling.com/

Using the Indiegogo share tools is an excellent way to help.  We value your help in getting the word out any way you can!

The warehouse rental rates in our area average around $2000/month.  Your contribution will help us pay for a space to launch the next chapter of our business!
 

The Impact
With the success of our business and the number of people wanting our service, we have proven that our model works.  If we can establish a drop-off center and eventually take the pick up service to other neighborhoods, the impact could be huge.  First is the environmental impact.  Post-consumer plastic waste is a big problem and we have found a solution that's working.  We have a committed group of customers who follow our recycling guidelines and want to learn about what can and can't be recycled.  In addition to collecting recycling, if we can continue to educate people about recycling, we can help create cleaner recycling streams.  The human impact is also huge.  The unemployment rate for people on the autistic spectrum is around 80% and the rate of autism in our country is 1 in 58.  There is a huge group of people who are absolutely able to contribute to the workforce but don't have the opportunities.  We want to help change that.

James hard at work

Risks & Challenges
Our business is unique and something that no one else in our area is doing, but there are some risks associated with growing our business - one being that we don't know how many customers will use our service.  However, with limited options for recycling in our community and with a population of 2.45 million in the Portland metropolitan area, odds are good that we will get more than enough business to keep us going.  Another challenge might be getting the word out about our expansion.  Along with our own marking efforts,  a local reporter has offered to do a news segment once our drop-off site is up and running, plus two local recycling companies and the Portland Metro recycling information center are eager to refer callers to us, making us feel confident that people will hear about us.  Our project has been approved by the City of Portland and we are complying with all regulations associated with our venture.

 
Other Ways to Support our Cause
You can help us by getting the word out and letting your friends, neighbors, local businesses and other contacts know about our campaign.  Visit our website for more information about what we do  https://jshrecycling.com/
Using the Indiegogo share tools is an excellent way to help.  We value your help in getting the word out any way you can!

story:
Who We Are

Abode Farm is a collective of young farmers, organizers, and artists working together to provide accessible local food and farm-based education and experiences to our community. Our 16-acre horse-powered farm supplies fresh produce to our CSA program, farmers markets, schools, food pantries, restaurants, and distributors.

Our Project

For seven years, we have used an unfinished barn—even on many cold winter days—to wash and distribute our farm produce. It's been our dream to create a space to host year-round farm-based educational programs and to expand our vegetable growing operation. By renovating the barn into the Abode Farm Center we will create a dynamic four-season space where food, ecology, and education come together. Achieving these goals will help stabilize our farm business and deepen our community work. 

We need support to make this project become a reality! Your support for the Abode Farm Center will help create a regional resource for local food, education, and community.

We are taking out loans for 60% of this project. Because we lease this barn, this project is not eligible for most capital improvement grants. We’ve set a financial goal of $25,000 and are seeking community support to help us with the remainder.

But the renovation requires a lot of materials and costs! We need to buy concrete, lumber, insulation, excavation equipment, climate control equipment, overhead doors, lights, hardware, electrical work, windows, doors, harvest bins, and washing equipment -- and pay contractors and laborers.

With the completion of the Abode Farm Center, we will be able to:

  • Utilize a cold-storage facility that will double our capacity to produce and distribute our vegetables 
  • Expand our educational programming, offering more resources and opportunities to local youth, like our partners at Roots Rising
  • Create a community event space for workshops, farm celebrations, and performances
  • House the Summer and Winter CSA distribution in a comfortable and inviting space 

 

What We Are Offering

In exchange for your support, we have incredible rewards! We are offering beautiful postcards, T-shirts and tote bags designed by Mount Lebanon Residency artists . At higher tiers of support we are offering farm tours, sleigh rides, and personalized on-farm dinners.

The Impact

Abode Farm is a place for anyone to visit and connect with the land. Creating the Abode Farm Center will extend our mission to more people and communities and create a regional resource for local food, education, community, and livelihood.

We have been operating the Abode Farm on a shoestring budget for seven years. The farm continues to struggle to make ends meet. As young farmers, we are working towards paying ourselves a living wage with the hope of making farming a reliable livelihood for years to come.

This is a pivotal moment for the farm — renovating the barn is the first step in ensuring our long-term financial sustainability. We have run the numbers, and we know that your support can truly help stabilize our business and make our farm thrive. Creating the Abode Farm Center is our biggest project to date and will have the most impact to our farm team and community, we hope you will support our project and help turn this dream into a reality!

If you cannot contribute financially, please consider sharing this campaign with your networks. If you have thoughts, comments, or ideas please don't hesitate to contact us!

story:
Make A Real Impact on the Planet in 2018


Imagine if you could offset the carbon footprint of your electricity usage, transport and flights, how would that make you feel?

For too long, I've felt helpless watching the planet deteriorate due to man-made global warming.
Singapore suffers from haze pollution coming from Indonesia every year, a consequence of human activity and El Nino.
In 2015, these fires put more carbon into the air in 3 months than all of Europe did in a year.

That year, I went to investigate what was happening in Indonesia, distribute masks to victims of the haze and for the last two years, designed and built a working haze shelter in Indonesia. And that work needs your help to protect more people.

Also we want to do real work to tackle climate change by capturing carbon through re-forestation.

With our partners in Indonesia, we will embark on a reforestation project where we support their sustainable tree planting effort and they harvest the trees after 15 years. Each tree planted will capture about 600 kilograms of carbon in it's 15 year life span.

Our intention is to plant 100 thousand trees and offset 48 million kilograms of carbon over 15 years,

And this is just the start.  

What We Need & What You Get

Every Tree Offsets 40KG of carbon a year at $5 per tree.

  • If you drive your car daily, you may average 20 thousand kilometers a year, generating 4000 kg of carbon. That's 100 trees.
  • A return trip to Tokyo produces 400 kilograms of carbon. That's 10 Trees.
  • The average household may average 10 Kilowatt Hours a day. 4.3Kg of carbon a day. 1600kg a year. That's 40 trees. *

*Source: https://www.ema.gov.sg  - Booklet_Singapore_Energy_Statistics_2016.pdf


The Impact

We made a crazy commitment to plant a 100,000 trees in 2018. We have 3600 on the way.
Join us in offsetting your carbon foot print for building haze shelters for children who live near the forests.

story:
HAPPY ELEPHANTS IN HUAY PAKOOT!

Have you ever wondered how elephants who are publicly enjoyed in zoos, ridden in camps and cheered for in circuses came to be there? The unfortunate truth is most of these beautiful creatures have been taken from the wild, separated from their families and forced into a life of servitude by performing unnatural tricks. Elephants are subjected to an intense and often brutal training period called “Crush," which literally crushes the animal’s spirit, thereby making these tricks easier to teach.

Elephants in these artificial environments are often subjected to substandard living conditions. They develop arthritis from being ridden, and blindness from a life spent without the shade of trees. Once the shiny veneer of elephant tourism is peeled away, the harsh reality becomes increasingly clear: even the best of facilities are unable, and are often unwilling, to provide adequate living conditions for this critically endangered species.

In response to these issues the people at Global Vision International have joined forces with the villagers of Huay Pakoot in creating the concept of The Elephant Village—a program designed in 2010 with the purpose of reintroducing elephants into the surrounding forests to lead more natural lives.



ELEPHANT FOOD GARDEN

The last four years have been a tremendous success, both in reintroducing our nine elephants back into the forest, and in collecting data about their unique behaviour as Asian Elephants. We are only able to do this because of the generosity of those willing to donate to our project.

We want to expand our current operation by bringing more elephants into the forest, but because we are situated in a small rural village we are currently unable to accommodate more volunteers to achieve this goal.

How you can help:

Not only do we want to bring more elephants to our project, but we also want to start a food garden to benefit the elephants currently in our forest, and any elephants that visit our upcoming elephant hospital.

Currently we have nine wonderful elephants in the forests surrounding Huay Pakoot, but we would like to add another to our herd.

The villagers of Huay Pakoot have a piece of land, formerly used as a rice paddy field, which can be used to grow an elephant food garden full of bananas, sugar cane, and elephant grass, that they’ve been kind enough to offer for this endeavour.

If you donate to our project, not only will you be allowing us to bring another elephant back to the forest to live a more natural life, but you’ll also be supplying treats for elephant health checks, and contributing to reforestation in our local area.


Thank you on behalf of all the elephants at Huay Pakoot! They wouldn’t be here without your help.

story:
MAHALO folks!!!! Together with YOU, we exceeded our goal of $5000 and boogied down with over 70 people around Hawai'i -- and as far away as the Philly and Shanghai!! You make it all possible! We hope you'll check out our mahalo dance video here:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HPnVwJgSUfk


Let's Make Some Movement!

We are Kuaʻāina Ulu ʻAuamo (KUA), a movement-building organization supporting and connecting rural Hawaiian communities, restoring natural abundance to the islands we call home.

For our 2014 fundraiser, we're throwing an all-paeʻāina (islands) online dance party -- and you're invited! Join mahi ʻai  (farmers) and lawaiʻa (fishers) around Hawai’i moving for the movement! 

Why We're Dancing

Folks, we have some choices to make. Abundant lands & waters in Hawaiʻi will either be a nostalgic, distant memory... or something to MOVE for! 

Hawaiʻi's rural fishers & farmers -- our kuaʻāina people -- are choosing to move. Through KUA, they ally together in a grassroots movement for a better Hawaiʻi.


Together, they rebuild fishponds, restore streams, grow food, and care for fishing grounds. Altogether this represents thousands of acres of Hawaiian lands and waters in grassroots community stewardship. 

We think it’s both hopeful AND dance-worthy. It needs your support. 

Our goal is to raise at least $5,000 + get at least 100 people dancing in a show of support during our All-Islands Online Paeʻāina Dance Party.

How It Works:

From now through December 31, 2014:


Click the pink "contribute now" button + make a tax-deductible donation! 

Donate $10 or more & we'll send you a gift for a free music download of your choice from Amazon.com. We also have some other great perks available to mahalo (thank); you can keep scrolling for more info below!

Do a dance, get down, boogie! Across the pae‘āina (islands), Hawaiʻi’s grassroots kua‘āina will be dancing in their places, celebrating the movement! In your shower, in your car, in your backyard with friends + family... wea-evah YOU stay... Turn up your song + get moving!

We'd love to hear what you're dancing to! Share your favorite dance song on our comment wall, or post a video of you and your favorite people cutting a rug on Facebook, Instagram or Twitter.

  

#paeainadanceparty2014  #KUAhawaii

We're compiling everyones favorite dance tunes into an All-Paeʻāina Playlist that you can listen to HERE or on Spotify! 

Community groups across Hawaiʻi will be sharing dance videos, photos and song picks under the hashtag #paeainadanceparty2014 over the next few weeks, so join in and show us your moves in support of a MOVEMENT for land, people, culture and justice! Check it out on:

How Your Gift Makes A Difference

The problems are real and pressing:
  • Hawaiʻi is the endangered species capital of the planet. There are more endangered species per square mile on these islands than any other place in the world.
  • 85% - 90% of what we eat is barged in, despite a wealth of resources for producing our own food.
  • 86% of 55 native fish species included in a 2008 study were found to be depleted or below desirable levels.

Communities hold important solutions -- innovative, self-determined, and place-based. Yet their voices, needs and ʻike (knowledge) have historically been marginalized or even ignored. 

OUR MODEL OF IMPACT:

“One person standing alone has only one voice, and it’s not as strong as one hundred people standing together.” – Uncle Damien Kenison, Hoʻokena, Kamaʻāina United to Protect the ʻĀina (KUPA)

Your giving helps make it possible. Here are a few of our key initiatives for 2015:

  • Lawaiʻa Pono: Build impactful alliances between subsistence fishing communities, advancing Hawaiian traditions of lawai‘a--fishers caring for their fisheries & nearshore reefs.
  • Hoʻokua: Help skilled fishpond mahi i‘a (fish farmers) organize an “all-islands mobile workcrew" with capacity to tackle larger restoration projects at fishponds, and teach and share their skills with others.
  • Limu Hui: Grow a new network of limu (native seaweed) gatherers & growers who support each other in restoring and protecting limu and limu practices.

SINCE 2003, KUA HAS:

Other Perks

This work needs support, and we're grateful to you! As thanks, we've put together some other fun perks... Give more than $10 and in addition to your song download, we'll thank you with:

... some nice KUA swag:  a 3 x 5" KUA sticker for show your love, and a stylin’ KUA Trucker Hat!

... a signed 16 x 20 poster of the mākāhā (sluice gate) at Heʻeia fishpond taken by KUA photographer Kim Moa at one of our workshops in September 2014.
... a lawaiʻa (fisher), mahi iʻa (fish farmer) and photographer of Koʻolaupoko, Oʻahu, Hiʻilei Kawelo is known for her intimate depictions of Hawaiʻi's plants, animals and places, and for sharing her knowledge of their moʻolelo (stories) and hidden meanings.
... for your generous gift, Hoku Hanohano award-winning musician Ernie Cruz, Jr. will call you or the person of your choice and sing them a song! You can hear a little of Ernie on HI*Sessions.

FAQs

Q. Wait, do I need to go somewhere to attend this party? What’s the address?

A. No need to go anywhere. You don't even need to get out of your pajamas. You can dance in your car, in the shower, or with your friends and family in your backyard. This party is about people all over the islands, dancing in THEIR place, to celebrate a shared vision of natural abundance for Hawaiʻi. = )

Q.Why an online dance party?

A. We do like in-person parties too! But we know that fundraising dinners and concerts can be expensive. We’re a small organization, and lower costs mean more of your gift goes directly to support the mālama ʻāina (stewardship) work of communities. Plus, it means that people from all over the paeʻāina -- and the world -- can “come” and party with us!

Q: I bought a perk to help with the fundraiser, but can I give more?

A: Yes! For example, if you choose a $65 perk, but would like to donate $100, you can. Select whichever perk you like, and there is an option at checkout to add more to your contribution. Thank you!

Q: What if I want to donate but don't want a perk?

A: Of course! That means 100% of your donation will go directly to the hana (work)!

Q. I think I'd prefer to donate a more traditional way. Can?

A. You can always make a donation at our KUA website at donate.kuahawaii.org or by mail:

KUA
307A Kamani St, The Box Jelly
Honolulu, HI  96813
checks can be made out to: KUA

Q. Is my donation tax deductible?

A. Yes! KUA is a 501(c)3 non-profit. Donations to KUA qualify as a charitable deduction for federal income tax purposes. In general, the IRS says that you can deduct the value of your donation MINUS the fair market value of any perks you choose.

Q. I don't think I can give money this year, but I'd still like to show my support ... What can I do?

A. If you can dance, join us! Get your friends and family to join too. Send us a video of your best dance moves, and weʻll add it to our video gallery! Whether you give financially or not, your movement expresses your support! Email videos to Kim Moa at dance@kuahawaii.org.

Q. Er, I don't speak Hawaiian... What does  Kuaʻāina Ulu ʻAuamo mean?

A.  KUA means back -- like a backbone that connects and supports. KUAʻĀINA are the grassroots, rural peoples of Hawaiʻi nei. ULU means to grow. ‘AUAMO is the carrying stick held on multiple shoulders of laborers who shared the burden of carrying something of great weight forward. By taking up the ‘AUAMO, our KUAʻĀINA communities share the sacred kuleana (responsibility) to better Hawaiʻi. 

Still have questions? You can reach Dance Party Coordinator Kim Moa at dance@kuahawaii.org or call KUA at 808-672-2545.

MAHALO 

To the families and communities of E Alu Pū and Hui Mālama Loko Iʻa and the Limu Hui for your participation in this party & your everyday hard work and sweat. You make Hawaiʻi better!

To Harold K.L. Castle Foundation, Office of Hawaiian Affairs, Wallace Alexander Gerbode Foundation, Swayne Family Foundation, Hawaiʻi People's Fund, Sidney E Frank Foundation, and Toyota TogetherGreen Fellows by Audubon, for your generous support of this movement in 2014! 

To Matt Ing, Jen Barrett, Deb Gowensmith & Sandy Huang whose advice & aloha helped make this party possible. We love you guys!

Thanks for dancing with us!  To learn more visit www.KUAhawaii.org.
