story:
You can still donate to this campaign! 

--



Coggins Farm, a 169 acre tract of land 7 miles from downtown Asheville, is slated for residential and commercial development. This land has been in the same family for over 200 years. Kept largely undeveloped and bordering the forests of Warren Wilson College, it features a mix of pastures, long stretches of Bull Creek, fertile bottom lands, and mature woods that provide a home to a plethora of native medicinal plants and wildlife.

Over the past 25 years, the Coggins Farm has been an incubator for several of our area’s current crop of successful organic growers and has the potential to continue to influence the organic, sustainable food movement in Western North Carolina.

The first conservation initiative of the Coggins Conservation Project (CCP) is aimed at preserving a generous portion of Coggins Farm in an agricultural conservation easement. This initiative has been proposed as an effort to maintain a scenic natural viewshed, keep intact a valuable ecosystem, and connect the greater Asheville community with local farm production and education. The CCP has outlined their formal business plan (see below), which includes Legal Conservation, Innovative Agriculture Programming, and Small Footprint Living.

Developer, Case Enterprises, and representing Real Estate Agency, TFM Carolina, Inc. has obtained a contract to purchase the entire 169 acre property. As of April 2015, their plans are to subdivide the entire property into 99 private lots. This publicly released development is operating under the name Coggins Farm Mountain Living Community. The development plan doesn't include engagement with greater Asheville community, nor have they proposed any legal conservation elements or farming initiatives.

The CCP is also working to identify local tracts of land for conservation and collaboration in advancing sustainable agricultural opportunities. Through your support, the CCP will  raise awareness about the natural, economic, and social benefits that the public receives from land preservation and develop viable conservation proposals that will further preserve Asheville’s Farms and Rural Communities.



The Coggins Conservation Project has worked diligently to create a conservation-based plan for Coggins Farm™.  Our plan provides a clear alternative to the current developer’s subdivision proposal. It incorporates the top priorities and concerns expressed by community members and stakeholders.  It also enables this large tract of historic land to sustainably support and enrich the lives of Asheville area residents and visitors.

The core of the CCP plan is built around conservation, sustainable agriculture, and community connection.  We have committed significant resources to our project to date and we are moving ahead by meeting with potential investors and strategic partners every week.

The CCP plan is comprised of the following elements. More details of this Conservation Plan for Coggins Farm can be found here: 

http://cogginsconservation.org/new-conservation-plan-for-coggins-farm

1) 

>> PRESERVATION OF OPEN SPACE AND RURAL CHARACTER

>> PRESERVATION OF NATIVE PLANTS, WILDLIFE, AND NATURAL HABITATS 

>> PROTECTION FROM FUTURE HIGH-DENSITY OR DISRUPTIVE DEVELOPMENT IN PERPETUITY

2) 

>> HEIRLOOM SEED SAVING PROGRAM 

>> BIODYNAMIC FARMING 

>> FARMING INCUBATOR 

>> NON TIMBER WOODLANDS AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION 

>> HANDS-ON EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS 

>> RECREATIONAL, NATURE-BASED PROGRAMMING FOR YOUTH 

>> CSA PROGRAM AND FARM STAND

3)  

>> 20 - 30 RESIDENTIAL UNITS 

>> RENEWABLE ENERGY AND SOLAR HEATING SYSTEMS 

>> COMMUNITY-CENTRIC BUILDING DESIGN 

>> GREEN BUILDING STANDARDS AND INITIATIVES 

>> WALKING TRAILS

WHO ENDORSES THE ALTERNATIVE CONSERVATION PLAN FOR COGGINS FARM?
The Asheville and greater WNC community, business owners, and stewards of our environment and local food systems are speaking up in support for an alternative conservation plan for the pristine 169 acre Coggins Farm. Proudly displaying your name (and your company or organization) as a supporter for conservation on Coggins Farm versus a 99-lot subdivision makes our collective voice even louder and more effective. Our actions in support of this land will set the stage for how open space and farmland is maintained in our region as farm and land owners face retirement.
You can become an official endorser of this alternative plan. Please read the Letter of Endorsement here and simply enter your contact information to officially endorse the Alternative Conservation Plan for Coggins Farm, designed by the Coggins Conservation Project. You are welcome to customize the letter as you see fit. These letters will be sent to the Developer, David Case of Case Enterprises, the development’s representing Real Estate Agency, TFM Carolina, Inc., and other related parties.
http://cogginsconservation.org/speak-up

       


  • Read our Alternative Conservation Plan for Coggins Farm


  • 'Like' the Coggins Conservation Project on Facebook

  • Sign our Letter of Endorsement for an Alternative Conservation Plan for Coggins Farm versus a 99-lot subdivision

  • Join the Newsletter and stay connected with project updates

  • Provide connections to potential donors or Conservation Funds to further secure the 75 acres

  • Become a campaign outreach volunteer to help spread the word about the campaign efforts and preservation initiatives of the project




Who’s Behind Coggins Farm?

There are two alternative visions for Coggins Farm. Help clear up the confusion between the conservation efforts of the CCP and the private lots proposed by the developer!


Share this Flyer Online (Click Here)



We welcome your questions and comments! Whether you are an individual or a group representative, please do not hesitate to contact us concerning the proposed conservation easement.

http://cogginsconservation.org/contact

contact@cogginsconservation.org
story_txt:
You can still donate to this campaign! --
Coggins Farm, a 169 acre tract of land 7 miles from downtown Asheville, is slated for residential and commercial development. This land has been in the same family for over 200 years. Kept largely undeveloped and bordering the forests of Warren Wilson College, it features a mix of pastures, long stretches of Bull Creek, fertile bottom lands, and mature woods that provide a home to a plethora of native medicinal plants and wildlife.Over the past 25 years, the Coggins Farm has been an incubator for several of our area’s current crop of successful organic growers and has the potential to continue to influence the organic, sustainable food movement in Western North Carolina.The first conservation initiative of the Coggins Conservation Project (CCP) is aimed at preserving a generous portion of Coggins Farm in an agricultural conservation easement. This initiative has been proposed as an effort to maintain a scenic natural viewshed, keep intact a valuable ecosystem, and connect the greater Asheville community with local farm production and education. The CCP has outlined their formal business plan (see below), which includes Legal Conservation, Innovative Agriculture Programming, and Small Footprint Living.Developer, Case Enterprises, and representing Real Estate Agency, TFM Carolina, Inc. has obtained a contract to purchase the entire 169 acre property. As of April 2015, their plans are to subdivide the entire property into 99 private lots. This publicly released development is operating under the name Coggins Farm Mountain Living Community. The development plan doesn't include engagement with greater Asheville community, nor have they proposed any legal conservation elements or farming initiatives.The CCP is also working to identify local tracts of land for conservation and collaboration in advancing sustainable agricultural opportunities. Through your support, the CCP will  raise awareness about the natural, economic, and social benefits that the public receives from land preservation and develop viable conservation proposals that will further preserve Asheville’s Farms and Rural Communities.The Coggins Conservation Project has worked diligently to create a conservation-based plan for Coggins Farm™.  Our plan provides a clear alternative to the current developer’s subdivision proposal. story:
Who I am and how you can help me save lions

My name is Tutilo Mudumba and I am a lion researcher who has been working to save one of Uganda's last lion populations in Murchion Falls National Park since 2005. Wildlife snaring is one of the biggest threats to lions in Murchison and we've lost more than half of our populaton in the last ten years. My team and I presently cover an area of ~1500 km2 in which we track 90 lions, follow their movements and assist anti-poaching teams with removing lions and other wildlife caugt in snares.

The Northern Bank of the Albert Nile river is one of the hot spots for snaring in the park and we are in dire need of a small outboard motor to patrol this section of the park. We've lost four lions in this region alone this year and patrolling this river section will greatly help us reduce the number of snaring events on lions and their prey. 

What we need & How you can help

  • We need £ 1200 to purchase a small second-hand Yamaha/Honda outboard motor (20 hp or greater)
  • This motor will be attached to an existing patrol boat currently deployed along the Northern bank of the Albert Nile river
  • Your donations will be rewarded with anything from a limited edition series of lion photographs taken in the field in Murchison to a "I saved a lion today" shirt. The highest donor will also receive a framed photograph of the first 50 snares removed by my team along the Northern bank!

The Impact

With an outboard motor our team and I will be better equipped to cover this section of the park, remove snare lines laid by poachers and remove lions and their prey from snares

Lions in Africa are facing a crisis with maybe ~30 000 individuals left and this population of lions is critical to the persistence of lions in the state of Uganda 

Other Ways You Can Help

We are in a state of financial crisis and many of us are not able to help by donating, but some of our friends may be in a position to give. We would be grateful if you could spread the word along twitter, facebook and other social media sites!

 

With lion roars from the heart of Uganda's wilderness

Tutilo

story:
The GOAL

Hello, I'm Jeremy Williams with http://rivervoices.ca
I've been producing environmental and social justice documentaries for 14 years and have won a few awards in the process.I am passionate about human relationships with the land and how we can re-learn to live in balance with the earth and each other.

My goal is to create a compelling documentary film about the Tsilhqot'in (aka Chilcotin) region of "BC" (Canada), which is a major tributary of the mighty Fraser River and is connected to the coast and its salmon. This area is extremely wild, magical and in need of our protection! With your support, we will tell this story to the world, and help protect this amazing wilderness!

What We Need & What You Get

What we need financial support for;

  • In order to create a professional film that can reach a global audience, I need to give it the effort it deserves. This means travel, vehicle and equipment maintenance ; production costs, licensing music... (See our budget below)
  • Filming; our travel expenses are minimized by camping and carpooling, but each trip to the Tsilhqot'in costs $1,000.
  • PERKS! Ranging from credit in the film, DVDs, and T-shirts to a Trip to Chilko Lake Lodge, we are offering a huge spectrum of benefits to you, the funder!
  • This project is ongoing and every bit of support will be put to use as we prioritize our needs and creative goals.
  • Aside from financial support, we need you on our team to tell this story, raise awareness and spread the word!

The Impact

This project is part of a larger campaign to protect this magical wilderness and your contribution will not only help this film, but the conservation of wildlife and their habitat!

  • This project is about social justice and the environment and will impact and inspire people around the world!
  • This project is my passion and I know that it will be effective and reach a global audience.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • If you can't contribute financially, please help by spreading the word!
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools, and social networks!

Thank you!

Jeremy Williams, River Voices


https://www.facebook.com/RiverVoicesProductions


THE TRAILER


MORE INFO ON THIS FILM

http://jeremyseanwilliams.wix.com/tsilhqotin


OUR BUDGET (1 year)

Travel costs $5,000.

Aerial footage $2,500.

Music rights $2,500.

Archival images $2,000.

Purchasing footage $3,000.

Production $25,000.

Editing $25,000.

Equipment rental $5,000.

DVD duplication $2,000

Marketing and Distribution $5,000.

Total needed: $75,000

Invested already; $15,000


The RIVER VOICES series

This series of films will profile the Fraser River Basin from it's source to sea. Broken into chapters, each region will be explored extensively to reveal it's natural beauty, cultural heritage, and efforts to preserve the rivers, salmon, and species at risk. We are now in our third year of this series. St'at'imckalh ~ Spirit of the People was the first feature length film in the series, focusing on St'at'imc territory.


SEE MORE FILMS by Jeremy Williams and River Voices Productions;

http://jeremyseanwilliams.wix.com/home#!films/c65q


OUR TEAM

Jeremy Williams - director, producer, camera

Jeremy has been producing independent documentaries sinces 1999 and has won awards for his photography and filmmaking. He focuses on environmental and social justice issues in BC. Jeremy's latest feature film 'St'at'imckalh ~ Spirit of the People' won "Best Documentary" at the Cowichan Aboriginal Film Festival, and was nominated for 'Best Documentary' and 'Best Director' at the Winnipeg Aboriginal Film Festival.


Daniel Gautreau - co-director, camera

Daniel Gautreau has been making films for 20 years and has worked with CBC as a photo journalist abroad. His film Green Dreams explored the controversy in BC's forest industry and the largest citizen movement in Canadian history in Clayoquot Sound.​


Claudia Medina - script adviser, consultant

Claudia Medina began her career as a filmmaker fifteen years ago assisting acclaimed Canadian director Nettie Wild on her feature documentary "A Place Called Chiapas". Since then she has worked alongside a number of respected Canadian filmmakers as a writer, editor, production coordinator, field producer and shooter. Claudia has been the recipient of numerous awards from the Canada Council of the Arts for her short dramatic films she has written, produced and directed. For the past two years she has also been collaborating with artists of different disciplines to create visual projections for performances, and live visuals for electronic musicians throughout Canada and in Barcelona. She also develops and implements curriculum for workshops that combine community development, conflict resolution and ecological awareness through filmmaking to diverse groups nationally and internationally. Claudia has recently completed a master’s degree in Visual Culture from the University of Barcelona with a focus on visual culture and ecology. Recently she has co directed a short documentary about alternative economics called "Life After Growth”, which will be developed into a longer film. Her latest fiction film, "Animal Blessings" set in the Friuli region of Italy, is currently in post production. Most recently, Claudia created a multi media installation that explored our relationship to the natural world.



ABSTRACT  

This film will explore the radically different cultural paradigms of indigenous values and colonial or 'gold rush' mentality which continues to prevail in Canadian politics.  We take a deep look at the landscape with its' vast wilderness and wildlife values, the Tsilhqot’in culture, spiritual relationship with the land and their fight for justice. Ranchers and non-native residents will offer a variety of perspectives and add modern context to life in the wilderness.Rich with poetic cinematography, the films will inspire the audience to action.

​

THE STORY

The Feature Film will weave together Tsilhqot'in myths, place based traditional ecological knowledge (TEK), historic battles (the Chilcotin war of 1864), and contextualize the current fight for rights and title as well as the fight to stop the proposed "Prosperity" gold mine. The Tsilhqot'in, with the support of many environmental organizations have been fighting to stop this mine and its' potential to destroy this last great wilderness of BC.​


THE CHARACTERS

The films will portray the rich culture of the Tsilhqot'in people, as well as the 'new comers' and ranchers that call this place home. The majestic landscape and wildlife are characters in this story too; the salmon that swim 600km up the Fraser and Chilko rivers, the grizzly bears, and wild horses.


THE PLAN

Over the course of one year (+/-) the crew will capture key cultural and political events in and around the Tsilhqot'in lands, court battles and protests, chronicling the struggle for rights and title both historic and current.

The Feature Film will be broadcast on TV, reach the international community through filmfestivals and be distributed on DVD.

CULTURE

To best represent the culture, interviews will be in Tsilhqot’in language whenever possible.

ENVIRONMENTAL FOCUS​

The Tsilhqot'in region is perhaps the biggest and biologically richest area in southern British Columbia, yet this wild land is under threat of destruction. Clearcut logging has destroyed much of the rainshadow forests of the norther Tsilhqot'in territory and the proposed "Prosperity" gold mine at Teztan Biny (Fish Lake) could leach toxins into the entire watershed for millennia.

The rugged landscapes from the Coast Mountain Range east to the Fraser River are home to a healthy population of grizzly bears that have been extirpated from their former ranges south to Mexico.

Wolves, moose, black bear, caribou, mountain goat, Mule deer, cougar, coyote and other species thrive here.The project will highlight the amazing opportunities for conservation of ecosystems and threatened wildlife.

THE CAMPAIGN

Since 1990, the Tsilhqot'in have been fighting for justice in the courts. Several environmental organizations have been working alongside them to protect this paradise for generations to come. ​

Some of the NGOs working on this campaign include;

Friends of Nemaiah Valley

The Wilderness Committee

Sierra Club of BC

Fish Lake Alliance

The Council of Canadians

OTHER LINKS
Tsilhqot'in National Government
Xeni Gwet'in
Taseko Mines Ltd.

story:
Every Tree Counts! 

Above is the tree we were able to save! Its trunk, roots and canopy grow across our property line with a neighbor who tried to have it cut down. With the help of celebrated lawyer Clayton Ruby, we won a legal landmark ruling preventing one owner of a shared tree from unilaterally cutting it down. Our ruling protects the many thousands of trees in Canada that grow across property lines. 

We are asking you to help us raise funds to pay the legal costs we have accrued to achieve this landmark legal ruling.

Our story:  Over the past 18 months, the Scharpers have spent tens of thousands of dollars in their own money to preserve and protect not only their own shared tree, but also thousands of other shared trees. Under law, these co-owned trees are common property. They make our backyards, neighborhoods and cities beautiful places to live. 

Our fight to save the maple began over a year ago when our neighbor suddenly announced her intention to cut it down. We hired expert arborists who determined that the maple is healthy, vigorous and has 50+ more years of life ahead. We tried to convince our neighbor to preserve the tree (offering to fully pay for the maple’s maintenence ourselves), but she hired a lawyer who began to threaten us with legal action. We politely but firmly objected to the destruction of a healthy tree. Our neighbor then sued us. 

As our case went to the Ontario Superior Court, we discovered that our situation was not unusual. According to expert arborists, each year thousands of shared trees are arbitrarily cut down by one owner. After many stressful months of mounting legal bills, we successfully defended ourselves against the lawsuit and won a landmark legal ruling. The Ontario Superior Court dismissed our neighbor's lawsuit in May 2013. In December 2013 our neighbor appealed, but her case was again dismissed.

The 4-page ruling can be read at http://boundarytrees.com 

The modest $15,000 campaign goal on this website represents a fraction of our legal costs. (Costs to defend the ruling against the appeal alone will be approximately $35,000.)

For more information and resources for your own trees, please visit:  http://boundarytrees.com

Thank you for your support!  

—Hilary and Stephen Scharper


For mailing address please contact Hilary Scharper: 

hilary.scharper@gmail.com
story_txt:
Every
Tree Counts! 
Above is the tree we were able to save! Its trunk, roots and canopy grow across our property line with a neighbor who tried to have it cut down. With the help of celebrated lawyer Clayton Ruby, we won a legal landmark ruling preventing one owner of a shared tree from unilaterally cutting it down. Our ruling protects the many thousands of trees in Canada that grow across property lines. We
are asking you to help us raise funds to pay the legal costs we have accrued to achieve this landmark legal ruling.
Our story:  Over the past 18 months, the Scharpers have spent tens of thousands of dollars in their own money to
preserve and protect not only their own shared tree, but also thousands of other shared trees. Under law, these co-owned trees are common property. They make our backyards, neighborhoods and cities beautiful places to live. Our fight to save the maple began over a year ago when our neighbor suddenly announced her
intention to cut it down. We hired expert arborists who determined that the
maple is healthy, vigorous and has 50+ more years of life ahead. We tried to
convince our neighbor to preserve the tree (offering to fully pay for the maple’s
maintenence ourselves), but she hired a lawyer who began to threaten us with legal action. We
politely but firmly objected to the destruction of a healthy tree. Our neighbor
then sued us. 
As our case went to the
Ontario Superior Court, we discovered that our situation was not unusual. According to expert arborists, each year thousands of shared trees are arbitrarily cut
down by one owner. After many stressful months of mounting legal bills, we successfully defended ourselves against the lawsuit and won a landmark
legal ruling. The Ontario Superior Court dismissed our neighbor's lawsuit in May 2013. In December 2013 our neighbor appealed, but her case was again dismissed.The 4-page ruling can be read at http://boundarytrees.com 
The modest $15,000 campaign goal on this website
represents a fraction of our legal costs. (Costs to defend the ruling against
the appeal alone will be approximately $35,000.)
For more information and resources for your own trees, please visit:  http://boundarytrees.comThank you for your support!  
—Hilary and Stephen Scharper
For mailing address please contact Hilary Scharper: 
hilary.scharper@gmail.com

story:
My name is Christina Kamp.  For 18 years I have been teaching children in my home.  I believe in kids, they are the future, and they NEED us to love them, guide them, and protect them. 

For two years we have been growing a small chemical free vegetable garden.  A garden is the perfect way to get kids interested in healthier choices AND teach kids about caring for the environment.  We have had immeasurable success.  We have the chance to expand our garden to grow more of what the kids eat chemical free but we don't have the funding to build the new garden.

America’s children are not eating enough fruits and vegetables and they are 80 percent more likely to eat foods that they grew and cooked themselves.  Oklahoma is at the bottom for fruit and vegetable consumption and the health of our nation is
rapidly declining.

As a result of Little Sprouts Learning Garden, some of the kids have built and tended gardens at home. We are planning garden tours for other child care providers and the community, to publish a book on gardening with kids, and to show as many people as possible how to grow earth friendly gardens. These children will grow up and influence change in how we are treating the earth and our bodies!

What We Need 

We need at least $3,000 to get started on the garden expansion project. We need DHS approved fencing so the kids can be in the garden. The proposed area is 20 feet by 80 feet. We are planning to build cedar raised beds that are one foot deep. We also need plants and seeds. We can fit fourteen 2 by 10 beds along the edges of the area and eleven 3 x 10 beds through the center. We would like to plant fruit trees and bushes, larger crops such as corn, some perennial vegetable and some more annuals.

School gardens are popping up, but very few people are working with young children in gardens.  Fifty percent of what a child learns in their entire lifetime is learned by the age of 3.  Starting young makes the most lasting impression. We use NO chemicals in our garden and have watched how nature takes care of itself. This is knowledge that people need.  There is no project more valuable than this.  And this fire WILL spread!

This year we grew almost 300 pounds of produce, enough to feed the kids fruits and vegetables several days a week throughout the growing season, but if we can build the expansion, we could grow enough to feed them every day during the growing season and preserve food for the other months of the year. 

Any amount will help, even $5 can help keep us moving forward. If we fail to reach the entire goal, we will use the funds to build as many beds as we can and keep working to raise money in the future.

Other Ways You Can Help

Sharing this campaign with your friends, family, and networks like Facebook and Twitter is super important so more people will have the chance to participate! 

Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
NOTE: We met our goal! Thank you so much to all our supporters, you are truly the best! EVERY penny over will go DIRECTLY towards scholarships for low-income kids, through our Adventure Outreach Program. Help us get as many kids as possible outdoors this summer! 


WHAT’S THE STORY?

Two years ago, a fantastic wilderness program decided to close its doors. At the time, the two of us worked in the office as supervisors. After hearing the news, we immediately began scheming about how we could start the program of our dreams. And after hearing lots of gear would be liquidated, our plans suddenly got more serious.

We didn’t know exactly what direction we wanted to go…. but we knew how passionate we are about getting people outdoors. And we knew the power that nature and adventure has on people’s lives.

After many long processing sessions, seeking loads of advice, and a business plan, we decided upon “Cascadia Expeditions”—an outdoor adventure program that serves groups, non-profits, schools, and organizations. We aren’t a “conveyor belt” type of rafting outfitter. Instead we focus on providing deep and personalized experiences amidst Oregon’s most beautiful landscapes.

Last year we found our first partners, the non-profit P:EAR in Portland, and Jackson St. Youth Shelter in Corvallis. We took groups of homeless youth rafting, rock climbing and to the beach on a number of different adventures. The trips proved to be highly successful. 


OUR SITUATION and WHAT WE ARE ASKING FOR

We invested over $28,000 of our own money to get this off the ground. We got 60 kids outdoors our first season, and served four different organizations.  We learned a ton. Most importantly, we confirmed there is a lot of interest and enthusiasm for what we’re doing. We already have additional partners lined up for next season and anticipate running three times as many trips.

We need help to survive this initial period of growth. And we decided to put it out to the internet-crowd-funding universe!

For us to get more people outdoors adventuring, we need to raise $8,600:

·  $5,000 to cover our insurance premiums

·  $2,400 to get us a much needed new raft

·  $1,200 for new tires on our van (and trust us, we need them bad!)

If we exceed our goal, all money over the top will go towards scholarships for underprivileged kids through our Adventure Outreach program. 


THE IMPACT

Do you believe nature and adventure positively impacts people’s lives?                           

Your contribution helps get more people outdoors adventuring!

We plan to work with Jackson Street Youth Shelter, Benton County Mental Health, P:EAR, a program in North Carolina, a boarding school in eastern Oregon, and a yoga studio in Portland, to name a few partners. And, this winter we are networking and marketing like madmen!


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If you simply cannot afford a contribution, there are other things you can do to support us: 

Help spread the word!!!! Via phone, Facebook, your mouth, Twitter, email, street signs, whatever.  Tell people what we are up to and ask them to view our campaign and website.

Use the Indiegogo share tools as well to spread the word!


THANK YOU SO MUCH!  WE ARE BEYOND GRATEFUL!

-Brett and Harry

story:
We need your Common Cents!

It is only through the support of readers like you that The Common Sense Canadian can thrive as a voice for the public and environmental interest - which is why Rafe Mair and I need your help. 

With this easy-to-use tool, you can get some awesome rewards for supporting independent media we know you value and enjoy.

Donating online not your thing? We happily accept cheques :-)

How this fundraiser works

  1. Click on a reward or "perk" from the right hand column
  2. Fill in your email address
  3. Provide your credit card information

It’s that easy!

Media that YOU own

It's no secret that much of mainstream media no longer serves us. The old bastions of journalism not only fail to cover the issues that matter, but they're steadily going out of business. 

Many of us spend tens or hundreds of dollars a month on newspaper and cable subscriptions. What if some of those funds went to support a different model of journalism?

Many of you have spent time at The Common Sense Canadian in the three years since Rafe Mair and I co-founded it - so you have a sense of what we're capable of. What you may not be aware of is how much we've managed to do with so little.

Your support will go a long way!

We already reach a hundred thousand people, primarily in Western Canada - but we want to be speaking to a half million, across the country and beyond. That's where you come in.

We've been working hard for the past year at taking The Common Sense Canadian to the next level. By investing in this campaign, you will help fund:

  • Our new web platform
  • Heightened reporting and coverage of key stories
  • Investigative research
  • New videos and infograhics  
  • Public forums

    We'll keep hammering away at the issues that really matter

    From Enbridge, Kinder Morgan and Keystone XL to "fracking" and LNG; from elusive salmon viruses to billions in hidden government debt; from the destruction of BC Hydro to Canada's lagging support for innovation; from foreign trade deals to solving our transportation challenges; from resource politics and climate change to balancing our need for jobs with our need for a clean environment - the team of independent experts and commentators at The Common Sense Canadian have been there with fresh insights, a dogged pursuit of the truth and defence of the public interest.

    This isn't a one-way street - get awesome rewards for your support!

    By chosing to support our independent journalism, you're also eligible for some unique rewards!

    • HD digital downloads of Sean Holman's new doc, "Whipped" and "Rafe Mair: 80 and Still Kicking Ass"
    • Exclusive web video chat, invitation to Networking Party, dinner with Rafe and me
    • Modo Car Co-op - free membership, $50 discount
    • All-new e-book - "A Dose of Common Sense"
    • Limited, signed Ian McAllister prints

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

    Help us share this Indiegogo campaign and web page with your friends.

    Check out our new website at CommonSenseCanadian.ca - and share widely!

    Like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter

    A citizen-supported media project dedicated to the environment and public interest...now that's common sense!

     

     

    Publisher, The Common Sense Canadian

story:
IDEA: InterDisciplinary Exchange in Action. We will be holding an interdisciplinary conference on sustainable energy Monday, October 14th in the Marshall Center's Royal Palm Ballroom. This event is open to the public.

Our goal is to create an annual gathering in which students, researchers, businesses, and other members of the community can network and exchange ideas, eventually leading to cross-disciplinary collaborations.

Confirmed Speakers as of 9/9/13

Kenneth Christensen - Professor and Director of Undergraduate Program Department of Computer Science and Engineering

Professor Christensen’s research focuses on energy efficiency of computer networks - “green networks.” He has made substantial contributions in technological innovation to reduce the amount of energy used by information and communication technology.

James Stock - Distinguished University Professor and Frank Harvey Endowed Professor of Marketing

Reverse logistics is the focus of the majority of Professor Stock’s research. Reverse logistics deals with all aspects 
of product returns, including remanufacturing, repairing, and refurbishing of products, packaging reuse, recycling, 
minimization and substitution, and environmental and energy implications of reverse logistics.

Christian Wells - Associate Professor of Anthropology and served as Founding Director of the Office of Sustainability

Dr. E. Christian Wells is an environmental archaeologist, whose principal scholarly interests include cultural and 
ecological trajectories of long-term socionatural systems, the influence of environmental worldview on economic decision making, outcome-driven sustainability science.

Allan Feldman - Professor of Science Education at the University of South Florida

Professor Feldman’s research focuses on the role that K-12 teachers and students can have in authentic scientific and engineering research projects. Their participation can serve several functions such as improving workforce development for professionals in fields related to sustainability.

Cheryl Hall - Associate Professor of Government and International Affairs

Professor Hall’s current research focuses on the ways in which different understandings of freedom, agency, happiness, and sacrifice influence our imagination of the possibilities for creating environmentally sustainable societies.

Michael J. Lynch - Professor of Criminology

Professor Lynch has been researching environmental issues for more than 20 years. His research has addressed environmental justice in the United Stated, the distribution of hazardous waste sites and chemical accidents, global warming, behavioral toxins and their effects on behavior, environmental law and regulation, and penalty outcomes in environmental crime prosecutions. 

George Philippidis - Patel College Associate Professor of Sustainable Energy

Dr. Philippidis is a recognized leader in sustainable energy with over 20 years of a successful career directing strategic business units in both the private and public sectors. At the Patel College of Global Sustainability Dr. Philippidis directs the development, scale-up, and commercialization of biomass and algae technologies for sustainable production of transportation fuels, renewable power, and value-added chemicals as part of a green global economy. He works closely with the private sector, venture capital firms, and equity investors to bring clean technologies to the market place.

Friedemann Buschbeck- Green Party liason to Germany, speaking on the German government and what they do in regards to spurring green innovation. 

Ashleigh Stewart- Young Americans for Liberty, speaking about free markets in regards to energy innovation. 

Jay Egg- EggGeoThermal, speaking about geothermal technologies and also discussing his recently published article in National Geographic on the same topic.

Attending Companies: 

SolarSource
YGrene
EggGeothermal
Ocean Energy Council 
Get Off the Grid
Smart Car

Tentatively: 

Bosch Geothermal
Algenol
Solar Independence

Attending Organizations: 

Patel College of Global Sustainability
Student Environmental Association
Sierra Club
Greenpeace
Green Party
FloridaEnvironment.org
Students for Liberty
Florida PIRG
Florida Solar Energy Industries Association 

WMNF will be broadcasting their Sustainable Living Show live from the event (10am-11am).

story:
ConCiencia is a group of young people from different disciplines who excite and educate children to explore science and nature through poetry, art, music, games and theatre.  We run science camps and conservation programs on the Peruvian Northern coast to reconnect children with nature and change the dynamics of education in Peru.  

ConCiencia is teaming up with Jack Johnson on his 2014 From Here To Now To You Tour and All At Once, a social action network connecting nonprofits with people who want to become active in their local and world community. All At Once comes to life online at www.AllAtOnce.org and at the Jack Johnson concerts where you can get educated, get inspired, and connect face-to-face with us and other local and national non-profits. All At Once promotes sustainable local food systems and plastic free initiatives.

By donating to the campaign, you keep our programs running and invest in a future of environmental stewardship along Peru's coasts, South America, and the world, as we reshape the way children discover themselves through their surroundings.  Every dollar you give will be doubled by All at Once and Jack Johnson's World Tour 2014.  Now's your chance to give all you've got and show your support for ConCiencia and our programs!


Our Goal is to reach $2,000 by March 1st, 2014.  Jack Johnson's From Here To Now To You Tour will play Lima's historic Parque del Exposicion March 3rd at 9pm.  Look for the ConCiencia Intervention and learn more about how you can get involved.

story:
This Sunday, September 21, thousands of people will take the streets of New York City to demand world leaders coming to NYC for a UN summit on the climate crisis a world with an economy that works for people and the planet; a world safe from the ravages of climate change; a world with good jobs, clean air and water, and healthy communities. With our future on the line and the whole world watching, we’ll take a stand to bend the course of history. 

Currently GMC students are working on getting a bus to attend this event.  If you can’t attend the march, but still want to contribute, please donate to help with the transportation costs of this event. Every person counts in this march and we will be potentially renting a bus that could fit around 25 to 35 of our students. This march is exactly what GMC's environmental values stand for and that is why we need our environmental leaders present at this march. Help us achieve this goal by donating. Thanks!

story:
UPDATE: ALL ARE WELCOME TO ATTEND MY PRESENTATION, THIS FRIDAY OCTOBER 3 AT 7:30 PM IN THE DINING ROOM OF THE SF ZEN CENTER :)

Summary

I'm a longtime dharma practitioner motivated to do something about the climate crisis. What needs to be done to save our planet is clear, but how to do it is not; the forces that Buddhism calls greed, hate and delusion dim awareness, hindering compassion.
History has shown that non-violent collective action works to change harmful systems. I think we need something along these lines. Gary Snyder wrote, "The mercy of the West has been social revolution; the mercy of the East has been individual insight into the basic self/void. We need both.” I want to bring my individual insight into the world of social revolution, and also bring what I learn in that world into my spiritual practice and community. 
My next big step in this quest is to take the People's Climate Train to New York this September and march in the People's Climate March. This is a train chartered by many grassroots organizations, including 350.org and Buddhist Global Relief, to transport and facilitate connections between activists on their way to the march. I heard about the train from several Buddhist teachers who encouraged me to try to be on it. I hope to have many conversations on the train and at the march with concerned citizens of many backgrounds to put my finger on the pulse of the climate movement. I hope what I learn will be interesting, inspiring or helpful to others, so I'll share pictures, stories and reflections from the trip in my community.
I'll give a presentation at the San Francisco Zen Center to share my experience of the trip, and how it all fits into my thinking on Engaged Buddhism and the Climate Crisis. This trip is both personally exciting and enriching as well as an opportunity to share my journey with others, heightening awareness and positive energy around this incredibly important issue. The entire experience preparing, doing and following this trip is about meeting reality openly, with others. What I'm doing now is itself an expression of my goal: peace.

Financial Goal:

I initially disregarded the idea of this train because I don't have extra money. However, a trustworthy friend encouraged me to ask others for help. I've received a partial scholarship for the train ticket, and a loan so that I was able to buy my train and plane ticket as early as possible. I will pay back whatever I cannot raise, but $450 is what I need to raise to make this trip affordable. Any extra money raised will go towards the trip, presentation or related future project (and keep me better fed than Cliff Bars on the train!). 

I hope you will come to my presentation on this trip or contact me with any interest about this. Money is by no means the only way to support this endeavor. For example, some fellow Zen Students are working with me to sell lemonade as a fundraiser! Others may simply want to talk with me and share their thoughts on these issues.


Further Information:

On the train: http://peoplesclimatetrain.weebly.com/

On the march: http://peoplesclimate.org/march/

On my  perspective: https://sites.google.com/a/trig-cli.org/dticcc/climate-statement


Many Thanks!

story:
Let’s ring in the new year with a brand new perk! With a shout out to our partners in Kenya, Big Life Foundation, we proudly offer the stunning photography of co-founder Nick Brandt.

Nick’s photographs are a tribute to the 35,000 elephants slaughtered annually for their ivory, valued at over $2,000 a pound, and to the other big animals that define Africa.  Big Life is the only organization in East Africa with coordinated cross-border (Kenya/Tanzania) anti-poaching operations. Big Life employs 280 rangers, with 30 outposts and 15 vehicles protecting 2 million acres of wilderness in the Amboseli-Tsavo ecosystem of E. Africa. 

In their desire to give back to the Maasai Mara villagers – and to protect critical habitat from the pressure of firewood scavenging – Big Life is partnering with Solavore to introduce fuel-free, 100% renewable solar cooking to the villages in this region.

Your contribution of $75 will help fund this program, and in return you’ll get a signed copy of Nick’s book “Across the Ravaged Land.”  

Thank you!



Hey everybody! Just as the ink is drying on the COP21 Accord signatures in Paris – woohoo! - we’re introducing one of our biggest supporters and champions of change in Cambodia, Mr. Yorn Yon, President of the United Cambodian American Association. Improving the lives of his countrymen back home is Yorn’s passion, and he is equally passionate about the power of solar cooking for smallholder farmers, reducing deforestation and literally saving life and limb. We’ve created a special perk to make it easy to join Yorn in helping his countrymen: a 100% silk Cambodian scarf from Cambodia as a bonus when you contribute $145 for a Solavore Sport solar oven. We’re gearing up for training beginning in January in 5 regions all around Cambodia – and we need your help to ensure that every class is full.  

Thank you for becoming a Solavore!




100% fuel-free cooking.  No burning of any gas or biomass. No smoke inhaled.

2-pot cooking capacity capable of cooking for a family of 8, two meals a day.

Simmering, baking, dehydrating, even water pasteurization.  Built to last - ten years or longer.




Today, almost 3 billion people still cook over wood fire.  Women are bound to generational roles of wood-gathering, fire-tending, and the constant stirring of cooking pots.

With your help, women will breathe clean indoor air, they’ll have time for learning or starting a micro-business, and forests will recover. 



Today, respiratory illness kills over 4 million women and children per year, more than malaria, more than AIDS.

Women walk increasingly greater distances, often into harm’s way, in their search for fuel wood.

Loss of trees leads to changes in rainfall and wind patterns, such as in Cambodia, where the primary forest covered 70% of the country in 1969.  Now it’s around 3.1%. 

Solavore: empowering women, one solar-cooked meal at a time.



We stretch every dollar by partnering with local organizations – teams who know the people, their customs and their cuisine.  And we create jobs – assembling ovens, distributing ovens and training new users.

Hand in Hand India’s self help groups and microfinance programs have empowered over a million women in ten countries throughout Asia and Africa.  

The BigLife Foundation is dedicated to the preservation of African wild lands and wildlife, and they’re committed to improving the lives in the Maasai Mara villages where they base their outposts. 

The Cambodian diaspora in the US (UCAM) is our newest partner, joining the UN Foundation agency IFAD (Int’l Fund for Agricultural Development) and the Royal Government of Cambodia who invited Solavore to join their Renewable Energy Technology pilot earlier this year. 


Indeed:

1.  Women selling foods they bake or dehydrate

2.  Local assembly in India, in Kenya, in Cambodia

3.  In time, local sales, distribution and support

Solavore: helping communities prosper, one solar-cooked meal at a time


Our goal is to raise $40,000 in 45 days!

With your help, Solavore and Hand in Hand will launch a revolving fund for 100 ovens.

In Kenya, we’re expanding our initial pilot to three villages, including hiring a local trainer…very exciting!


In Cambodia, we’ll be training new Solavores from five districts, ranging from farmers near Phnom Penh to the boat people of Tonlé Sap Lake.


These are ambitious efforts, and with your help we’ll be building the foundation for on-going, self-sustaining programs.


By its very nature, solar cooking requires sunshine. Thanks to its 1” surround insulation, you can cook in your Solavore Sport under passing clouds – thirty minutes of bright sun out of every sixty will keep you cooking. However, monsoon season can really put a damper on things.

That’s why in our developing country programs the Solavore Sport is presented as the heart of an integrated cooking system.  Keeping food warm until mealtime is the job of the retained heat cooker, an outer container lined with insulating materials.  A small, efficient-wood-burning stove (EWS) burns only a few twigs to heat water for morning tea.  An integrated cooking system with the Solavore Sport at its core reduces firewood consumption by 50%-80% - saving lungs, time, and trees.








· Take a baby step off the grid.  Hours of cooking without burning a single kilowatt.

· Have fun: If you can use a crockpot, you can cook with the Solavore Sport.  No burning. Flavors are amazing and clean up is a breeze.

· Be prepared:  The Solavore Sport can pasteurize water and cook dinner in the event of a disaster or emergency



Anne Patterson, founder and CEO

Anne started Solavore™ after a successful career in hi-tech. She cut her teeth at Hewlett-Packard and managed operations planning for Steve Jobs at NeXT Computer during his Wilderness Years away from Apple. She later worked for 3Com Corporation, managing distribution and logistics for Europe, the Middle East and Africa, while based in the UK. 

Raised under a big sky in Wyoming, Anne is an expansive thinker, adventurer, and all-around Renaissance woman. A giver, not a taker. She studied music at Colorado State University, became a teacher, and earned a masters degree in mathematics, taking up computer programming at the precise moment when women, despite their early contributions, dropped off the programming map. 

During her corporate years, Anne fed her soul by mentoring young women and helping build schools in Africa. Today, she lives close to the bone, dividing her time between a sailboat and an off-grid island cottage in the Long Island Sound. Wind and sun play prominent roles in her life.

The original solavore, Anne believes passionately in solar cooking as a clean, joyful, liberating alternative to wood fires and grid-based fossil-fuel appliances. 


Mike and Martha Port, Managing Directors:  

Founded and managed the Solar Oven Society over 15 years, now managing Solavore’s production operations.  Mike and Martha have been solar cooking advocates around the world, responsible for the deployment of over 20,000 Sport solar ovens both in the US and in the developing world.


Paul Funk, PhD, R&D and Engineering

Paul wrote the book on solar ovens. Actually, what he wrote is the international evaluation criteria for sun-cooker performance, published by the American Society of Agricultural Engineers as ASAE Standard S580.1.  The Sport owes much of its elegant functionality—from its one-piece resin base to its stackable shipping-container-optimized shape—to Paul’s insights.


John Roche, R&D and Engineering

John’s solar-cooking passion started at 3M, where he worked as a research and design engineer and headed up the company’s Solar Films Division. At 3M, John oversaw the development of a robust, hi-tech polyester film designed to withstand exposure to normally destructive UV light, now a key component of the Solavore Sport.


Vera Weill-Halle, Impact Business Development

Vera is the former Director of Resource Mobilization, and Senior Advisor for Innovative Financing at the UN International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD). Currently, she serves as Director for Donor Relations, Partners for Euro-African Green Energy, (PANGEA) and Chairperson of the Board of Directors, Women Organizing for Change in Agriculture and Natural Resource Management (WOCAN).


Kristin Laing, Director of Digital Content

Kristin spent many years as a software project manager before moving into the creative realm. She ran her own design firm for 15 years before joining Solavore. Kristin oversees our website, social media and digital marketing.

story:
Name: Ubud Botany Interactive

About Me:

My name is Dewi, I was born into a peasant family. After a serious accident, my father had to give up his career as an architect and my mother became the breadwinner. My mother is a farmer. We have rice fields located close to Ubud, on the island of Bali. Our everyday needs are met through the crops we grow in the fields. This is where I learnt how to use plants as medicine and for everyday uses, such as hair conditioners, body scrubs, etc. I attended school while working part-time in the rice fields. Eventually I managed to obtain a scholarship to further my education in biology /plant sciences at the University of Udayana, Bali.

I love to share the knowledge that I gained over the years so that the younger generation could learn to care more about the environment and can utilize natural resources for daily life, such as the use of plants for their healing purposes. I hope that my business can spur young people to return to nature, the concept of a harmonious relationship between: man and God, man and man, and man and his environment. Moreover, I hope to be able to realize this business so that I can provide care and accommodation for my elderly parents.

The Idea:

Purpose for establishing this business is:

  1. Introduce the farming culture to the younger generation so that they learn to care about the importance and preservation of agriculture in our lives.This is done by doing a walking tour in the agricultural area, with an explanation about the rice growing process from cultivation, maintenance, through to harvesting. Preserving the irrigation system and the concept of harmony to maintain a relationship between God, farmers and their environment - the rice field.  This way the younger generation can more respect the environment, by doing the tour.
    Moreover, the tour will include an explanation about the various types of plants that can be used for daily living. The participants will be taught plant classification and descriptions of plants that can be used for daily food, for traditional medicine and beauty products.
  2. Botanical Class: This class will explain the process of making a natural product that is made with the concept of back to nature.  We will have a hands-on experience in creating our own botanical products, which they can take home.
  3. Fresh Botanical Supplier: I will do good relation with farmers and support them to growing organic plants.  When these are harvested I will collect some vegetables, fruits, rice, all that is harvested from ricefield and I will buy it from the farmers.  I use it for Botanical class ingredients and sell it to people. This business will help farmers to get more income for their children going to school.    

The Service:

Walks

Bali Agriculture and Botany Walks is a nature immersion walk in the fields around Ubud. The walk lasts approximately 2 hours. During this walk, guests will enjoy the green scenery and see the various types of plants that have known benefits as well as how to use these plants for everyday life such as for medicine, beauty treatments, and food. Participants will learn how to take advantage of this natural wealth, by looking at the plants and then classify and smell them. This will greatly assist in the introduction of native plants, which will be the ingredients used later in the class. The walk is a way of gaining first-hand knowledge about agriculture in Bali, from the seedling process, planting, maintenance, and harvesting.

Class

Following the walk, guests will be involved in an interactive session. This class will explain the process of making a natural product that is made ​​with the concept of back to nature. Here guests will have a hands-on experience in creating their own botanical products, which they can take home. The process will be guided by an English-speaking teacher. This class lasts approximately 2 hours.

Ingredients supplied in the Class:

Fresh rice

Aloe vera

Tumeric

Clove

Sweet corn

Palm sugar

Ginger

Rice powder

Cucumber

Galangal

Hibiscus leaf

Tamarin

Botanical Products that guests will produce:

1. Natural hair conditioner

2. Natural Balinese body healing scrub

3. Natural face mask

4. Natural Balinese detox drink (jamu)

5. Natural skin moisturizer ( sun protection)

The return for investors:

Fresh Botanical Supplier: I will do good relation with farmers and support them to growing organic plants.  When these are harvested I will collect some vegetables, fruits, rice, all that is harvested from ricefield and I will buy it from the farmers.  I use it for Botanical class ingredients and sell it to people. This business will help farmers to get more income for their children going to school.     


The Service:
Walks 
Bali
Agriculture and Botany Walks is a nature immersion walk
in the fields around Ubud. The walk lasts approximately 2
hours. During this walk, guests will enjoy the green scenery and
see the various types
of plants that have
known benefits as well as how to
use these plants for
everyday life such as for medicine, beauty
treatments, and food. Participants will learn
how to take advantage of this
natural wealth, by looking at the plants
and then classify and smell them. This
will greatly assist in the introduction of native plants, which
will be the ingredients used later in the class. The walk is a way of
gaining first-hand knowledge about agriculture in
Bali, from the seedling
process, planting, maintenance,
and harvesting. 
Class
Following
the walk, guests will be involved in an interactive session. This class
will explain the process of making
a natural product that is made ​​with the
concept of back to nature.
Here guests will have a hands-on experience in creating their own botanical
products, which they can take home. The process will be guided
by an English-speaking teacher. This
class lasts approximately 2 hours.
Ingredients supplied in
the Class:




Fresh rice


Aloe vera


Tumeric




Clove


Sweet corn


Palm sugar




Ginger


Rice powder


Cucumber




Galangal


Hibiscus leaf


Tamarin





Botanical Products that
guests will produce:
1. Natural hair
conditioner
2. Natural Balinese body
healing scrub 
3. Natural face mask
4. Natural Balinese detox
drink (jamu)
5. Natural skin moisturizer
( sun protection)

story:
Hello and Welcome to ANIÁN OFF THE GRID 

ANIÁN OFF THE GRID is about our journey. It has taken us from shaping surfboards in our back yards to manufacturing goods in Canada and selling them in our own store.  With your support we can take the next step. Together we can make ANIÁN Canada's 1st and only 100% OFF THE GRID retail store, located in Victoria and powered entirely by solar energy.

How can we do it?

We have already done it. We just need to make it bigger.

Current System

Our current solar system is comprised of five solar panels that create 100 watts of energy.  For now we can run everything with that.  However with winter coming and the shortening of days we can't get enough from what we have.

With better panels combined with thicker wiring through out we will be able to maximize our power charge to the battery bank.

Perks

Free shipping for stickers and post cards, for everything else please add 10 bucks.

Stoke Sticker

Water Paint Post Card


Camp Socks

Limited Edition T.

Henley

Merino Wool T.

Solar SurfBoard
Shipping and handling is extra and starts once the campaign is over.


We are asking you to help ANIÁN show the world that even on an island where there is more precip than the rainforests of Uganda solar can work.

    Risks & Challenges

    If we do not raise enough funds to upgrade our system, we will have to spend the winter in the dark working with our headlamps.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      This Campaign is as much about awareness of solar energy as it is about raising funds.  If you are able to share our video, or campaign it would be greatly appreciated.

      #anianoffthegrid

      Facebook  https://www.facebook.com/pages/ANIÁN/5346856865...

      Twitter https://twitter.com/ANIANMFG 

      Website www.anianmfg.com

      Instagram @anianmfg

story:
Where others see rubbish, garbage and waste, we at Diseclar see furniture. Thanks to our inventive manufacturing process we’re able to turn waste materials into stylish furniture that can be used in and outdoors. By using non-degradable plastic and vegetable fibers that come from agro-industrial waste sites, we’re able to create a product that both looks and feels like solid wood. Our stylish, custom pieces not only look great, they’re also resistant to moisture, rot, insects and UV rays, and are markedly better for the environment than traditionally produced furniture.

(Español) Donde muchas personas ven basura, desperdicios y desechos, nosotros en Diseclar vemos Mobiliario. Gracias a nuestro proceso de producción innovador y amigable con el medio ambiente, transformamos la basura en mobiliario con diseños exclusivos y elegantes, los cuales pueden ser usados en exteriores. Se fabrican a partir de plástico reciclado y fibra natural que proviene de desechos agro-industriales, con lo cual logramos crear productos con apariencia y textura a la madera. Nuestros productos brindan ciertas ventajas en comparación a los mobiliarios tradicionales, ya que son resistentes a la humedad, no se pudren, insectos, a los rayos ultravioleta (Sol), y protegemos al medio ambiente


The problem

Two years ago I worked as an industrial engineer at a big company that produces beers, water and soft drinks. They use plastic bottles to sell their products, and the problem is that they don`t recycle this bottles.  In my country (Colombia), we produce around 40.000 tons per day of solid waste, but we just recycled the 5%.

I decided to quit my job and dedicate myself to find a profitable solution to solving this problem.

(Español) Hace dos años, estaba trabajando como ingeniero industrial en una gran compañía que produce cerveza, agua y bebidas. Ellos usan botellas plásticas para vender sus productos, sin embargo estas botellas no se reciclan. En Colombia producimos más de 40.000 toneladas al día de residuos sólidos pero solo reciclamos el 5%.

The Solution

We produce furniture from plastic and agro industrial wastes from the coffee industry, based on an innovative process. Plastic wastes come mainly from used plastic bottles that would otherwise be discarded as contaminating garbage. Agro industrial wastes include coffee chaff, rice chaff and sugar cane. This mix gives our products resistance to moisture, rot and insects. It also provides UV resistance, rigidity and the feel and look of solid wood.

(Español) nosotros producimos mobiliario hecho a partir de plástico reciclado y desechos agro-industriales de la industria del café. Los desechos plásticos provienen de las botellas plásticas las cuales no están siendo reutilizadas y son altamente contaminantes. Los desechos agro industriales que mas utilizamos son la cascarilla de café y bagazo de caña. Con esta innovadora mezcla obtenemos un producto resistente a la humedad, insectos y no se pudre. Al igual que es resistente a los rayos UV, al agua, nieve y tiene apariencia a la madera.

Our current product portfolio includes (nuestro portafolio):

Home chairs and tables (Mesas y sillas): Garden Lounge Set 

Beach chairs (Sillas para playa): Baru Chair

Benches (Bancas): Española Bench 

Farallones Bench

Pool Chairs (asoleadora):

Decks (pisos):

Dog

Houses (casas para mascots):


What is the big problem we face in the world today?

Environmental and Social Impact in Our region:

In the World, we generate more than 9.975.000.000 tons of solid waste per day, this is equivalent to the weight of 25 million Boeings 747!.

(Español) en la tierra producimos más de 9.975.000.000 de toneladas al día de residuos sólidos, lo que equivale al peso de ¡25 millones de Boeings 747!


In Latin-America alone, we generate around 463.000 tons of solid waste per day and recycle only 5% of this, each person generates more than 1,4 kg/day.

(Español) En Latinoamérica se producen más de 463.000 toneladas al día de residuos sólidos, sin embargo solo reciclamos el 5%, es decir que cada persona genera alrededor de 1,4 kg/day.


55% of this solid waste is going to sea, where many animals die every day from eating waste like plastic caps, plastic bottles, plastics glasses and other plastic objects.

(Español) 55% de los residuos sólidos van al mar, donde gran parte de los animales mueren cada día al ingerir estos desperdicios como tapas plásticas, botellas, vasos plásticos, entre otros. 


Deforestation in Latin-America stands at 50.000 km2 per year (the area of Switzerland!), cut every year to produce, among others, wood furniture. These forests are the home to millions of animal species and the spring point for thousands of rivers that bring water to 588 million Latin Americans.

(Español) la deforestación en Latinoamérica es de 50.000 km2 por año, lo cual se asemeja al área de Suiza. Estos árboles son cortados para producir mobiliario. Los bosques que son cortados día tras día, nacen las fuentes hídricas que alimentan a las de 588 millones de latinoamericanos y es el hogar de millones de animales. 


There are more than 135.000 recyclers in Latin- American, people who live of recycling wastes every day in the street and that do not receive a fair compensation. Many of them earn less than USD1 per day. 

(Español) existen más de 135.000 recicladores en Latinoamérica, los cuales viven de la basura que recogen día tras día en las calles y no reciben una buena remuneración para esta labor. Muchos de ellos viven con menos de USD 1 por día. 

There are more than 563.000 coffee farmers in Latin America. Ever year their incomes are affected by fluctuating exchange rates that often led to net losses.

(Español) en nuestro continente hay más de 563.000 caficultores los cuales se ven afectados por la fluctuación del dólar, cuando venden sus productos, generando bajos ingresos para sus familias. 

Re-using wastes to produce a substitute for wood tackles 3 key environmental and social issues of our region of influence in Colombia:

1)  CO2 emissions: In our first year of operations we will recycle 300.000 kg of plastic waste and 192.000 kg of agro-industrial waste thus preventing the production of 35.136 ton of CO2. 

2)  Deforestation: As a substitute for wood for furniture production, our mix saves the lives of more than 2.000 trees per year.

3)  Unemployment among the most vulnerable:

a.  We will create 300 indirect jobs among recyclers from whom we will source plastic wastes. Recyclers are the poorest and most vulnerable social group in the region.

b.  We will create 250 indirect jobs among Coffee farmers whom we will source coffee wastes from (Vegetable Fiber)

(Español) en Diseclar reciclamos los desechos para producir un producto que reemplaza a la madera, con lo cual generamos 3 impactos positivos ambientales y sociales en nuestra región.

1)  Emisión de CO2: en el primer año de operaciones esperamos reciclar mas 300.000 kg de desechos plásticos y más de 192.000 kg de desechos agro-industriales, con lo cual lograremos retenes más de 35.136 toneladas de CO2

2)  Deforestación: reemplazando del uso de la madera en la fabricación de mobiliario lograremos salvar más de 2.000 árboles.

3)  Empleo a personas vulnerables:

a.  Crearemos más de 300 empleos indirectos a recicladores quienes son nuestro principal proveedor de materia prima. Los recicladores son personas de bajos recursos y vulnerables en nuestra región.

b.   Crearemos más de 250 empleos indirectos a caficultores, quienes son nuestro proveedor de la fibra vegetal. 

News about Diseclar (Noticias sobre Diseclar)
 

  
 

  
 

  
 

  

Diseclar had been recognized by some international and national awards:

  • Innovation Javeriana Contest, Colombia.
  • Fondo Emprender, Colombia.
  • Ventures, Colombia.
  • CSR (corporate social responsibility) - Comfamiliar, Colombia
  • BID Juventud, BID, USA.
  • SEED Award, UNEP, Kenya.
  • Stephan Schmidheiny Awards, CIC, Costa Rica

(Español) Diseclar ha sido reconcido por ciertos premios Internacionales y nacionales como:

  • Concurso de inovacion Javeriana, Colombia.
  • Fondo Emprender, Colombia.
  • Ventures, Colombia.
  • Premio a la Responsabilidad Social Empresarial - Comfamiliar, Colombia.
  • BID Juventud, BID, USA.
  • SEED Award, UNEP, Kenya.
  • Stephan Schmidheiny Awards, CIC, Costa Rica

Features (Características)

Contribution Perks

  • Electronic Certificate: 10 USD, an electronic certificate of your support.(certificado electrónico: 10 USD, un certificado electrónico por su apoyo en nuestra campaña)
  • Your name in our company: 20 USD, your name and your country will appear in the wall of our new headquarters. (Su nombre en nuestra compañía: 20 USD, escribiremos su nombre y país en la portada de nuestra nueva sede).
  • Diseclar`s Candles: 35 USD, set of 3 candles produced with our material, they will have your name and Diseclar’s Logo. (Velas de Diseclar: 35 USD, juego de 3 velas producidas con nuestro material, las cuales vendrán marcadas con su nombre y el logo de Diseclar.



  • Adopt a tree: 70 USD, we will plant a tree on your behalf in our City Cali, Colombia. (Adopta un árbol: 70 USD, sembraremos un árbol en nuestra ciudad Cali, Colombia).
  • WEAR “I am Green”: 60 USD, Limited edition T-shirt (unisex) with Diseclar Logo and with a label that reads “I am Green”. (Vístete con la campaña “I am Green”: 60 USD, Edición Limitada de una camiseta unisex con el logo de diseclar y con la marca “I am Green”).


  • LIMITED EDITION Farallones Bench: 500 USD, Limited Edition Farallones Bench, produced with our material and with your name and Diseclar’s Logo on it + T-shirt + Candle + Electronic Certificate. (EDICION LIMITADA Banca Farallones: 500 USD, Edición Limitada de la banca Farallones producida con nuestro material y marcada con su nombre y logo de Diseclar + una camiseta + certificado electrónico).
  • Amazing trip to our factory: 3.000 USD, 4 day trip to our headquarters and production facilities. The event will happen in 2016. Includes 5*Hotel accommodation, local transportation and a visit to the Coffee Park (www.parquedelcafe.co) in Armenia City (includes meals, entrance ticket and transportation). Airplane tickets are not included. (Gran Viaje a nuestra fábrica: 3.000 USD, 4 días de viaje a nuestra nueva sede. El evento se llevara a cabo en el 2016 en la inauguración de la compañía. Incluye: acomodación en Hotel 5 estrellas, transporte local y una visita al parque del café (www.parquedelcafe.co) en la ciudad de Armenia (incluye comidas, entrada al parque y transporte). Ticket de avión no está include. 


Also, please support us with your vote (también nos puedes ayudar con tu voto)

We are currently participating in The Venture from Chivas Regal global contest. We need your vote to support our venture. During 5 week you can vote up to 1 time per week. You can use your Facebook or Google+ id to vote for us. To vote for us go on https://www-staging.theventure.com/gb/en/finalists/diseclar. Voting starts on May 11th and ends on June 14th.

(Español) Estamos participando en el concurso global The Venture de Chivas Regal. Necesitamos su voto, este proceso dura 5 semanas donde puede votar cada semana. Con el usuario de facebook o de Google + puede votar por Diseclar. Las votaciones se hacen en el siguiente link https://www-staging.theventure.com/gb/en/finalists/diseclar e inician el próximo 11 de mayo hasta el 14 de junio.

Please share with your friends and family our campaign in Indiegogo.

Follow us:

Instagram: @Diseclar

Twitter: @Diseclar

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Diseclar?ref=hl

Thanks for your help.

What We Need

We need to raise additional capital: USD 100.000 to open up new markets and increase the social and environmental impact in our region. We have already identified potential new clients in United States, Mexico and Costa Rica, but we currently lack the production capacity required to meet this demand. An increase in production capacity would also help us have a far greater impact environmentally and socially, as we would be able to further help the waste collecting community and coffee farmers of Colombia.

(Español) Buscamos levantar USD 100.000 para abrir nuevos mercados e incrementar nuestro impacto social y ambiental en nuestra región. Tenemos clientes potenciales en países como Estados Unidos, México y Costa Rica, pero no contamos con la capacidad de producción para atender esta demanda. Incrementando nuestra capacidad de producción lograremos tener un impacto social y ambiental más alto, ayudando a los caficultores y recicladores de nuestro país. 

The Team (equipo de trabajo)

Our cofounder and CEO, an industrial engineer, he is a specialist in CSR (corporate social responsibility). Born and raised in Colombia, he will represent us at The Venture final.

(Español) Fundador y Director Ejecutivo, ingeniero industrial, especialista en Responsabilidad Social Empresarial. Nació y creció en Colombia, será la persona que representara a Diseclar en el concurso de The Venture. 

Industrial engineer from Switzerland helps us reach new markets throughout Central America

(Español) ingeniero industrial, nació en Suiza, y nos ayuda en  la apertura de nuevos mercados en Centro América. 

She is our business administrator, Monica has a Masters degree in Logistic, she is from Colombia and helps us improve all internal processes in Diseclar

(Español) Administradora de empresas, tiene una maestría en logística, nació en Colombia y nos ayuda en el mejoramiento de los procesos internos de Diseclar.

Electronic engineer, from Colombia, leads our marketing strategy

(Español) Ingeniero Eléctrico, lidera las estrategias de mercadeo de la empresa.
