End of May: Sanctuary is fully setup.

The ProblemWe are on the brink
of a biological disaster. Bees who are essential for pollinating many fruits
and vegetables have been dying off in massive numbers since 2006. Beekeepers have
been losing on average around 28-34% of their hives every year with some
farmers experiencing losses up to 90%. Some commercial beekeepers say losses
have expanded drastically in the last year, wiping out 40 percent or even 50
percent of the hives. Losses of this magnitude are not sustainable for
beekeepers or the ecosystem. Bees are in such high demand they are trucked all
over the country to pollinate crops.
Honeybees
are the most important insects to the human food chain their role in our diet
goes beyond honey production. These tireless creatures pollinate about
one-third of crop species in the United States, bees pollinate about 100
flowering food crops including apples, nuts, broccoli, avocados, soybeans,
asparagus, celery, squash and cucumbers, citrus fruit, peaches, kiwi, cherries,
blueberries, cranberries, strawberries, cantaloupe, melons, as well as animal-feed
crops, such as the clover that’s fed to dairy cows. Essentially all flowering
plants need bees to survive.
Bees are a
highly valued resource around the world. They are prized for their honey and
wax production and depended upon for pollination of many important crops. By
far the most important contribution honey bees make to modern agriculture is
the pollination services that they provide.
A continued
massive bee die-off will imperil world food supplies and devastate ecosystems
that depend on them. The loss of these creatures might rival climate change in
its impact on life on earth.
Studies have
shown us that there are number of factors that are weakening the bees. We have
to assist those amazing creatures that have helped our agriculture in so many
years. 
Crop
pollination by insects is estimated to be worth $19 billion to the economy of
the USA. There are estimated 2.4 million hives in the United States. The
increased use of pesticides, the reduction in the number of wild colonies and
the increased value of both bees and pollinated crops have all added to the
importance of protecting bees. 
We are
currently at the minimum level of bees required for food production. For the
almond crops in January and February in California, 1.8 million bees are
trucked to the fields from all over the United States. In January this year the
only reason the almond farmers were able to complete the pollination is because
the weather was perfect. That means that in 2 months time we could have reached
the tipping point and the bee shortage becomes very real for everyone. There is no other viable alternative to bees
when it comes to pollination
There have
been many researches done into this area, but no real solution has been found and
bees are still dying at the same or faster rate as before. We need a new
approach.Bee hive built in our research facilityThe solutionWe need the money for
land and building bee hives to create a bee sanctuary. bees need long-lasting,
undisturbed nesting sites in sunny, relatively bare patches of ground with a
diversity of nectar and pollen-rich plants nearby. The greater the variety of
flowering plants, the greater the number of bee species that will be attracted.
One of the major risks, to both bee and plant diversity, is their separation
through increasing fragmentation of wild uncultivated areas. Without bees, many
flowering plants fail to set seed and without flowering plants, there is no
food for bees. Leaving field margins, ditches, roadside verges and woodland
edges unsprayed with chemicals, and undisturbed, does much for bee
conservation.
Beekeeping
has changed a lot in the past few decades and the number of commercial
beekeepers has declined fast. Because of the bee die-offs commercial beekeepers
are losing money and there are no incentives for new people to get into
beekeeping.
The sanctuaries
will allow us to conduct research and build a knowledge base that beekeepers
can use to take better care of their bees, help with returning beekeeping to a
profitable business and attract new people into beekeeping.
We need to
concentrate on what we can do today so there will be a tomorrow. We need to
help the bees gain their strength to fight another day.
Who we areWe are an
independent research group based in Minnesota. Our passion for the environment
and our business experience creates a unique mix that we believe can be used to
make a difference.
Much of our
research and production of hives will be
conducted in our 144,000 sq ft facility in Minnesota.
Help us make
this a reality so we can help the honey bee and at the same time the health and
survival of the human race.
Thank you
for your support.

story:
“Prayer begins with the senses, in the body, in geography, in botany.” 

--Eugene Peterson

Join us in supporting the efforts of creation care, hospitality, and songwriting through the work of Nashville A Rocha, a faith-based conservation organization.

Thirty years ago, A Rocha founders, Peter and Miranda Harris moved their family to the Alvor Estuary in Portugal to help start a Christian field study center.  A Rocha (Portuguese for “the rock”) is now in 19 countries around the world, including the US.  Blending the work of science, faith and hospitality, A Rocha projects are characteristically rooted in community – working to improve relationships between people and their particular place.

In Nashville, our A Rocha story includes music.  In a town of songwriters, we wondered what might happen if we gathered musicians and scientists and talked together about the created world around us.  The first A Rocha songwriting retreat resulted in an album, From Smallest Seed, a collaborative effort to cultivate community and creation care. 

Our story also includes kids, and neighbors, and yards, and a vision for what could happen if we started thinking more deliberately about stewarding our place; starting small, thinking big.

So join us in celebrating the release of our first album, From Smallest Seed,* and help us raise support for the work of Nashville A Rocha as we take the next step forward.

Learning to Bio Blitz, taking notes on our own backyard.  photo - Flo Paris Oakes

1. Backyard Biodiversity Project 

$4,000 for plants, tools, educational resources and promotion to help transform urban and suburban spaces into more biodiverse wildlife habitats

“Diversity of species is a form of safety in numbers…the more species there are, the less likely it is that any one of them will get out of hand and – just as true – the less likely that any one of them will suffer unduly.”  Sara Stein, Noah’s Garden: Restoring the Ecology of Our Own Backyards

We care about the environment because we believe God made it, loves it, and asks us to take care of it.  Environmental conservation work can be intimidating, so we’re starting with work that can be done in our own backyards and learning what it takes for ordinary people to become conservationists.  Inspired by the work of Douglas Tallamy, Sara Stein, Wendell Berry and others, we seek to better know and love our particular place, and to create and restore habitat for insects, birds and mammals right where we live. 

Currently in its pilot phase, our Backyard Biodiversity group consists of five busy moms (with 12 kids among us).  We've been reading and meeting together to develop the concept, and connecting to local groups already doing good work.  Since native plants are essential to biodiversity, our first step has been to help each other install rain gardens full of native perennial plants in our yards, with the support of Cumberland River Compact (a local watershed protection agency). 

We'd like to empower and inspire others to join us in this work. Some of the barriers to creating habitat include lack of knowledge, skills and materials (rain garden installation costs run from $300 to $1,700 or more). Funding will help us address these needs and share this developing program with others who want to learn about biodiversity and restore it to their own yards. 


Young 'Great Horned' owls in the backyard.  photo - Andy Gullahorn

"It is increasingly clear that much of our wildlife will not be able to survive unless food, shelter and nest sites can be found in suburban habitats." Douglas Tallamy, Bringing Nature Home

Sharing songs at the A Rocha Songwriter Retreat.  photo - Trevor Henderson

2. Songwriter Retreats

$4900 for hospitality, guest speakers, and CD manufacturing costs

We are shaped by what we sing.  Songs have the power to influence us and our response to the world around us.  Nashville A Rocha has organized and hosted two local songwriting retreats, spearheaded by singer-songwriter Sandra McCracken, to explore the intersection of songwriting and creation care.  The result is one finished album: From Smallest Seed.  With more music in the works, Nashville A Rocha would love to continue to inspire our Nashville community through songwriting retreats offered at no cost to the artist. 

Listen to one of the songs from our first retreat: The Night Sky - Featuring Sara Groves and Andy Gullahorn

(The song link above opens best in the Safari browser.)

Getting our feet wet in the creek.  photo-Courtney Howard

 3. Creation Care Camp

$1,100 for camp curriculum and 'Nature Build'

We are preparing for our 3rd year of Creation Care Camp where we use A Rocha USA's curriculum to engage kids in hands-on outdoor learning with the help of local wildlife agencies, musicians and pastors. The camp quickly fills to capacity every year (30 kids).  Help us expand our ability to share this special program with more kids in 2015.  Also, as an extension of the Backyard Biodiversity project, we're piloting a "Nature Build" program this summer, where 15 kids will spend four summer mornings learning about biodiversity and making a piece of habitat to take home (like a birdhouse, ladybug house or bug hotel), in the hope that we can share this curriculum more broadly in the future.


Learning about the watershed. Photo-Courtney Howard

_________________________________________________________________

More detailed funding breakdown:

Backyard Biodiversity: $4,000
-Native plants, tools or other supplies (like mulch and drainage materials), with a goal of installing native plant gardens at 30 homes by the end of 2015, granting up to $100 per garden (according to need). $3,000
  -Developing educational materials for workshops and promotional materials, and yard signs. $500
-Developing data tracking resources, Bio Blitz materials, to document changes to biodiversity indexes $500

Songwriter Retreats: $4,900
-Food, hospitality and retreat venue ($500 per retreat) $1000
-Travel and honorarium to bring in guest speakers/scientists  $1,000
-CD duplication  $1,700
-Artwork Design  $400
-Sheet Music  $300
-Website development  $500

Creation Care Camp: $1,100
- Supplies and scholarships to expand Creation Care Camp in 2015 $500
- Creation Care Camp curriculum adaptation for Tennessee ecology  $300
- Supplies and materials for 2014 summer Nature Build program  $300

Nashville A Rocha is a non-profit. Your donation is tax deductible. For more information, contact Nashville Project Director, Jenna Henderson:  jenna.henderson@arocha.org

story:
SustainaSoil

We are two students from NC State and the University of North Carolina combining our strengths in science and business to solve one PIG problem. Pigs out number people in North Carolina and their waste has become a huge environmental problem. The waste poses a threat to rivers, wildlife, and people. Together we begin to tackle this growing problem. Using hog manure as an input for composting, we use red wiggler worms to consume the manure and produce worm castings that act as one of the world’s most potent organic fertilizers. This composting process provides a premium product while diminishing a major pollutant in North Carolina. Synthetic fertilizers are known to be an environmental detriment due to the chemical run off harming our water supply. Our product is an alternative fertilizer that mitigates the environmental hazards of synthetic fertilizers, while improving healthy soil ecology. With YOUR help, the stronger our business grows, the more waste we can refashion into something that is good for our planet.


What Your Dollars Can Do For Our Planet

First we need an infrastructure to grow on. Your dollars will go directly to key hardware we need for refashioning hog waste into worm castings. Our goal is to have relatively large scale hardware designed for using our worms to process waste. With the proper equipment we will completely eliminate the harmful effects of hog waste. With growing worm populations we will need to expand our worm housing units, to process several tons of waste per week. Equipment is our limiting factor in terms of how much waste we can eliminate. Our ten thousand dollar goal will be enough to get the ball rolling in starting our business. This will help finance a cascade of production allowing us to expand throughout our state and region. 

If you haven't fallen in love with our business then our donation perks will help to change that. Using worm castings on your garden will help fruit bearing plants grow larger and healthier. With a 25 dollar donation you will receive one pound of our organic Power Fertilizer made of worm castings. You can watch as your garden grows to the brightest you have ever seen it! With a 100 dollar donation you will receive 2000 red wiggler worms (one of only two species of worms that produce large casting quantities). This robust population of worms will have a 5 year life span that grows each month. You can use these worms to get your hands dirty and produce castings of your own using your yard waste/kitchen scraps. Doing a small part to compost your food waste and reduce landfill waste volume! With a 1000 dollar donation you will recieve a blueprint to a small worm bin and 6000 starter worms. The bin will help collect the valuable castings that your starter worms produce and potentially give you a life time of everything you need to maintain a beautiful garden while reducing your waste footprint! This perk will have your neighbors asking your secret garden trick and you asking for their food scraps!

The Impact

We must find a solution to a large and continually growing environmental waste problem. With the growing population and increases in waste it is crucial for us to practice sustainable ways of existing on this planet, we have no choice but to become responsible stewards of our planet. Our small startup aims to protect the farming communities as well as the ecosystem. Thus far, our startup has won a first place entrepreneurial grant from the University of North Carolina and has partnered with a farm outside of Raleigh, NC. With our proven track record you can rest assured that your money will go to a responsible sustainable cause. Doing your part to donate today brings us all closer to a cleaner planet with beautiful gardens.

story:
Money raised through this campaign will create a fund to support Forest Schools across the country - the only one of its kind.

Forest Schools are needed urgently, especially in deprived and urban areas, because:

  • All children need regular contact with the natural world to explore, play and learn: Forest Schools provide all children with this essential contact and freedom in a woodland environment.

  • Children suffer physical and mental health problems if they do not have regular contact with the natural world: Forest Schools help the personal development and wellbeing of the whole child.

  • Children face barriers to experiencing natural and wild places: Forest Schools overcome these barriers because they are part of a child's school day.

  • Children will become adults who value nature and its benefits: Forest Schools increase children's environmental understanding and sustainable use of the natural world.

"We can't afford to have children growing up without experiencing the natural world." Tim Gill, author and child play expert at 'Rethinking Childhood

What is Forest School?

Forest School is a concept that can be adopted by any educational establishment for any age and ability. It is not government-funded but is a grass roots education movement. Forest School sessions are not one-off visits, but a regular feature of the school timetable. Forest School sessions are run throughout the year in all weathers. Young people develop confidence, self-esteem, skills and knowledge  through hands-on learning experiences in a woodland or natural environment with trees.

A Forest School site can be a wild area within school grounds, or a designated area of a local woodland. Forest School sessions are led by trained Forest School leaders, often a teacher. Forest Schools are one of many woodland education activities that are meeting the increasing demand for outdoor learning and play in wild areas.

The Charities behind the campaign

Two environmental charities - Sylva Foundation and the Forest School Association - have come together to promote what many teachers and educators believe is the most effective kind of environmental education – Forest School.

The Sylva Foundation is working to care for forests across Britain and to promote deeper environmental understanding in all people. We work with thousands of woodland owners across Britain, conduct research with leading universities, and have developed innovative education projects - such as the OneOak project and The New Sylva book. Sylva is a charity registered in England and Wales 1128516 and in Scotland SC041892. www.Sylva.org.uk

The Forest School Association is a registered charity and the professional body for Forest School within the UK. We are devoted to promoting quality Forest School for all. Our goal is to promote learning about woodlands and to enhance people’s well-being through regular educational experiences in local woodlands. FSA is a charity registered in England and Wales 1155616. www.forestschoolassociation.org


What We Need & What You Receive

There is no funding or grant specifically for Forest Schools in the UK. School budgets are decreasing. Forest Schools are not a government funded programme. 

The money raised through this campaign will provide the only fund specifically set up to support Forest Schools.

We aim to raise £30,000 to provide a range of practical support to schools that want to establish and maintain a Forest School. The funds raised will target areas of the country that have few or no existing Forest Schools.

  • £60 will pay for one child to attend a Forest School for one year.
  • £500 will help towards creating an area of school grounds into a woodland dedicated to a Forest School.
  • £1000 will pay for one ‘Forest School Start Up Kit’ - essential for each new site
  • £3,000 will allow one new forest school to be set up.
  • £10,000 will enable Sylva to employ a part-time teacher to train Forest School Leaders in how to care for their forest sites.
We offer a number of unique rewards for people who give £25 or more, but every donation will make an impact.


Why is this important?

All children need regular contact with the natural world to explore, play and learn: Forest Schools provide all children with this essential contact and freedom in a woodland environment.

Without Forest Schools our children face a crisis.  In 2009 Natural England carried out an extensive study into how children’s contact with the natural world and play patterns have changed:

  • Children spend less time playing in natural places, such as woodlands, countryside and heaths, than they did in previous generations. 
  • Less than 10% play in such places compared to 40% of adults when they were young. 
  • Children today would like more freedom to play outside (81%). 
  • Nearly half of the children say they are not allowed to play outside unsupervised and nearly a quarter are worried to be out alone.

*

Children suffer physical and mental health problems if they do not have regular contact with the natural world: Forest Schools help the personal development and wellbeing of the whole child.

A recent NHS study revealed that one-in-five children are obese by the time they leave primary school.

The Nuffield Foundation (2013) reported that the proportion of young people reporting frequent feelings of depression or anxiety has increased in recent years - doubling between the mid 1980s and the mid 2000s.  It has been shown by a number of recent studies in deprived areas in Scotland how regular contact with the natural world can increase a sense of well being and combat stress and depression by regulating cortisol levels in the brain (e.g. Roe et al, 2013).

*

Children face barriers to experiencing natural and wild places: Forest Schools overcome many of these barriers and are part of a child's school day.

The Project Wild campaign identifies that over use of new technology can displace nature in children's lives leading to behaviour problems, obesity, mental health problems like depression, and illness like diabetes.

Children lack adult role models who will lead them outdoors and inspire, guide and educate them about the natural world. Forest School Leaders are trained to provide children with oppportunities for play, learning and risk benefit in a managed woodland site. Forest School training gives teachers, educators and parents the confidence to take children into natural and wild places. 

*

Children will become adults who do not value nature and its benefits: Forest Schools increase children's value, understanding and sustainable use of the natural world.

Just being outside is not enough – Forest Schools are important because they move children on from experiencing nature to understanding it. They are then able to care for it and grow to value it as adults. Forest Schools help our children to value UK woodlands as much as the Amazonian rainforest.


The Impact

Forest Schools have a holistic impact on children unlike any other formal educational process. Outcomes of Forest School include:
  • Social skills = team work, friendships, relationships with the wider community, involvement of parents and grandparents. 
  • Environmental values = connection with nature, interest sparked, conservation and ecology, sustainable use of woodlands. 
  • Physical improvement = risk taking, risk benefit, exercise, reducing obesity, confidence in outdoors
  • Intellectual achievement = memorable moments, inspirational experiences to complement classroom teaching across the curriculum areas
  • Spiritual benefits = an increased connection with nature, sense of peace and wellbeing
  • Emotional intelligence and self esteem increased = independence, child-led, responsible, new skills e.g. sawing!

We know from our existing educational work that many children never have an opportunity to experience the natural environment in woodlands. Some children from inner city schools have never worn a pair of welly boots before, others have never been allowed to play freely outdoors.

  • The more money we raise the more children will be introduced to nature through Forest School.
  • We will be training new Forest School leaders, which will have a longlasting impact over the years as they support and develop their own Forest Schools.
  • Our two charities are subject to the stringent rules of the Charity Commission.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word -  and share your love - by promoting our campaign. Some ideas:

  • Follow and promote us on Love Trees Love Wood on Facebook
  • Add our fundraising logo or banner to your website or email signature.
  • Hold a fundraising tree plant, conker-collecting, or wood-sawing challenge to raise money with your friends and community.
  • Offer the partners a unique reward that we could make available to donors in return for their generosity.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

Tim Gill, author and child play expert at 'Rethinking ChildhoodWhat is Forest School?Forest School is a concept that can be adopted by any educational establishment for any age and ability. It is not government-funded but is a grass roots education movement. Forest School sessions are not one-off visits, but a regular feature of the school timetable. Forest School sessions are run throughout the year in all weathers. Young people develop confidence, self-esteem, skills and knowledge  through hands-on learning experiences in a woodland or natural 
environment with trees.A Forest School site can be a wild area within school grounds, or a designated area of a local woodland. Forest School sessions are led by trained Forest School leaders, often a teacher. Forest Schools are one of many woodland education activities that are meeting the increasing demand for outdoor learning and play in wild areas. The Charities behind the campaignTwo environmental charities - Sylva Foundation and the Forest School Association - have come together to
promote what many teachers and educators believe is the most effective kind of environmental education – Forest School. 
The Sylva Foundation is working to care for forests across Britain and to promote deeper
environmental understanding in all people. We work with thousands of woodland
owners across Britain, conduct research with leading universities, and have
developed innovative education projects - such as the OneOak project and The
New Sylva book. Sylva is a charity registered in England and Wales 1128516 and in Scotland SC041892. www.Sylva.org.uk
The
Forest School Association is a registered charity and the professional body for
Forest School within the UK. We are devoted to promoting quality Forest School
for all. Our goal is to promote learning about woodlands and to enhance
people’s well-being through regular educational experiences in local woodlands. FSA is a charity registered in England and Wales 1155616. www.forestschoolassociation.org
What We Need & What You ReceiveThere is no funding or grant specifically for Forest 
Schools in the UK. School budgets are decreasing. Forest Schools are not
 a government funded programme. The money raised through this campaign will provide the only fund specifically set up to support Forest Schools. We aim to raise £30,000 to provide a range of practical support to schools that want to establish and maintain a Forest
School. The funds raised will target areas of the country that have few or no existing
Forest Schools. 


£60 will pay for one child to attend a Forest School for one year.


£500 will help towards creating an area of
school grounds into a woodland dedicated to a Forest School.


£1000 will pay for one
‘Forest School Start Up Kit’ - essential for each new site


£3,000 will allow one new forest
school to be set up. 


£10,000 will enable Sylva to employ a part-time teacher to train Forest School Leaders in how to care for their forest sites.

We offer a number of unique rewards for people who give £25 or more, but every donation will make an impact.Why is this important?

All children need regular contact with the natural world to explore, play and learn: Forest Schools provide all children with this essential contact and freedom in a woodland environment.Without Forest Schools our children face a crisis.  In 2009 Natural England carried out an extensive study into how
children’s contact with the natural world and play patterns have changed:
Children spend less time playing in natural places, such as
woodlands, countryside and heaths, than they did in previous generations. 
Less
than 10% play in such places compared to 40% of adults when they were young. 
Children
today would like more freedom to play outside (81%). 
Nearly half of the
children say they are not allowed to play outside unsupervised and nearly a quarter
are worried to be out alone.
*Children suffer physical and mental health problems if they do not have regular contact with the natural world: Forest Schools help the personal development and wellbeing of the whole child.A recent NHS
study revealed that one-in-five children are obese by the time they leave
primary school.The Nuffield Foundation (2013) reported that the proportion of young people reporting
frequent feelings of depression or anxiety has increased in recent years - doubling between the mid
1980s and the mid 2000s.  It has been shown by
a number of recent studies in deprived areas in Scotland how regular contact
with the natural world can increase a sense of well being and combat stress and
depression by regulating cortisol levels in the brain (e.g. Roe et al, 2013).*Children face barriers to experiencing natural and wild places: Forest Schools overcome many of these barriers and are part of a child's school day. The Project
Wild campaign identifies that over use of new technology can displace nature in children's lives leading to behaviour problems, obesity, mental health problems
like depression, and illness like diabetes.Children lack adult role models who will lead them outdoors and inspire, guide and educate them about the natural world. Forest School Leaders are trained to provide children with oppportunities for play, learning and risk benefit in a managed woodland site. Forest School training gives teachers, educators and parents the confidence to take children into natural and wild places. *Children will become adults who do not value nature and its benefits: Forest Schools increase children's value, understanding and sustainable use of the natural world. Just
being outside is not enough – Forest Schools are important because they move
children on from experiencing nature to understanding it. They are then able to care for it and grow to value it as adults. Forest Schools help our children to value UK woodlands as much as the Amazonian rainforest.
The ImpactForest Schools have a holistic impact on children unlike any other formal educational process. Outcomes of Forest School include:

Social skills = team work, friendships, relationships with the wider community, involvement of parents and grandparents. 

Environmental values = connection with nature, interest sparked, conservation and ecology, sustainable use of woodlands. 

Physical improvement = risk taking, risk benefit, exercise, reducing obesity, confidence in outdoors

Intellectual achievement = memorable moments, inspirational experiences to complement classroom teaching across the curriculum areas

Spiritual benefits = an increased connection with nature, sense of peace and wellbeing

Emotional
intelligence and self esteem increased = independence, child-led, responsible, new skills
e.g. sawing!

We know from our existing educational work that many children never have an opportunity to experience the natural environment in woodlands. Some children from inner city schools have never worn a pair of welly boots before, others have never been allowed to play freely outdoors.
The more money we raise the more children will be introduced to nature through Forest School.
We will be training new Forest School leaders, which will have a longlasting impact over the years as they support and develop their own Forest Schools.

Our two charities are subject to the stringent rules of the Charity Commission.

Other Ways You Can HelpPlease spread the word -  and share your love - by promoting our campaign. Some ideas:
Follow and promote us on Love Trees Love Wood on Facebook

Add our fundraising logo or banner to your website or email signature.

Hold a fundraising tree plant, conker-collecting, or wood-sawing challenge to raise money with your friends and community.
Offer the partners a unique reward that we could make available to donors in return for their generosity.

Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
We Need To Pay Our Expert Witness

Hydrogeologists are invaluable when presenting allegations of water contamination before a court of law. Scott Ely, who has spoken out as a gas industry whistle-blower, and his family are proceeding with a landmark federal lawsuit over drilling-related water contamination in Pennsylvania. Earlier this June, the judge ruled that Scott's evidence is compelling and credible, permitting jury selection. We need to compensate Paul Rubin, our expert hydrogeologist, for his analysis of Scott's water before the trial begins.


Water Contamination in Dimock

There have been 119 Marcellus Shale wells drilled in Dimock Township, Susquehanna County.

In 2008, well water in homes along Carter Rd went bad after Cabot Oil & Gas developed the first fracked wells in northeast Pennsylvania. Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection determined that well casing failures in the Baker, Gesford, Ratzel, and Ely wells had caused 17 water wells to become contaminated. Cabot subsequently signed a consent agreement admitting fault and began remediation to plug or repair the wells.

In 2011, HydroQuest's Paul Rubin, an expert hydrogeologist, determined in his initial findings that Scott Ely's water contained lead and manganese at 5.8 and 10 times State Maximum Contaminate Levels and arsenic at 15 times the State MCL level. He found aluminum concentration of 28 mg/l, some 140 times the State MCL.

Aluminum is a potent neurotoxin that may be linked to dementia, including Alzheimer’s like health symptoms. Similarly, iron was detected at 34 mg/l, some 113 times the State MCL Safe Drinking Water standard.

At the time, Mr. Rubin stated, "While all analyses have not been completed, preliminary findings also indicate the presence of low level hexanes, octanes, and decanes."

He added "However, the high pH of the water indicates the presence of SIGNIFICANT other frack - related chemicals that are both unknown and untested – chemical compounds that do not have MCLs – chemicals that potentially present long-term chronic exposure to toxins and carcinogens."

Rubin found that the pH of the water has repeatedly been found to be around 9.5 – a very basic water, some 10 times the normal outer MCL State drinking water standard range of pH 8.5 and, quite likely, 100 times that of a more normal Dimock groundwater pH. "This is highly unusual and extremely troubling. Something is VERY wrong with this water," he wrote in testimony offered at a press conference.

Holding up a sample of Scott's water, Mr. Rubin said, "Here, you can see it as it now comes out of the well – the color of chocolate milk, five times the maximum allowable PA MCL Safe Drinking Water standard (75 vs. 15 color units) for color. Even after weeks, it still does not settle out"


What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $1,500 to pay for Paul Rubin's time and analysis. He will need to be deposed by the Cabot attorneys, prepare for cross-examination, and has been gracious with his professional time thus far, offering Dimock families his services at reduced rates.

  • For all donors, we will mention you in a video to thank you for your support.
  • You will be the first to know the progress on Scott's landmark case.
  • You or your group will be welcome in Dimock for a private tour of fracking, related infrastructure, and to meet families with water contamination.

The Impact

If Scott's case is successful, we will finally have some closure on the Dimock case and compensation, in the best case scenario, would include a permanent water supply for at least the Ely family.

At the very least, the discovery phase will serve as an opportunity to compel evidence like internal communications from Cabot that will reveal the standard operating procedures when families cry foul.

Anyone interested in public health, environmental justice, and corporate accountability, should find our fundraiser a worthy cause.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute money, that doesn't mean you can't help. Please share this page and encourage your friends and family to donate.
